name: Martin SCHULZ
text: In accordance with Article 7 of the Code of Conduct for Members of the European Parliament in the field of financial interests and conflicts of interest, yesterday, July 15, 2014, I appointed the five members of the Advisory Committee on Members' Conduct.These are: Danuta Maria Huebner Mady Delvaux-Stehres Sajjad Karim Francisco Sosa Wagner Jiří Maštálka The two reserve members will be named in the next few days because we still have to contact them and have not yet received an answer from all of them.The five full members can start their work immediately.I would like to thank my colleagues for their willingness to participate.***** Mr Glezos, you have raised a point of order.

name: Emmanouil GLEZOS
text: Mr President, yesterday morning President Juncker began his speech by saying that dreams have a place here.After a while, at least, the dreams of democracy were destroyed when the dear President Schulz refused to give the floor to his colleague Papadakis to explain why Le Pen does not express it.It was an explanation of a second, but the President denied it.I consider this to be a violation of the notion of democracy, and I ask President Schulz, whom I know very well, to acknowledge his mistake.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Mr. Glezos! Anyone in this House can speak up and comment on a point of order or on the agenda, just like you have just done. You have spoken here, I have given you the floor. You did not speak on the agenda or on the agenda, but you were able to express yourself here. Mr Papadakis did not do that yesterday. Mr Papadakis has not spoken up, nor has he given any signal that he wants to say anything. He just started talking. We are now 751 colleagues. If everyone here just starts to talk, then that is no longer a democracy, but rather a polyphony that means that nobody knows who said what. That is why I have asked Mr Papadakis to wait and properly speak up. If he had done that, I would have given him the floor. Not everyone here can quickly say “Look, I'm not interested here. I'm going to say what I'm thinking here. ”It doesn't work that way. I have also given Mr Papadakis the opportunity to express that, as a member of the Communist Party of Greece and as a non-attached party, he does not feel represented by Mrs Marine Le Pen. I can understand that, and I am hereby making it public again what he wanted to say: that Mrs Le Pen spoke on behalf of the non-attached, but not on his behalf. That, I believe, has made that generally clear here.

name: Martin SCHULZ

name: Rebecca HARMS

name: Martin SCHULZ

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: I cannot answer the last question.I do not know what the commissioners are entitled to for the rest of their lives.It would be nice for her if it were.I will inquire about it.First of all, the Conference of Presidents has stated that this vote should take place en bloc.I put that to the vote in the Conference of Presidents yesterday.There was a clear majority in favor of us voting en bloc here.Ms. Harms has now made a motion to vote individually.We have a request to speak, and that was Mr Fox.Would anyone like to speak against Mrs Harms' proposal?

name: József SZÁJER
text: Mr President, I would ask, we will be holding another vote very soon on the new College of Commissioners; are we going to vote en bloc on that? The decision of the Conference of Presidents is just following the rules, namely that we have now to vote on four Commissioners together. Does that mean you are going to ask for separate votes there as well, or what is your view in this case?  I am not sure that we have to re-write previous decisions all the time just because some colleagues change their minds. In the committees, however, there was an opportunity and my message to these colleagues is as follows. You used this opportunity in the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs to vote against. You lost. If you want to lose again here then it is up to you. We are not supporting this separation.

name: Gabriele ZIMMER
text: A question of a point of order: I would like to know whether the use of the block vote is mandatory for the subsequent nomination of commissioners, because this is not the vote of the Commission as a whole.I am not aware that a block vote is compulsorily carried out when re-nominating commissioners.As a group, we said that yesterday.(Applause)

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Mrs. Zimmer! Voting en bloc is clearly not mandatory. Voting en bloc across the entire commission is mandatory. We do not have any rules on renaming, it is up to the company to decide. That is why I brought a procedure yesterday in preparation for this sitting in the Conference of Presidents, where you were present. There I established and had it established - because I do not decide that alone and it should not be my sole decision - how the Conference of Presidents, which has to prepare this meeting, sees it. In the Conference of Presidents there was a large majority in favor of voting en bloc. Mrs Harms has now requested that this decision of the Conference of Presidents be corrected and that it be put to the vote here in an individual vote. It is a question of fairness that we are putting Mrs Harms' motion to the vote. (The application is rejected by electronic vote.)

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Mister President!According to Rule 38 of the Rules of Procedure, Parliament has to consider the financial consequences of a legal act that it commits.It has to determine the financial consequences.You have just been asked what financial consequences the election of the Commissioners will have for three months.Parliament must first be informed of this.You owe us the information before we vote.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: These commissioners are elected for the remainder of the current commission's term of office. The same ends on the last day of October. The next commission will take office on November 1st. In other words, the gentlemen and ladies on whom you are voting will take up their mandate with immediate effect and it will end on October 31. All additions to this, the service law as well as the pension and pension law claims, result from the existing rules of procedure for members of the European Commission, which you, Mr. Lucke, are certainly familiar with. They are available in the house. All members of this commission and all candidates have declared their financial interests in advance. The pension entitlements result from the pension decrees of the Commission and the European institutions, which are certainly also available in detail on the intranet of this company at any time. (Heckling) If you are not familiar with these, Mr Lucke, I am surprised because otherwise you always give the impression that you are perfectly informed. (The vote is taken.) This closes voting time.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The next item is the debate on the Commission statement on youth employment (2014/2713(RSP)).

name: László Andor
text: Member of the Commission. - Madam President, in his inaugural address two weeks ago in Strasbourg, the President of the European Parliament outlined to this assembly what he sees as the major challenges facing Europe. The first challenge he mentioned was the shocking level of youth unemployment, which he sees as a source of desperation and hopelessness that constitutes a threat to our democracy. Those are very strong words. As we all know, they are perfectly warranted, mainly, but not exclusively, in respect of the countries and regions of the eurozone periphery, which have been affected by a dramatic rise in youth unemployment in recent years. The Commission has been adamant about keeping youth unemployment at the top of the EU agenda and launched an unprecedented range of measures combining policy and financial support.  I would like to thank the European Parliament for its support both in terms of bringing about the Youth Guarantee and of ensuring adequate resources from the European Union budget. Under the Youth Guarantee, all Member States have committed themselves to ensuring that all young people under 25 receive a good-quality offer of employment, continued education, or an apprenticeship or traineeship within four months of leaving formal education or becoming unemployed. The Youth Guarantee is a major structural reform, as well as a key social investment.  In order to support the implementation of the Youth Guarantee, the Commission launched a European alliance for apprenticeships and put forward a quality framework for traineeships. All 28 Member States have now submitted Youth Guarantee implementation plans as requested by the European Council. I welcome the efforts made by the Member States to put in place the Youth Guarantee schemes. I recognise that this is not an easy task, as it requires strategic reforms.  The Commission has assessed the national Youth Guarantee implementation plans as part of the 2014 European Semester. The analysis shows that progress has been made across the board. However, there are a number of challenges, including strengthening the capacity of public employment services, providing quality offers, reforming education and training systems, and reaching out to inactive young people. Altogether, 18 Member States received country-specific recommendations focusing on one or several of these points I have just mentioned. A total of eight Member States were invited to act more decisively to implement the Youth Guarantee. Making the Youth Guarantee happen requires that all available resources are there to get started as quickly as possible and achieve concrete results, already in the short term. The European Social Fund, with more than EUR 10 billion every year in the 2014-2020 period, is the most significant source of funding for implementing the Youth Guarantee. In addition, the European Council has agreed to launch a Youth Employment Initiative targeting young people aged between 15 and 24 not in employment, education or training – the so-called ‘NEETs’ – who live in the regions most affected by youth unemployment. This is a dedicated financial tool worth EUR 6.4 billion which directly targets individuals and supports the implementation of the Youth Guarantee schemes.  The initiative should focus on job-creating measures, including well-targeted wage subsidies and recruitment subsidies, apprenticeships and traineeships. It can also support activation measures such as job search guidance and assistance, as well as further training.  The Parliament and Council agreed to frontload the Youth Employment Initiative resources so the EUR 6.4 billion are committed in 2014 and 2015 rather than over the entire period between 2014 to 2020. Parliament also agreed to allow Member States to claim related expenditure from 1 September 2013. This means that the Commission can reimburse the Member States once the relevant operational programmes are adopted. In addition, when a Member State chooses to programme the Youth Employment Initiative under a dedicated operational programme, the Commission can approve it before the adoption of the partnership agreement, thereby speeding up implementation. Where do we stand now? France and Italy have presented such dedicated operational programmes. The Commission approved them in June and July respectively. As a result, EUR 1.5 billion, or a quarter of the total allocation, has already been committed. In addition, 11 out of the 20 eligible Member States have officially submitted operational programmes covering youth-employment-initiative-related actions. Seven Member States have not yet done so.  Last Friday, the Commission organised a seminar to support Member States in accelerating the programming and practical implementation of the Youth Employment Initiative. On this occasion, the Commission clarified outstanding issues regarding the programming of the Youth Employment Initiative and had bilateral technical meetings with the Member States. Following the seminar, I am sending a letter to ministers, encouraging them to ensure swift completion of the Youth Employment Initiative programming. The Youth Employment Initiative, together with the Youth Guarantee, should be a reality on the ground as a matter of urgency. We cannot afford to delay the implementation of such a crucial initiative. The Commission encourages Member States to continue their efforts to ensure swift implementation of the Youth Employment Initiative. The Commission will continue to assist them in this endeavour and, at the same time, we also have to continue developing the macroeconomic framework in order to ensure that fiscal and monetary policies become more supportive for growth and job creation in all countries and all regions of the European Union.

name: Maria João RODRIGUES
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, I am a former Minister of Labour and now Vice-Chair of the S&D Group on social and economic issues. I have a very difficult question for the Commission but first let me greet Commissioner László Andor, who has done a great deal in a very difficult situation. Commissioner, you fought for job creation, you fought for social investment: investing in people is the right way to invest in Europe. Lastly, you launched the Youth Guarantee.  Now the situation is as follows. In spite of many efforts, the unemployment rate remains very high in Europe, particularly the youth unemployment rate. Beyond that we have divergences, economic and social divergences, between regions and Member States, which never existed in the past. So something is deeply wrong in Europe. I do not believe there is a future for Europe if there is no future for young people in Europe. This means that we need to have a much higher ambition as regards tackling this problem. My question is therefore very simple. Based on your experience and what has been done so far, which stronger instruments should we have in the European Union to tackle and reduce youth unemployment and stop these economic and social divergences? These divergences are undermining our European ambition, our European project and our European cohesion. We are losing the win-win game we should have in Europe.  So my question for you, Commissioner, is what ideas do you have about that? What is the stronger instrument we should be building together in order to come before our citizens with a convincing response?

name: Anthea McINTYRE
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, may I take the opportunity to welcome you to the chair and encourage you to keep people to their speaking times. I will try to do my best.  I am really pleased that our first proper session of this Parliament is concentrating on this really important issue of youth unemployment – or youth employment if you want to be positive – and I would like to thank Commissioner Andor for his words.  It is indeed encouraging that Mr Juncker has put job creation as his top priority, but we have to recognise that it is not the Commission that creates jobs, it is not Parliament that creates jobs, it is not even the Member States’ governments that create jobs. It is businesses that create jobs. SMEs create 85% of new jobs across Europe. So our job must be to create an environment where businesses can grow and can create jobs, and businesses will only create more jobs and recruit more people if the economic environment encourages growth: if they can rely on a qualified workforce, if labour markets are sufficiently flexible, if labour costs, including wages, are in line with productivity, if social protection systems make work more attractive, and if regulation is proportionate and evidence-based. We have seen a trend towards more skill-intensive jobs – almost 90% of the jobs expected to be created and become vacant by 2020 require medium or high qualifications – and Europe’s education and training systems are not adapted to the business skills needs that we will need in the future years. We need a better supply of science, technology, engineering and maths skills, the stem subjects, and those are currently not going to match the increasing demands of business. There are encouraging signs and companies are bringing jobs back. We just have to encourage them.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, I too would like to welcome my colleague Mrs McGuinness to the chair; I wish you well. Before the election youth unemployment was the biggest issue for many groups and unfortunately it still is: with 7.5 million young Europeans between the ages of 15 and 24 not in employment, education or training, and 6.8 million in the same situation between the ages of 25 and 30. At European level we have a number of instruments. We have the Youth Guarantee, we have the Social Fund, we have the Youth Employment Initiative, the Quality Framework for Traineeships, the European Alliance for Apprenticeships and of course the Programme for Employment and Social Innovation. I suppose in many ways it is too early to really assess the progress made by most of these instruments – for example the Youth Guarantee or the Youth Employment Initiative – but I think it would be fair to say that so far progress is slow and uneven. In this context I think we need a renewed effort from the Commission to encourage Member States to immediately set about the implementation of the Youth Guarantee. I mean, after all, this is supposed to be a flagship project for European Union policy and if we are really serious about its implementation we need to take action. Obviously I believe youth unemployment needs to be a specific objective within the European Semester and also measures to combat youth unemployment. I am happy that it is included in the country-specific recommendations and the national reform projects and that must remain a priority. I believe too that the Youth Guarantee should be extended to young people under 30. However we also have to deal with the supply side as well as the demand side and in this context we need to ensure easier access to financing and simpler rules for setting up new businesses. However in many countries, like my own, Ireland, many SMEs are already overburdened with debt. It is not simply a question of easier access to finance – small businesses do not want to take on new borrowings and there is a problem with adequate working capital – so they are caught in a bind. Some mechanisms have to be found to deal with the overhang of debt, otherwise many SMEs will struggle and are doomed to fail.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Ms Harkin, thank you for your kind remarks.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President, how long have we been here, we have been here, discussing, regretting, listening to commiserations, promises of everything to be done to solve a problem that is leaving young people of an entire generation without the possibility of planning safely and dignity your life project? It is important to understand what has changed since then: little or nothing. 23% of young people in the European Union are unemployed, and in some countries, such as Greece and Spain, more than half of young people in these countries are unemployed. In several countries like mine, for example, attempts are being made today to manipulate the statistics, omitting that a slight decrease in this statistic is also due, rather, to the untied bleeding of immigration, to the growing number of young people who are forced to leave their country, which only finds an equivalent if we go back to times of poverty several decades ago when we had fascism. And also omitting that those jobs that are created have very precarious employment links, which are replaced ... work with rights for work without rights. Now we have to know the following: how is this Youth Guarantee program different, is it different from all the other programs that have existed before? Occupational and internship programs that did not give any perspective on the future, but that have existed for several years. So, how is this program different from the ones we all already know? And, if we really want to end precariousness, one of the wounds that most compromises the present and future of these young workers ... We need to know from the European Commission, please, to understand each other, why in the recent recommendations of the Semester European Parliament impose on several countries, such as mine, the flexibility of wages and the implementation of forms of regulation of collective labor contracts? Therefore, ending collective bargaining, one of the guarantors of labor rights. We have to understand that, otherwise we don't understand anything that is going on.

name: Terry REINTKE
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen! During the election campaign, we heard incessantly how much should be done to get the problem of youth unemployment under control in the European Union. My group will make this issue one of the most important priorities in the upcoming legislature, not only because it will deprive millions of young people in Europe, but also because, in the long term, it will lead to European societies and the European Union itself falling apart. For years, young people in Europe have been told about austerity policies. It is said that one has to consolidate public budgets in order to make new employment possible. In addition to the aforementioned social consequences of this policy, even the term “austerity” is wrong. Is it economical to pursue a policy that, according to a Eurofound study, takes away 153 billion euros from the EU member states every year? Is it economical if this money is wasted because not enough is being done in the fight against youth unemployment? This money and the half-baked support will not be enough to solve the dramatic problem of youth unemployment. We therefore demand, among other things, an end to the blind austerity policy, which primarily affects young people in the field of education and labor market policy, and instead invest in the future of young people. We call for a meaningful implementation of the Youth Guarantee with more support from the European level, as is also proposed in the joint resolution. And we ask that, in the face of many other demands that will be decided in the resolution together with many Members of this Parliament, these words are finally followed by action. Because the question of whether or not the European Union will be able to solve the problem of youth unemployment in the next few years will point the way for the entire integration project. If we fail, we lose a common future and an entire generation. But if we can work together to master this challenge in solidarity, it will be a first step towards a socially just and stable European Union. Therefore: we have to fight this fight now, before it is too late, and finally give young people a perspective within the European Union again. And we hope to have the Commission by our side.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: Madam President, the concern of bourgeois governments, the European Union and all parties that support it for youth unemployment is both hypocritical and hypocritical. EU unemployment recycling programs do not aim to alleviate the unemployed young people who are deprived of both unemployment benefits and medical care. On the contrary, in addition to further financing monopolies with hot money, they also subsidize businesses with free labor, promoting greater overall wage cuts and the generalization of flexible employment. False training, unpaid apprenticeship, all education, based on the directives of the European Union, produces a semi-skilled workforce, flexible in the demands of monopolies, wandering from branch to branch and from country to country. And why this? Because cheap labor is the first condition for competitiveness and business profits. The Communist Party of Greece is fighting for the essential protection of the unemployed, unemployment benefits for all without conditions, insurance and free medical care for as long as unemployment lasts, reduction of utility tariffs, no power and water cuts. He fights to stop the chase of the banks against them.

name: Verónica LOPE FONTAGNÉ
text: Madam President, Commissioner, we are starting a new term and I am glad to see that youth employment appears on the agenda from the beginning, which shows the commitment of this Parliament to one of the biggest concerns in Europe. The crisis has taught us that we cannot return to the productive model that we had ten years ago, but that we have to reinvent ourselves; To achieve this, we have to start working from education, adapting it to labor needs and basing it on sectors with a wide margin of growth and job creation. Promoting youth employment is fully linked to supporting SMEs and the self-employed, the main generators of employment at European level, and, to achieve this, we have to create a favorable environment for their establishment and growth, reduce administrative obstacles and, mainly, facilitate The credit. There are currently around two million job vacancies in the European Union that could be filled if all obstacles to mobility were removed and there was greater coordination of public employment services. The last legislature - and the Commissioner has already realized this - the Guarantee and the Youth Initiative were approved, which are already underway. However, Commissioner, in order for our young people to have career opportunities that match their qualifications, we need to act before problems appear. Therefore, I would like to ask you whether you expect a truly clearly defined long-term youth employment strategy and endowed with the necessary funds to achieve it. And, secondly, I also wanted to ask you if there is any proposal aimed at favoring the entry into the labor market of young migrants, disabled or belonging to the Roma community, who have greater difficulties in finding employment.

name: Jutta STEINRUCK
text: Madam President! The still high youth unemployment is a scandal. For many years now, we Social Democrats have been calling for rapid action and concrete proposals that actually have an impact, including investments in growth to create jobs or the youth guarantee. What has been done so far is too little. The fight against youth unemployment must be a top priority for everyone - for us here in Parliament, for the Commission and also for the Council. The shuffling of Black Peter, who is to blame for the fact that nothing moves, does not bring us forward. The 6 billion euros for the Youth Guarantee are too little. We have to support the Member States in implementation, including in calling up the funds. We also have to look carefully. What will be done on site with the funds? Is youth unemployment actually being combated? Or is the cause of youth unemployment actually being tackled? We have to make concrete proposals now: What happens when the funds are exhausted? We need to make sure that there is more funding after 2016. And we need more European solidarity, for example when it comes to co-financing. We Social Democrats also call for standards in the implementation of the Youth Guarantee, the establishment of binding targets for combating youth unemployment within the framework of the European Semester. In addition, we also need European minimum standards for good work, for good apprenticeship positions and good vocational internships. Wage and social dumping is not the solution to youth unemployment. I appeal to everyone not only to hold summits that are effective in the media, but to tackle the plight of an entire generation just as ambitiously as to enforce economic freedoms in the internal market or to save banks.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Thank you, Madam President. The youth unemployment rate in the EU is still too high. I am glad that this problem has been recognized in this home and that there is a consensus on how to solve it as seriously as possible. Unfortunately, however, we have not yet reached a consensus on measures that would be effective and beneficial for all Member States. On the contrary, I think we are going in the wrong direction by trying to find a universal solution, without taking into account the specificities of each of the Member States. From the perspective of poorer members, youth mobility is a disastrous solution that only improves statistical indicators in the short term. For example, if Germany needs workers, while in some member states a lot of young people are sitting without a job, then logic dictates that they look for happiness in Germany. This is certainly good for Germany, but it is disastrous for the poorer members who thus travel towards economic and demographic collapse. If we want a healthy Union of Sustainable Economies, we need to approach this problem at the level of the individual Member State. First of all, we need to work on further connecting the education system and the real sector so that young people can meet the needs of the labor market after graduation. I also consider it crucial to encourage the entrepreneurial spirit among young people and make it as easy as possible to start private companies. Europe today offers countless opportunities to young people. The only possibility that young people from poorer member states do not have at the moment is precisely the possibility of surviving in their own country, among their closest ones. If we want a Europe of unity, solidarity and a bright future, we must make it possible for them.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: Madam President, Commissioner, the future of Europe is its 94 million young people under 30 years of age. For this reason, as the new President Juncker also promised in his speech yesterday, we want to ask the Commission to urge the Member States to opt for increasing the age limit for recipients of employment aid - such as the Guarantee youth, but not alone—, from the current age of 25 to 30, because seven years of economic crisis have left millions of young people out of aid, who are losing hope. We ask you to urge the States to link youth employment policies to sustainable contracts, to quality contracts. We ask that they confront unequivocally underemployment and growing precariousness. We ask, please, that you urge the Member States to also establish a preferential and key tool, such as the Eures network, the guarantee of mobility and the possibility of using the Union's resources so that the available employment is better distributed and best used. Commissioner, we cannot afford to leave not one euro, not one minute, not one available resource unused to deal with this unbearable youth unemployment rate that embarrasses all Europeans.

name: Rina Ronja KARI
text: Madam President! A lot of good things have been said today about youth unemployment. Thank you! But, ladies and gentlemen, that is not enough! First, we need to be honest. The youth guarantee as it stands today has been a failure. Secondly, there is a serious risk that it will be misused to put pressure on working conditions and to provide cheap labor. Thirdly, it does not address the fundamental problem, namely the EU's austerity policy, which is creating even more youth unemployment. EU austerity policies mean, for example, dismissal of civil servants and higher retirement age. It helps to create even more young unemployed people. Of course, that is also the reason why we are proposing a radical change in EU policy. We demand that the EU's cut-off line be stopped, and at the same time we must recognize that the labor markets are vastly different in the various EU countries. The solution is to give member states the opportunity to find solutions themselves - without forcing a unification. It must be possible to make public investments in e.g. the education and health sector, as it can create more jobs and it must be possible to redeploy at work so that some can take further training while others fit their work. We have many suggestions, but it requires a new course. It requires that we acknowledge that the old path is wrong and that we dare to do something else. Let's start the new course today!

name: Karima DELLI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the Turin summit of July 11, which was to discuss this crucial issue of youth unemployment, has been canceled. This is the image we give of this priority. In spite of incantatory speeches, in spite of the good intentions displayed during the campaigns, the reality of the policies in favor of the young people remains the same, that is to say "at the pick-up", late and not at all up to the challenges . What else to expect? Do you want a generation conflict? Do you want all young people to go elsewhere than in Europe to find an El Dorado that does not exist at home? Young people today are experiencing a real social hazing. The most striking thing takes place when entering the labor market, in this period of transition which is lengthening, notably with internships; internships which are neither recognized nor remunerated and which are truly an adjustment variable for this youth. Youth unemployment distresses young people but it also distresses families. Since 2008, they have been subjected to the double penalty, even though they are the first victims of the financial crisis and its consequences. The austerity implemented by the Member States is pushing them even further into precariousness. Is it normal that 30% of 15-27 year olds live below the poverty line? We should all be standing in this hemicycle to say no to that. It's intolerable! Youth really should not be this adjustment variable for the economy. So you are all talking about debt. I offer you a good debt, one word: invest. Investing in this youth, in education, in training, in our common good because it is they who will make the Europe of tomorrow. Finally, this resolution, it calls on you, the Commission. This new Commission must say that young people have rights: the right to housing, the right to decent work, the right to a paid job at its fair value, but let's go further, put in place the youth guarantee a real reality and, then, let's be ambitious with a real unemployment insurance fund. It is high time to reconcile Europe, the Europe of citizens, and for that we must fight concretely against youth unemployment.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: Madam President, it seems to me that many Members of this place have forgotten that they claim to believe in the principle of subsidiarity. They have forgotten that decisions should be taken at the level closest to the citizen. The challenges facing each of the Member States are varied and different. In my constituency of the North-East of England, almost one in four young people are unemployed. We have the highest levels of youth unemployment in the UK. Our manufacturing industry, which was once the powerhouse of the region, has been decimated. It is European Union legislation which is preventing us from being competitive once more. Competitiveness is what drives economies forward; it is what is needed to prevent jobs going overseas. In the UK we need to learn from other countries; we need to learn from Germany that there should be no stigma attached to manual jobs. We need to learn that young people should be taught to take as much pride from vocational as from academic routes. Most of all we need an education system that reflects the needs of industry and 21st Century society. The free movement of workers, which means uncontrolled immigration, causes a massive problem in the UK. That principle might have worked when all EU countries had similar standards of living but, when we have Member States with a minimum wage of 80 pence an hour, migration to the UK becomes a big issue. It causes wage compression and it means experienced workers from other countries are able to take UK-based jobs and deprive British young people of their first step on the career ladder, and what we do not need is misguided European Union intervention.  As the President of the EPP’s Youth Wing, Costas Kyranakis, has said, the Youth Guarantee Fund is not working. The measures push short-term employment and short-term internships but, when only 9% of interns actually go on to get the job, this is not effective. The International Labour Organisation has said it is ineffective. The Youth Guarantee has come to mean guaranteed failure. Sometimes the answer is not more Europe. The answer is for countries to work together, for national governments to innovate, for us to learn from each other, to learn from best practice and to learn from the many charitable organisations which have a phenomenal success rate in getting young people back into work. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: Question asked under the 'blue card' procedure.- Madam President, I am surprised that you, as a Member of the European Parliament, are raising the issue of banning the free movement of people in the European Union, but I want to ask you a question.From everything you said, I did not understand that you proposed something concrete for today's topic, namely increasing the employment rate of young people.If you can, tell me a concrete measure that you propose.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: blue-card answer. – Well, the concrete measure is very simple, is it not? The problem we have at the moment is that we are getting more Europe, we are getting more legislation, more red tape strangling our businesses and of course if we deal with that problem then we will be much more competitive. And on terms of free movement, is the whole point not that different countries with different standards of living actually have different needs and that when you try to have a one-size-fits-all straitjacket affecting 28 different countries at once, then you know that it is not going to work? The free movement is a principle of the 1950s and the 1960s. We live today in a 21st century society and it is high-time that this place grew up and recognised that the future does not lie with the failed old EU institutions. (Applause)

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, in Italy there are 10 million and 48 thousand people living in conditions of poverty. Over 6 million are absolute poor, therefore people who are unable to purchase goods and services to have a dignified life. These numbers would be enough to understand the dramatic situation in which millions of Italians live. But that's not enough. In Italy there are 3 million and 200 thousand unemployed and of these 700 thousand are young people aged 15 to 24. And do you know what Juncker said, the one who just yesterday became President of the European Commission? He said that unemployment in Italy is the fault of the Italians. No, dear colleagues! The problems of the Italian unemployed, of European citizens, especially young people, arise here! They come from this wrong Europe! They arise from the failure of the single market and the failure of the euro. Wages cut to the bone, social dumping, lack of liquidity for businesses and loss of wage purchasing power. Enough of this Europe of banks and enemy of the citizens. Your President Juncker, the one you voted for, said yesterday that new migrants are needed. We need 50 million migrants because we need manpower, we need a workforce. But does Juncker know that there are 25 million unemployed in Europe? Does he know that a quarter of young people in Europe cannot find work? No new migrants are needed. The job market is saturated. There is no place for a single migrant if there is no work for our young people. We have to help our young people. We must give hope and a future to our young people. Young Europeans need another more efficient and fairer Europe.

name: Elisabeth MORIN-CHARTIER
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I am saddened to note that this morning the Council left its benches empty on such an important issue. And this is only the reflection of what has just happened in the previous mandate with regard to this youth employment policy. This youth employment policy was supported by Parliament and by the Commission. It was not worn by the Council. This is the evil from which we suffer today. Because, obviously, it is the implementation of this policy by the Member States that is lacking today. I would like to come back to the substance of this policy. This policy is first and foremost to support the European Social Fund for the youth guarantee, which constitutes the backbone of our policy by 2020. The initiative for youth employment - and I have heard a lot of confusion this morning - is just the tip of the iceberg. The 6 billion euros is the front loading we obtained so that in 2014 and 2015 there are immediate policies that are put in place by the Member States for young people. Obviously, the Heads of State and Government were much more inclined to communicate on the subject than to hold the Turin summit, as Karima Delli said earlier. Today, it is they who must be put to work, because we need projects. And this also calls into question policies that are deeply governmental: exits without qualifications, therefore failure in training, apprenticeship and work-study, the link between academic training and professional life, the renewed training sectors that 'you also need to know how to wear. Yes, we need the Council to engage. Yes, we need forms of contract for young people that are stable contracts. Yes, we must also take care of the 25-30 year-olds, who remain in university because they cannot find a place in the job market. We need to help SMEs create jobs, encourage mobility for young people and regulate taxation on work. It is only at this price that we will be able to put together effective policies with Heads of State and Government by 2015. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8 , of the regulations))

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: blue-card question. – Well, here we are again and all we can hear about is more money, more spending. The question I want to ask is: are you not aware that the answer is never more government? The answer is surely that our young people need work. If they have more opportunities, because the flow of immigrants coming into the countries to fill the jobs is less, surely our young people can then get a footing and a start in the workplace, rather than constantly being undercut and beaten by people coming from elsewhere in the continent who are not required. Our young people need work in their own countries.

name: Elisabeth MORIN-CHARTIER
text: answer "blue card".- Do not count on me, dear colleague, to think like you that youth employment is necessarily linked to the closing of borders.Youth employment is necessarily training policies adapted to changes in the labor market.The company, the new professional sectors that are emerging by 2020, all the studies that we have done here, show that we must invest in the evolution of training.(The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Pervenche BERÈS
text: question "blue card".- Madame Morin-Chartier, do you recognize that this "youth guarantee", not only we fought to implement it, but we fought so that it can already benefit young people until30 years?That it can be directly financed by the European Social Fund and that France, in the government of Mr. Manuel Valls, be perfectly exemplary in its implementation since we are almost the first country to have implemented this youth guarantee.

name: Elisabeth MORIN-CHARTIER
text: answer "blue card".- Madame Berès, it's a bit of a Franco-French question.If we fought for all of this, we fought together, you and I, with the Commission and in front of the Council in many trialogues.I must say that today, as a Member of the European Parliament, there is one point that really struck me when the Commissioner reported on the implementation, and that is the fact that today'hui, this Youth Employment Initiative Fund - and I do not want to talk about the youth guarantee here again, because it is still a mistake - is only set up in a third of the European countries which have thereaccess.I call on the heads of state and government to pull themselves together.

name: Marita ULVSKOG
text: Madam President! I want to report the situation in the northern part of Europe, in Sweden. Even there, we have a very high level of youth unemployment today, which is why we have also been granted extra support through the EU's youth employment initiative. Recently, however, the Swedish government decided to pay out only a fraction of EU money for "budgetary technical reasons", as it states. The city of Avesta in Dalarna is one of the latest examples of what this leads to. There are finished projects that could start immediately if they received part of the EU money, but they are no longer allowed to do so. There is a lot to criticize the EU for and the EU's actions for in dealing with the economic crisis, but there are also national governments that do not take advantage of the opportunity. I would like to ask Commissioner Andor the question: How do you see the reduction in targeted measures that the Swedish government has now decided on with regard to youth unemployment? What can you do? What are you going to do?

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: Madam President! As one of the measures to remedy youth unemployment, it is proposed to increase the transnational mobility of workers, which is of course in the interest of those countries, such as Germany, suffering from a labor shortage. Freedom of movement and settlement is a great achievement for Europe. And, of course, I am not in favor of closing borders, as are some colleagues here. However, we must be aware of the effects that emigration has on the countries from which young people leave. This applies to many Central and Eastern European countries, for example, over 2 million mainly young people left Poland after 2004. Were it not for this emigration, unemployment would have been much higher. However, the departure of young people deepens the demographic crisis, contributes to economic and political stagnation, and takes away the dynamics of these societies. In addition, emigrants most often work much below their qualifications, often in unworthy conditions, inconsistent with the standards of a given country. The motive for emigration is also the willingness to start a family that young people cannot afford in their own country. That is why economic emigration, which is the result of the growing imbalance between the countries of the European center and other countries, cannot be any permanent solution. It is only a confirmation of the inequality between European countries. I ask that all youth employment programs also take this aspect into account.

name: Patrick LE HYARIC
text: Madam President, Commissioner, there will be no European project for the future as long as young people continue to be sacrificed on the altar of European austerity as they are today. The so-called "youth guarantee" project must therefore be more ambitious and it must be transformed so that no young person between the ages of 18 and 30, without exception, is unemployed or in precarious life. It must be allocated at least 21 billion, as requested by the International Labor Office. The money is there for it. We did find 1,000 billion for the banks. This project must include an autonomy allowance mechanism for each young person allowing them to train and gain access to their first job. A European plan to convert all precarious jobs into stable jobs should be considered; the establishment of a European trainee statute with new rights and employment opportunities; action aimed at large companies so that they commit to quantified objectives of creating sustainable jobs for young people.But, beyond that, I think that we need a major European investment plan for the future for young people. public services and ecological transition; the establishment in each country of a minimum wage since Mr Juncker committed to it yesterday; in addition, the Erasmus program must reach as many people as possible by increasing the number of grants and introducing progressivity according to family income.

name: Monika VANA
text: Madam President! I would like to measure the fight against youth unemployment not just by the fine words that are said here in this room, but by the deeds that are taken. If, within the framework of the country-specific recommendations, one were to place as much emphasis on the implementation of the youth guarantee as on the flexibilization and deregulation of the labor markets in Europe, then we would be a decisive step further in the fight against youth unemployment. If we were to exclude investment in youth employment from the excessive deficit procedure, then we would be a significant step further in the fight against youth unemployment in Europe, and that would be a support for those countries that have run into budgetary problems. In any case, we need more binding force in the implementation of the Youth Guarantee - at least effective control and monitoring strategies - and I think the Youth Guarantee is one thing, but the quality of youth employment is quite another. More and more young people are living in precarious employment. 50% of all young people only get a part-time job and no full employment when they start work. So here we need much more effective actions and, above all, measures and resources that ensure Europe's economic and social cohesion.

name: Peter LUNDGREN
text: Madam President, this is my first time speaking in this political House and that is why I want to start by making certain things clear. I have already said this to Mr Juncker at a meeting when he visited our group and met Members who are fighting for sovereignty and democracy in the EFDD. We love Europe, which is a beautiful continent, but we are against this terrible Union. We really want to work together with other countries in Europe, of course, but not in this way, and we do not want to lose our own sovereignty. Every day we see national powers being transferred to Brussels; it will not take long before we have no say any more about our own future. The United States of Europe will be a fact, with Sweden as a province. In Sweden we have 25% of young people out of work. Why is this happening? The European Council has come with its Youth Employment Initiative. That EU strategy is a real failure; it was set up to support young people not in education, employment or training in regions with a youth unemployment rate in 2012 of above 25%. There are very large disparities between the youth employment rates in different regions. For example, in Spain and Cyprus the rates of youth unemployment in December 2013 were 54.3% and 40.8% respectively. In Greece, the youth unemployment rate for November 2013 was 59%. In Sweden it stands currently at around 25%. The problem is that most of the EU funding allocated to addressing youth unemployment will be allocated to countries with a much higher youth unemployment rate than Sweden. So we are the backyard and we can pay for the other countries, which is totally unfair. As have I said already, solidarity is very easy when other people’s money is involved. Youth unemployment is today again an item on the agenda of this House. Again we have recommendations on how to tackle youth unemployment in the EU. Again we are trying to make it easier for young people to move to jobs or training and to have EU support for quality standards for traineeships and apprenticeships. Well, let me explain something: it does not matter how many times we put youth unemployment on the agenda, and it does not matter if we add another EUR 300 billion from Mr Juncker to boost growth and jobs – the EU will not succeed. Our taxpayers already contribute the role of the money to the EU and now again Mr Juncker wants to have more money for his first top priority as Commission President. More money for what? More money to create jobs, which is pure Communism and shows that Mr Juncker was running away on the Communistic highway even before being elected. We want a better and stronger Sweden, but above all we want our sovereignty back.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Madam President, the fight against youth unemployment at a pan-European level is a specific and immediate goal for all of us. It must be placed on the agenda of the governments of the European Union as a top priority. The unemployment rate among young Greeks is close to 60%, ie it has exceeded the alarm limits. In my country, Greece, unfortunately, the European funds and programs related to tackling youth unemployment are managed by the government as they see fit. Young people who manage to get into a program will get their money back in almost a year, because the government, instead of using the money of European taxpayers for the purpose for which it is available, withholds it and presents it as a primary surplus. Instead, it raises unemployment with continued layoffs as demanded by the Troika and international moneylenders. In 2014, an additional 6,500 new redundancies were announced in the public sector, while in the private sector, collective redundancies were released. We call for a reassessment of funding criteria and for more funds to be made available to the countries of the South, which have been hit hardest by the economic crisis and austerity policies. This will help reduce youth unemployment so that they do not have to look for work in other countries. The responsibility for rising youth unemployment lies solely with governments that do not use the money of European programs aimed at growth to provide solutions and opportunities for young people for their future jobs. I would like you, young MEP, to waste a little of your time on a point. I am saddened by the fact that Parliament's Chamber was vacated immediately after the vote. It seems that the main colleagues have solved the problem of youth unemployment in their countries or are simply not interested.

name: Thomas MANN
text: Madam President! Yesterday we saw Jean-Claude Juncker, elected Commission President by a large majority. He has promised a fresh start for the EU with a ten-point reform agenda. The central goal is to create more and better quality jobs and to tackle youth unemployment. We do not want to and will not leave job seekers alone and have decided on the Youth Guarantee, which is better than many have formulated so far. In October 2010 I dealt with this subject in a report for the European Parliament. Our ambitious promise: We now want to achieve an expansion for young people up to the age of 30. Since January 1st, 6 billion euros have been available as the first measure in the fight against youth unemployment. We have problems with implementation in the Member States. That has to be changed. It is about targeted help now, not in a few months. Above all, we need economic sectors with high growth and employment potential. That has to be encouraged. We have to counter the trend towards de-industrialization. Young people need support for small and medium-sized companies. They are the job engine in the EU with over two thirds of all jobs. The employment figures within the EU are drifting apart. We have seen it. In Greece and Croatia, around half of young people are unemployed. That must not let us rest, and not all of us, including in other Member States. In Germany it is 7.8%. One reason for the comparatively low values ​​is certainly the dual training comprising work and school. More and more imitators are being added across Europe. This is a good draft that we can bring forward. The accusation that many unregistered unemployed young people are neglected in Germany is completely unjustified. Every young person who wants to work has a close-knit network of advice, placement and support at a high level. In addition, the chances of starting a career increase through the first funding period. Those looking for training or work must not be left alone.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: Madam President, as you well know, youth unemployment is the great symptom of all the hopelessness that this continent has. Over the last few years, it has been talked about at length in the European Union. We are seeing how in some countries the personal option to emigrate has become a generational obligation, unfortunately. The alarm over the lack of hope and the present for a continent where young people cannot find work is the condemnation of its future. That is why we established the Youth Guarantee - to which we dedicated 6 billion euros - which is now beginning to be applied in some countries. I come from the country that has the dishonorable taste of being the country with the highest youth unemployment rate in the Western world: Spain. More than a quarter of the resources of the Youth Guarantee will go to this country: we will see what is going to be done in our country with that money. Unfortunately, we believe that the use will be absolutely fraudulent, using the resources in bonuses for public procurement - something that we know does not work. It is one more tool of the internal evaluation strategy, which causes you to end up firing your parents to hire your children with public subsidies from the European Union, the latter being able to be fired in turn after six months without returning those aids. That is what is happening in our country. And, furthermore, we know that, as deficit targets are met and spending is also accounted for in those deficit targets of the Youth Guarantee, we find countries with more unemployment that have these deficit targets, which is absolutely counterproductive. We have to find an answer to the following question: what is the scale of this problem? During the last few years, in the economic crisis, we allocated between 600 billion and 1.6 trillion - it depends on the calculation - to rescue the financial system. We said it was systemic, it was too big to fail. The question is whether the new generations on this continent are systemic, if we can let them fall. That is the 'answer' that this Parliament has to answer. (He agreed to answer a question asked under the 'blue card' procedure (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Teresa RODRIGUEZ-RUBIO
text: blue card question.- Mr López Fernández, don't you think that the increase in the retirement age that the Socialist Party and the Popular Party have carried out in Spain has had a direct relationship with youth unemployment?

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: "blue card" response.- I am very afraid that the problems we have with youth unemployment in Spain are due to many more causes.For this reason, we try to explain that the economic policy that Europe has carried out in recent years, both the restrictive monetary policy and the internal devaluation to gain competitiveness in some countries (which is a great euphemism for "wage poverty") or thebudgetary austerity, the only thing they have led to is recession and rising unemployment.As you well know, youth unemployment is usually, in all countries, twice the general, as is also the case in Spain, with 50% youth unemployment and 25% general unemployment.That is the answer we should give.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: Youth unemployment in Slovakia has been alarming in recent years not only because of the financial impact on society. Unemployed young people do not acquire work experience and habits, lose their self-confidence, job prospects and many lose the feeling that their studies have made sense. The number of unemployed people under the age of 29 registered at employment offices makes up more than a third of all registered unemployed, with the most vulnerable group being young people with disabilities or from socially disadvantaged backgrounds. Therefore, it is necessary to build an inclusive model of education so that no group of children is excluded from the quality educational process, more support for the development of students' key competencies, initiative and creativity, as well as lifelong learning so that graduates can be employers and not just employees. There is a need to make labor law more flexible and less taxable for work, and to reduce bureaucracy in setting up and running a trade or business. Initiatives in these areas would improve young people's chances of working much more than spending millions of euros on temporary subsidized jobs, which we are not tackling, but only postponing.

name: Mircea DIACONU
text: Madam President, I had to become a member of the European Parliament to realize how small a minute is. Remarkable, Commissioner, the effort, the funds, the intentions to solve this phenomenon, because it is a phenomenon. If it is a phenomenon, it means that it has some causes. If we do not treat the causes, we do not realize them, the phenomenon cannot disappear. About the causes, less. Sometimes investing funds in this genre and in this phenomenon is like pouring water into the sand. In my opinion - and not only mine - the equation of happiness, fulfillment in life is the relationship between what you think you can do and what you really know how to do. The question that always arises between an employer and a young person is: "what do you know how to do?". We answer this question very hard, young people give old people. Unfortunately, the minute is gone, I say one more thing: of my grandchildren, who left my country - I am Romanian - one of them repairs the teeth of English citizens and does not let him go home for good what is, and the other is ship captain and transports MEPs and other European citizens from place to place.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: Madam President, the Commission found that the youth employment program had been a failure and EUR 6.4 billion is allocated for two years for the Youth Guarantee. Do you really think that this budget is enough to get quality jobs and rights for young unemployed Europeans? To give an example: Spain. 55% youth unemployment. The rescue of the Spanish banks: 40 billion euros. The Youth Guarantee program: € 1.8 billion for two years, approximately € 70 for unemployed people, unemployed young people: € 70 per month! When have banks become more important to the Commission, the Council and a part of this Parliament than people? Are we going to consent, without making any statement, to the words of the President of the International Monetary Fund, who proposes to lower minimum wages —654 euros, in the case of Spain — to hire young people? Are we going to allow more poverty and inequality? Are we going to allow new discrimination, this time for being young? I finish. Do we want to end youth unemployment? It's simple: let's end austerity policies; let's boost growth above the deficit and debt repayment; let's bet on public policies, investment, research, development, innovation; added value to work; more budget. Jobs are not created by lowering social contributions, losing rights and breaking collective bargaining as has been done with labor reforms. No employment is generated by companies if there is no demand, and there is no demand if there are no quality, stable jobs with decent wages. Once and for all, ladies and gentlemen, once and for all, let's put people first.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: Madam President, Commissioner Andor, the situation of young people in Europe is absolutely dramatic. Some of the speakers who have preceded me have pointed this out. In the case of some countries, such as Spain, there is 55% unemployment. A situation that, despite proposals such as the Youth Guarantee, is aggravated by all the economic policy recommendations made throughout the European semesters. Today, young people are the field of experimentation with precariousness, and I would like to know what you plan to do in the face of siren songs to establish a specific labor relations framework for young people that is not an authentic attack against their rights. In some countries, Commissioner Andor, the application of the Youth Guarantee is a real disaster. In the case of Spain, practically all the money will go to tax credits, which - we know - do not work. I would like to know your opinion, Commissioner Andor, on how the youth guarantee is being applied in Spain and what you are going to do in the face of the misuse of these proposals by some Member States.

name: Gerolf ANNEMANS
text: Ladies and gentlemen, colleagues of the majority - a majority that we have seen at work here following the appointment of the President of this Parliament and also the President of the Commission - I am taking part in this debate on youth unemployment against to point out that the CO2 emissions of your unity thinking include youth unemployment. I am a Flemish nationalist, I come from a country, Belgium, which, like the European Union, is seen far too much as a socio-economic entity, when it is not at all. An artificial land, with different parts. A country that, like the European Union, is experiencing a transfer from north to south with all the adverse consequences that entails. I come here to contradict you in your great temple cathedral of the European unity idea, because you pretend that Europe is one socio-economic space, while that in fact violates Europe, because Europe is diversity, diversity and adaptation of the Member States. It will be one of the hallmarks of my mandate to regularly point this out to you in this cathedral of European integration. (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Rule 162 (8)).)

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: a question asked by raising a blue card.- Mr President, I just wanted to point out that colleagues who are talking about improving the quality of education and tackling the causes of unemployment are, of course, also right.But the European Union is currently looking at how to help find a place, to find practice for those who have worse conditions to find work.I appreciate the youth guarantee program, precisely because it helps employers open new jobs, which is the experience of the Czech Republic.I call on the Commissioner to find out the effectiveness of this program, which is the main thing now.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Madam Representative!Please check the order of the house.According to the rules, a blue card means that you can ask a question to one of your fellow Members.You didn't use it, you don't have time to post, so unfortunately, I can't provide that.Posting time is required to give your opinion here in the house.The following comment came from Mr Zdechovský.Card of a similar nature, or indeed a blue one, I ask the representative.Blue card?

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: a question asked by raising a blue card.- It is a question for colleagues from Spain.I wanted to ask my colleagues when they are talking here so fervently about how the European Union is not doing anything and how those funds will be misused: what will you do to prevent the funds from being misused as a Member of the European Parliament?

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: (The President asked Mr Urtason to answer Mr Zdechovský's blue-card question. As Mr Urtason did not have a headset, he asked for the question to be repeated and the President asked them to contact each other directly to discuss the matter.)

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: Madam President, Commissioner, the European Union must not waste the energy, creativity, skills of young people. They are an essential asset for growth and social and territorial cohesion. Young people are a solution, not a problem. Thus, the numbers of youth unemployed are not acceptable. They are even more worrying in the poorest regions and in low-density territories. The European Union, through the Youth Employment initiative, makes it possible to use EUR 6 billion for 2014 and 2015. Here is a question to the Commissioner: And then, and from 2016 to 2020, what is your proposal? The European Union also has programs such as Your first EURES job, programs within Erasmus +, it has cohesion policy funds, namely the European Social Fund, which should be used for job creation. But efficient and rapid use of these funds and programs is required. At the moment, we are still witnessing a paradox: we have unemployment, but we also have job vacancies to fill. Reinforcing its strategic importance in research and permanent development of knowledge, the training given, namely from the European Social Fund, cannot be dissociated from reality or from market dynamics. This will be useful for young people and businesses. In the field of job creation, I also highlight small and medium-sized companies and the attention they must have and the favorable environment that we must give them. We have funds, we have programs, we have instruments, but we have to reduce bureaucracy, because only in this way will we be able to foster young people's entrepreneurship and entrepreneurial capacity. (The speaker agreed to answer a question under the "blue card" procedure, pursuant to Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Blue card question.- I would like to ask Mr Fernandes - although I agree with him that there is little money that can be used or has been used for the European Youth Guarantee - but when we say that more money is needed, specifically for this purpose, how much would he personally spend?

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: Answer according to the "blue card" procedure.- I must have explained myself badly because I said that we have enough programs, enough resources.I spoke about the Youth Employment initiative, which has 6000 million euros.What I also said is that funds and programs are not enough.They have to be done quickly, but then everyone has to do their homework.Then each Member State, too, must cut red tape, must reduce obstacles to growth and employment.We have funds, we have programs, we also have to reduce all barriers to growth.

name: Evelyn REGNER
text: Madam President, Commissioner!I come from a country, Austria, where when the crisis broke out the funds for active labor market policy were doubled - I say doubled - to fight youth unemployment.This investment has clearly paid off.We have one of the lowest youth unemployment rates in Europe.That means investing in young people pays off.Therefore, from a social democratic point of view, a European response must apply that measures against youth unemployment should be included in the European semester, on a mandatory basis, and that young people should have a legal right to the youth guarantee.Young people are not supplicants, they are the foundation of society.They are incredibly valuable to us.Accordingly, every investment comes back double and triple.

name: Helga STEVENS
text: Young people are the future and tackling skyrocketing youth unemployment is rightly a priority. But we must clearly define who does what. The European Union can and must primarily facilitate growth and jobs by stimulating the necessary structural labor market reforms and creating a good business and investment environment. The large differences in youth unemployment rates across Member States and regions prove that unemployment is often the result of malfunctioning national and regional labor markets and deficiencies in national education systems. It is true that the European Union can act additionally through specific support measures, but this should not relieve the Member States of their own responsibility. Incidentally, the region that I represent, namely Flanders, is also prioritizing the activation policy of young people and is thus implementing the recommendation on the youth work guarantee. Finally, I would like to explicitly draw attention to a tailor-made language policy for young people with a migration background and for the specific needs of young people with a disability. This will also give these two groups of young people job opportunities. (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Rule 162 (8)).)

name: Giulia MOI
text: Question "blue card".- I am part of the 5 Star Movement.I would like to say that for young people there is a lot of talk and a lot of money has been invested but it has never been carefully checked where this money has gone.In my country, in particular in my region, in Sardinia, a lot of money was used badly in training courses, and ended up in the hands of a few who cheated and stole this money and the European Community has never investigated and ifhe investigated has always closed his eyes.I would like attention to be focused on this.

name: Helga STEVENS
text: "blue card" answer.- I do believe that it is a shared responsibility, including of your country Italy, which must work with the European Commission.But especially the Member States themselves must ensure that things are not misused.It seems simple to me.It is the responsibility of your own government and you should raise the problem there.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: I would like to take this opportunity to thank Commissioner Andor for his very encouraging work in his previous term and for a number of positive initiatives for the benefit of young people.I also hope that today’s listeners, among whom young people absolutely predominate, will understand that our interest in their problems is sincere and that we want to contribute to solving problems and paving the way for them to live with solid jobs and employment opportunities.In the previous term, we adopted a guarantee scheme, among other things.I think it is right to upgrade it with enough resources, as well as all the other instruments, because if we only have a large amount of instruments and very few resources, then we will not do very much for young people.I think it would also be good to get a report on the transparency of the use of funds on such occasions, perhaps this would contribute to greater efficiency.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: Madam President, almost a quarter of young people today in Ireland are unemployed and the figure would be much higher if we took into account those who have been forced to emigrate. Those who do manage to find work are often expected to accept precarious or part-time work which suits the profits of employers but little else. They are faced with the dire option of emigration or unemployment and many young people are being utterly exploited in the name of so-called ‘flexible working conditions’. We must provide our youth with real options for their career and properly paid apprenticeships which give an equal benefit to both parties. If we are to address youth unemployment seriously, then we need a properly considered and funded Youth Guarantee which will protect our young people against the worst effects of this crisis.

name: Ernest MARAGALL
text: (The speaker begins his speech in Catalan.) Madam President, I am still in Spanish, the language of my mother, my grandparents, and also mine. We have a debt as huge as it is illegitimate: the debt that we have contracted with our young people. In the last ten years, we have destroyed your present and your future; We have stolen the most important thing from them: the possibility of becoming full citizens. It is therefore regrettable that the meeting scheduled in Turin on July 11 was canceled. The Council and the Commission continue to accumulate debt to our young people. If we want to look at this issue - youth employment - we must use three concepts: rights, education and investment. First: it is a question of rights, not only of aid, subsidies or tax incentives. Aspects such as the Youth Guarantee, the living minimum wage and the "unemployment" insurance must occupy a concrete, tangible place in European policies and in that of each Member State. Sufficient resources are necessary for each of them and a European control of their effective application. Second: we must start from education and its adequate relationship with work in the immediate environment of each young person, but also with the promotion of mobility and the real existence of a European economic and labor space. And third: investment must be started, the only reasonable way to create jobs; the enormous resources now prisoners of budgetary consolidation and debt repayment must be released. How much of the 300 billion that Mr Juncker announced to us can we associate with this goal?

name: Robert Jarosław IWASZKIEWICZ
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Frankly speaking, youth unemployment should not be discussed in this House, neither by Parliament nor by the Commission. The more standards, regulations, directives, regulations and resolutions we produce, the worse it is for all entrepreneurs, and therefore - for young people who take their first steps on the labor market. In my deepest conviction, employment facilitation belongs not only to young people, but to everyone. All social and professional groups should have equal easy access to the labor market. So what to do to really make it easier for young people to get their first job, and to help other employees get their next job? Each country should answer this question for itself, depending on its economic condition, political conditions and cultural tradition. In the case of Poland, the tax and administrative pressure that suffocates every Polish company should certainly be reduced.

name: Danuta JAZŁOWIECKA
text: Madam President! Even though the European economy is slowly but steadily recovering from the crisis, the situation on the labor market remains worrying. The frustration and hopelessness of young people who cannot find a job is frightening. As members of the European Parliament, we have a moral obligation to prioritize the problem of youth unemployment and to support instruments that will actually improve the situation of European youth. For many years we have been complaining about the poor quality of education in the European Union. Despite more than 23% of youth unemployment, nearly 4 million jobs remain unfilled due to a lack of knowledgeable and skilled workers. Appropriate reform of education systems as part of the common European strategy for improving education, which we keep talking about and unfortunately doing nothing about, should be the first and fundamental step towards improving the situation on the labor market. The Union should focus on the development of a dual education system and the creation of structures for early personalized career counseling. This will allow for a more conscious choice of the educational path and subsequent professional career. The youngest children should be provided with access to education and the acquisition of the widest possible initial stock of knowledge, so that the future will be able to re-qualify much faster and easier when the labor market changes. Investing in youth pays off. Promoting mobility can also significantly increase the employability of young people. Unfortunately, as a result of the economic and financial crisis, too often there is mobility due to the lack of prospects and the very difficult socio-economic situation of some countries - this should not be the case! However, it reaffirms the need for appropriate social and employment reforms.

name: Corina CREȚU
text: Commissioner, today we are talking about one of the worst problems in Europe. We all know that finding a job is becoming an increasing challenge for young people in many countries who do not have the opportunity to put their knowledge into practice and gain professional experience and it is clear that their present and future is in great danger.
