I appreciate your efforts, Commissioner, but I believe that we need to pursue more concrete results and make reducing youth unemployment, fighting poverty, a zero priority for both the European institutions and national governments. I call on all Member States to promote measures to increase employment among young people as a matter of priority, so that, after completing their studies, they have the opportunity to do internships and benefit from good quality job offers. If we fail to close the gaps and inequalities between Member States, we will never be able to talk about sustainable growth in the European Union. I also call on the Commission and the Council to reduce youth unemployment as a specific goal in the European Semester, and to propose a set of binding measures to be included in the country recommendations and national reform programs.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Commissioner, the massive unemployment of young people in the European South due to the implementation of the memoranda and the policy of austerity is leading to social exclusion and marginalization. In Greece, youth unemployment reached 58%, although in the last four years 214 billion euros have been given as loans to our country. However, these sums were not invested in the real economy in order to create thousands of new jobs, but were given to repay old shameful loans and to save the German, French, Greek and other banks. To tackle youth unemployment, the European Union must invest in the knowledge economy, ie in education, new technologies and innovation. But the memoranda and policies of violent fiscal adjustment in the South are reducing rather than increasing public investment in education and new technologies. So as long as the European Union insists on wage Chineseization in order to supposedly boost the competitiveness of the economy, youth unemployment will explode.

name: Anneli JÄÄTTEENMÄKI
text: Mr President, in her virgin address, the newly elected President of the Commission, Jean-Claude Juncker, promised a new beginning for Europe.A workable new start would be for the new Commission to take the fight against youth unemployment seriously.Economic discipline should be used to curb unemployment.What does it mean?Of course, growth and new jobs, but it also means special measures for young people, education must be better adapted to the needs of working life, apprenticeship training should be made more effective.This, of course, means that employers will also be more involved in the design of support measures for young people.Support measures should be easy for both employers and young people so that they can be applied for and taken up by employers.A new beginning - to control unemployment.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: Mr President, Mr Andor, in your speech you complained about the situation faced by young people in southern Europe and you also said that youth unemployment represents a threat to democracy. I welcome your concern, Commissioner, but the truth is that the austerity policies, sponsored by both the European Commission and the International Monetary Fund, have resulted, especially for young people in southern Europe, unemployed, precarious and in emigration. One of the harshest images for those of us who come from the south is seeing young graduates serving drinks to tourists from the north. But, of course, Mr Draghi told the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs that young people in the south are not sufficiently prepared. Surely Mr. Draghi could help them, for example, to falsify the accounts of the Central Banks, which is what he did as a representative of Goldman Sachs together with Lucas Papademos. Ladies and gentlemen, the problem of youth unemployment is not solved with ease of dismissal, reducing the minimum wage, cutting rights, nor with racism. It is solved by disciplining the financial system.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: Mr President, earlier at the start of the meeting, Mr Schulz made inappropriate comments about Ms Le Pen. Today she represents one of the main European delegations and I ask that the rules be respected and that MEPs respect each other, that is to say that today I ask Mr Schulz to make a public apology to with regard to Ms. Le Pen. With regard to my speech at the European Council of 26 and 27 June on the issue of youth employment in Europe, everyone knows that the arrival of young people on the labor market is each year more thwarted: thwarted by unlimited globalization which places both young graduates and young people without qualifications in a situation of unfair competition in the face of the loss of market share of European companies, and in particular of small and medium-sized companies, which are by nature job creators, and thwarted by uncontrolled immigration, the most visible reflection of globalism which plays down wage levels. In this regard, the Council's conclusions are revealing. If the latter claims to focus on youth employment without mentioning real resources and real policies, the Council document is much more explicit, I quote: "Attract much more talent". However, our graduates see the job market closing in on them and we are even more lax with regard to the right to asylum, whereas today it is totally misguided. When will the Council and the Commission finally understand that globalization and mass immigration are harmful to employment in general and that of young people in particular?

name: Heinz K. BECKER
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! Commissioner, you have rightly put unemployment, and especially youth unemployment, in the context of the lost generation and the threat to democracy. The world's leading European social model is being put to the test. You're right. But I would also like to take up what is on the table today. We have a resolution from the European People's Party, prepared by David Casa, to be voted on tomorrow, we have heard a ten-point program from President Juncker, and we have the opinion from Commissioner Andor. We have to make it clear: at this point in time, Italy and France are the only crisis states that have access to the funds from the Youth Employment Initiative. If we accept that only one billion out of six billion is used, then it is not primarily a budget problem! It is about the principle of bench learning, that is, learning from the role models that exist in Europe. It is therefore clear that dual training, the European labor market network and EURES are tried and tested support that is binding. There are 2 million job vacancies in Europe, strengthening small and medium-sized enterprises is just as important as promoting entrepreneurship, which must be taught to young people at school.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: Mr President, last May, in this same chamber, 5,000 young people were debating ideas for a better Europe, and one of the clearest messages they transmitted to us is that we fight for their future, that we fight so that they can have a job in the next years; because they are the ones who are suffering the most from the consequences of the crises. Obviously, they have been those who have been most expelled from the labor market or those who have not even managed to enter; those with the least social coverage and, therefore, those who are suffering the most from all these consequences: more poverty and more inequality. That is the future they are seeing. In the past mandate, with Commissioner Andor, we managed to carry out one of our priorities: launching the Youth Guarantee for employment. But that Youth Guarantee was born diminished, it was born cut back, because the proposal of this Parliament and of this group was that the Youth Guarantee be for those under 30 and not 25 and that it be financed not with 6,000 million, but with 21,000. It's a lot of money, but what youth unemployment is costing us is 150 billion euros: what is 21 billion for the community coffers!

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Mister President! Commissioner, you talked about the measures against youth unemployment, but you did not talk about the causes of youth unemployment. If we look at youth unemployment in Europe, we find that it is not a pan-European phenomenon. Youth unemployment in Germany is 8%, while in Greece it is 60%, in Spain also 60%, in Italy and France between 30% and 40%. You just have to realize that the differences are so huge that you can't explain them by saying: “Well, the Spaniards and the French and the Italians, they don't train their youngsters properly, they don't have the best German dual system ”, or something similar, but you have to state that it is about the competitiveness of these states. The competitiveness of these countries is massively impaired by the common European currency. The Commission is turning a blind eye to the fact that it is the common European currency that is blocking young people's prospects for the future, which is degrading young people because they cannot find work, which is causing young people in Europe to turn away from Europe in disaffection because they see their professional future distorted. This problem must finally be seen and properly assessed by the Commission. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the blue card procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Richard SULÍK
text: Ask about the “blue card” procedure.- Yes, Mr Lucke, it is the lack of competitiveness that is causing these high unemployment rates in the south.Now many colleagues here are also trying to solve this lack of competitiveness through more and more investments - but, frankly, there are more and more debts.My question to you: what do you think, where should this end?Today the European Union is approaching approximately 100 percent indebtedness.What is enoughWhat is the best?We heard there is good debt too.Is 150% Enough?What is your opinion?

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Answer to a question about the “blue card” procedure.- Mr Sulík, you are quite right to mention the problem that the European Parliament and the European Commission seem to think that this problem can be countered through state intervention, through investment programs, through debt-financed investment programs.But in fact the state has of course only very little influence on the competitiveness of private companies.In other words, the problem is, in fact, beyond the scope of a government.The only way a government can try to ease the situation of youth job creation companies is to allow more flexibility in exchange rates.

name: Fredrick FEDERLEY
text: Mr President! I find it striking in this debate how weakly one actually reasons from both the political left and the political right. The political right believes that we will become stronger by closing our borders and making it impossible for the millions of jobs not filled in the European Union to actually be filled. The political left, for its part, believes that the only way to create more jobs is through more money and public projects. The truth probably lies in a long list of other things that we must look at in the future. How we can create common markets so that small and medium-sized enterprises can function. How can we get a trade agreement with the United States that strengthens our economy? Hardly any of my honorable colleagues have single-handedly highlighted the fact that we have just gone through the deepest economic crisis in almost 100 years in Europe. If we are not able to create rules that create greater finances for companies, we will also not be able to afford unemployment.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Mister President!(The speaker speaks without a microphone) ... Unemployed people in the Union and a so-called youth guarantee, which will not provide sufficient remedy, because where there are no jobs, there are no guarantees.Six billion euros is certainly just a drop in the ocean, and the goals for 2020, which envisage an academic rate of 40%, are completely counterproductive.I ask myself: why do we need so many academics?The consequences: more unemployment, sociologists as taxi drivers, lawyers as waiters and an inflation of diplomas.Rather, we need an upgrading of the craft, combined with skills in the new technologies, qualified skilled workers for our industry and a dual training system, as Austria and Germany are known to provide.What we do not need, of course, is further immigration, which will lead to wage dumping and also increase social tension in Europe.(Applause)

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Dear colleagues! If we look at the beginning of the joint motion for a resolution that has been tabled, it is also clear that we have already addressed this issue many times in the European Parliament. The speakers before me have said many numbers, tragic numbers, but I think it is also important to look at whether it has produced results in countries that have dealt with this issue before. Let's look at my own country, Hungary. A year ago, in March 2013, youth unemployment was 27.7%, and now we are at 20%. If we look at the other countries, 13 countries have different rates of youth unemployment. I believe that work must continue, efforts must be made by both the Commission and the Member States. And not just with these special projects, but with more comprehensive approaches. I am convinced that we will improve these measures by increasing competitiveness, including quality training, quality training for young people. In conclusion, I would like to point out that we must not make the same mistake again. In the next ten years, if we do not address this issue in depth, we will be re-creating the problem. And next time, 30 million unskilled young people in the world will appear in the job market. So we have to prevent this!

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: I thank Commissioner Andor for his information on the current situation in the Member States with regard to youth employment. You actually work a lot in this area. Despite the many languages ​​and the initiatives won by the European Parliament, there are still too few positive developments in the field of youth employment. Are the Member States' efforts to implement the Youth Guarantee really sufficient? As the Commissioner mentioned, as many as seven countries have not yet drawn up plans to implement the Youth Guarantee. Youth unemployment can no longer be described as a problem of lack of education or unskilled skills alone. Training, appropriate and early career guidance, and high-quality education for the labor market are, of course, part of the solution, but job creation, the other side of the problem, must be high on the European Union's agenda. Another important problem is discrimination against young people in the workplace. Even after getting a job, young people are discriminated against and exploited, which makes statistics on poverty and social exclusion among young people unjustifiably high in our Europe. Young people also need job security, social protection and social guarantees, because the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union enshrines the right to social security for everyone: not just workers who have already gained experience, but also beginners. And yet, aren’t we too focused in our discussions solely on the economic aspects of youth unemployment? Why are we not talking about the impact of youth unemployment on the demography of our continent? How do you think a safe job, or a young person with no job at all, is a connection to start a family and raise children? This is so important for our aging Europe.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: Slovakia also has one of the highest indicators of youth unemployment, which is up to a third of the unemployed in our country. This situation can be changed directly or indirectly. The EU should continue to support the Erasmus and Erasmus Plus training exchange programs, which will lead to a more focused and efficient workforce, which in turn will attract employers. The free movement of labor and services can only work if people speak foreign languages ​​at a communication level, so they need to be encouraged to do so. The European Union should also pay more attention to the disruption of rigid family structures and corruption, which will enable young and competent people to reach relevant positions that are now inaccessible to them. However, the current paradigm in the approach to motivating young people also needs to be changed, not only to teach them "study a lot, get a job in a company and you will have a lifetime", but they need to be encouraged to move creatively in a small business. The governments of the Member States must create opportunities for the creation of small businesses. However, once a father taught his son, set an example for him - today we in the EU have the disintegration of a healthy model of a functional family of man, woman and children, and especially the authority of the father, which suffers a young individual and is destabilized and therefore cannot be relevantly employed. It used to be a master and a teacher at school, so I think that schools must lead from theoretical knowledge to professional practice so that young people can also go to work as a craft, because craftsmen are missing here.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this is my first intervention in this House. At a time when we are witnessing a slight economic growth in the European Union, we see that the stark numbers of youth unemployment and the huge geographical asymmetries that respect them are maintained. Between 7.8% in Germany and 56.8% in Greece, passing by 38.1% in Portugal. I believe that the time has come to do more for growth in Europe and invest in investment and competitiveness, using structural funds, as well as funds from the European Investment Bank, in order to leverage private investment and the creation of youth employment. Mr. Andor said that youth employment will be at the top of the political agenda for the new President of the European Commission. It is one of the measures, and one of the measures is precisely the extension of the youth guarantee from 25 to 30 years of age, in order to cover the approximately 6.8 million young people called NEET - those who are not in employment, education or training. Going a step further, I also advocate the use of contributions from the European Social Fund, the ERDF and the EAFRD, which are essential for the sustainable inclusion of young people in the labor market. I believe, Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, that, without a stronger commitment to combating youth unemployment, Europe will eventually condemn an ​​entire generation to social exclusion and the loss of European citizenship itself. Is the Commission, Mr Andor, truly committed to meeting this challenge?

name: Jeroen LENAERS
text: The youth has the future. That is a proverb that we know in many of our European countries, but unfortunately it is no longer a matter of course in Europe today. Let us ensure that we do give our youth that future. Let us avoid talking about a lost generation of young people who are willing and able to work, but are not given the opportunity to do so. The Youth Initiative and the Youth Guarantee are important tools, but they are not panacea. They cannot be panacea, because the fight against youth unemployment must be fought primarily in the Member States themselves. Therefore, let us not be tempted to hand out large project subsidies from Europe, but let us focus on sustainable reforms in the Member States. Economic and labor market reforms. Reforms in education, so that it better meets the needs of the labor market. Reforms to give entrepreneurs the peace and confidence to do business, especially young entrepreneurs and start-ups. Only in this way can we sustainably improve employment. May I perhaps put one more question to Mr Andor on the following problem: one of the most important or one of the most vulnerable groups within the young unemployed is the young homeless unemployed. The current European instruments seem to find little connection with the challenges facing this group. What can we do together to give this group a future in Europe too?

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: Mr President, Commissioner, we are talking about youth employment, and this debate covers much more than the Youth Guarantee. First, because many of us already know that it was insufficient money, that there was insufficient amount - at least the 15 billion euros that the ILO told us are missing for it to be minimally efficient. Some of us also said that it was going to be an open door to precariousness when we renounced the fact that it was a European system, that is, with general rules to be fulfilled by all States. This debate is much more: this debate has to do with the labor reforms that the Commission, within the framework of the European Semester, has promoted to generalize the loss of rights and the reduction of wages; This debate has to do with the lack of guarantees in labor mobility so that many young people who are leaving their countries also receive guarantees and equal opportunities. This debate also has to do with the pockets of fraud that exist in all States with work grants, which we are unable to stop. Therefore, Commissioner, when we talk about youth employment, we have to be aware that employment is more than a right recognized in our rules: it is the umbilical cord by which a citizen feels or does not feel part of a society. If we want to end Euroscepticism, if we want to curb this wave of populism across Europe, we have to offer something more than unemployment or precariousness for young Europeans as a whole. It is your obligation and it is also our co-responsibility. (He agreed to answer a question asked under the 'blue card' procedure (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Janusz KORWIN-MIKKE
text: blue-card question. – Mr Gutiérrez Prieto is from Spain and he should remember that Spain was the leading power in the world but it got its gold from South America and dropped to third or fourth place. Money does not help. Money harms. Because if you get money you buy something from abroad and you are losing jobs and not getting them.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: "blue card" response.- Thank you for this reminder of history, but those who are losing money today are the millions of European citizens who see their salaries being devalued to gain competitiveness, to the point that, for example, the European Commission has recognized that having a salary, having a job, is insufficient in some Member States to lead a decent life.I cannot find anything that better defines the betrayal of the European social model with the austerity policies that we have carried out in recent years.I don't know, I don't want to remember what happened five centuries ago: what I do care about is what has to happen in the next fifty years to get Europe out of the social crisis in which it lives with these policies of economic suffocation.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen! It has to be noticed that the world economy has been growing much faster than Europe's economy for years. And it has to be noticed that the eurozone is growing less rapidly than Europe. It has also been made clear today that growth is much weaker in southern Europe than in northern Europe - with the following consequences: First, we are complaining about deindustrialization in southern Europe, not in the north of the euro zone. We are complaining about growing unemployment in southern Europe, not northern Europe. We complain about youth unemployment in southern Europe, not northern Europe. The reason is very simple: the euro has become far too heavy and expensive for the south. Almost all economists in the south and more and more politicians in the south are complaining about this. That is why we must finally talk about the terrible effects of a single currency in this Parliament. A one size fits all currency is a currency that can only be described as a one size fits none currency.

name: Jean-Marie CAVADA
text: Mr President, yesterday I heard the candidate, Mr Juncker, say that the economy should be at the service of people and not the other way around. It is only time to make this observation and it is lamentable that it took four years to arrive at this observation, provided that it is applied. Between 25 and 50% youth unemployment, that means that all these people, these young people and their families will turn, and sometimes violently, their backs on Europe. It is a major failure and it has been going on for four years. But the cause is not so much Europe, Ladies and Gentlemen, as the States which have indulged in "classicism" and have not carried out the reforms which needed to be made, or others which are are so heavily in debt that they have ruined a generation. So the drama is so important that now Europe must fly to their aid in three directions: stimulate the economy and circulate credit, accelerate qualified training and facilitate trade with migratory countries in Europe that need labor force and, finally, accelerate the implementation of the youth guarantee and extend its effects up to the age of 30.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: Mr President, I greet the Commission for the initiatives presented today, in particular welcoming the support announced for the regions with the highest unemployment rates. In the last parliamentary term, several extremely important programs were launched to combat youth unemployment. However, these responses have not been as successful as we intended. In my region, an outermost region, the Azores, youth unemployment reaches absurd values ​​of around 40%. There is therefore still a lot to be done in creating decent and stable jobs. The fight against youth unemployment has to be much more than an apology invoked in party struggles. It requires reasoning, commitments and partnerships from different authors. I argue that we must create guarantees for those over 25, as is done in my country, Portugal, and not just in France, thus also supporting the most qualified young people, who are endowed with greater tools and professional skills, thus promoting mobility in education and at professional level. I also defend the need to articulate with small and medium-sized companies, in order to create tax incentives in hiring young people and to develop initiatives that promote entrepreneurship and European start-ups. But combating youth unemployment requires combating social and cultural inequalities in the European space, which implies that we must also provide excellent teaching, reinforcing professional education and dual learning, in addition to monitoring the programs created, both in terms of interveners or their effect.

name: Agnes JONGERIUS
text: Now that our continent is hit by a major social crisis after the financial crisis, the citizens of Europe only want one thing and that is work! So a targeted approach to youth unemployment is a top priority; this requires a better connection between education and the labor market and thus more investment in education, preferably in the expected growth sectors, but also in apprenticeships, internships and start-up jobs and, as far as I am concerned, in plans where older workers take younger ones under their wing and teach them the tricks of the trade. We must also look at our industrial policy to create employment for young people who want to work with their hands, in order to prevent the lower educated from being displaced by the higher educated in the labor market. Our young people deserve a future perspective and therefore a larger budget than the current six billion euros, a higher age limit than 25; this should be raised to 30. Europe loses popular support when half of its youth are out of work. My question to the Commissioner is therefore: what can you do and what can we do to increase support for more political ambition in the fight against youth unemployment?

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: Mr President, I believe that the Youth Guarantee Scheme will be very important in tackling youth unemployment. Reforming our education and training systems is a very important element of that programme – that has been mentioned by the Commissioner here this morning – and I think it is something we really need to concentrate on.  In a recent survey of eight European countries, one third of employers said that the lack of skills among young people is causing major businesses problems in the form of cost, quality and time. Almost 30% of employers reported that a lack of skills was a major reason they did not fill their vacancies. And employers from countries with the highest youth unemployment reported the greatest problems due to skill shortages. Youth unemployment is not a new problem for Europe and we should note it. In 1995 it stood at 21% and since then it has not gone below 15%, so it is an institutional issue. A critical reason that youth do not get the skills that employers need is that education providers, young people and employers do not understand one another. They operate in parallel universes and they rarely interact. So we need to change the structure of how we teach young people skills. We need to focus on giving them the skills that the market needs, and that they are able to respond to what employers really need so that we can be sure that our young people have sustainable jobs. I would ask the Commissioner to ensure that this is a focus not just in my country but across Europe as well. It is an institutional problem and it is something that really needs to be tackled.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, given the short time, I express only two concepts. First of all, I note with great satisfaction that the youth guarantee - the "Youth Guarantee" - is a reality, a satisfaction, because it is a measure adopted also starting from an initiative of my party, the European Socialist Party, and of YES, the young European socialists. For this result, we must also thank the commitment of Commissioner Andor, who engaged in a difficult context for this measure. For this reason I ask the Commission to strengthen the monitoring tools for the implementation of the Youth Guarantee in the Member States. We cannot accept that what has been painstakingly achieved in Europe will then get bogged down at the level of implementation. It is a luxury that the young people of Europe cannot afford. As other colleagues have also said, I also believe that it is essential to broaden the available base of resources and gradually extend - as Juncker also said yesterday - the extension of the guarantee up to thirty years. The second point I want to make is that young people in Europe are certainly the most mobile generation and it is therefore important to complete the mobility of the workforce, especially for young people because it is a basic condition for the functioning of the single market. In light of this, I ask the new Commission, and therefore I hope it will be possible to discuss again in the future with the new Commission, to promote new measures to support the mobility of young European workers, for example in relation to pension rights. My experience as a young European is that of building a more just and more united Europe by giving young Europeans the opportunity to work throughout Europe by putting them in contact and giving them the opportunity to find a job and have hope for a better future. The Commission has a huge responsibility as does Parliament.

name: Georges BACH
text: Mister President! Yesterday morning, the newly elected President of the Commission, Jean-Claude Juncker, rightly said: “The crisis will not be over until the problem of high unemployment in Europe - especially youth unemployment - is resolved. Since 2008, youth unemployment in the Union has risen steadily up to 50% in some countries. The initiative's funds have been available since September 1, 2013. So my question to you, Commissioner Andor, is: how can it be that the European Commission has only accepted the programs of two countries so far? And how can it be that it took five years for something to happen at European level? Youth unemployment has been rising since 2008, and the initiative was only adopted in 2013. How can we work more effectively here? Wouldn't it also make more sense to increase the age to 30? At the beginning you mentioned the seminar in Brussels. Could you perhaps reiterate what has been said by the experts and what evidence has been withheld that could help accelerate programs, projects and initiatives in the Member States? Because in my opinion this is one of the biggest problems. Then I would like to point out this best practice in how Europe works. Austria has already been mentioned. In Luxembourg, too, the project officially started in June this year, and although unemployment is not that high in Luxembourg, it is still important to get work, school and orientation at the roots and find a solution here. This is not a reproach against the Commission, but against the Member States, because I believe that this is where the problem lies. That is why I also welcome the resolution by our colleague Casa that we should also deal with this important problem in the new legislative period. Many Thanks!

name: Christine REVAULT D'ALLONNES BONNEFOY
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, as has already been said, youth unemployment is at an unacceptable record level. It particularly affects those who are little, or who are not, qualified in southern Europe. Faced with this unbearable situation, I welcome Matteo Renzi's desire to put growth and employment, and in particular youth employment, at the heart of the European agenda. Many devices would make it possible to reduce youth unemployment more quickly, like those implemented in France since the coming to power of François Hollande. We make young people, who are the future of Europe, our priority. For this to really be a European priority, the budget must follow and the general austerity policy must end. Concretely, we continue to ask to increase the youth guarantee to 21 billion euros and to extend the measure to beneficiaries up to 30 years. The Commission and Mr Juncker must take stock of this issue. Strengthening vocational training at European level is also crucial. The Erasmus + program must be extended to apprentices and the Leonardo program must be strengthened. The recognition, at European level, of the professional experience given by internships must go faster. We must even go further - mobility being an important factor for the employment of young people - by defining a common framework for internships and vocational training. Europe cannot leave its youth in the current situation. We need a new direction from Europe to act more effectively in favor of youth employment.

name: Siegfried MUREŞAN
text: Mr President, youth unemployment is far too high in Europe. Any measure that can reduce unemployment, which gives young people the chance to do an internship, a practice, is welcome. In this sense, the guarantee for young people is useful, but I think we need more than that. An unemployed young person in Europe does not want a new unpaid internship, but wants a stable, well-paid job that will give him a perspective, to be able to start a family, to be able to buy a house. The reality is that jobs are created primarily by the private sector: entrepreneurs, SMEs, small family businesses. We believe that it is our duty as politicians to provide the private sector with an economic framework in which it can trust, be able to invest, a strong, competitive economy. This will generate stable and well-paid jobs in the long run. Europe needs reforms. Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I invite you to work together in the coming months to implement an ambitious economic reform agenda that will increase competitiveness. This is the only way we can gain the trust of investors, this is how jobs will be generated and this is the best measure to prevent unemployment. Secondly, I want to say the following: there are very large discrepancies in the level of youth unemployment among European countries - over 50% in Greece, Spain, below 10% in Germany. I propose, Commissioner, that we implement a mechanism at European level for the exchange of good practice between the Member States of the European Union on measures to prevent and combat youth unemployment. Let's see what measures have worked in states where unemployment is low and how they can be applied, transferred to states where unemployment is high.

name: Miltiadis KYRKOS
text: Mr President, young people are not just one of the weak links in the labor chain, next to women, people with disabilities, those from minorities. That's it too. And that is why we need to implement more and more measures to ensure that young people are not exploited and impoverished by either employers or modern slave traders. But the blood donors of innovation will also emerge from the youth, the new ideas that will push the boundaries of entrepreneurship will emerge, the ones that will support the new forms of sustainable development. That is why we have a duty to offer them continuous and specialized training, to offer them sound business incentives and a safety net for their inevitable failures. We therefore insist on the full implementation of the "Guarantee for Youth" program and demand the increase of the budget from 6 to 21 billion euros, but at the same time measures that ensure the efficient absorption of money. We firmly demand the decoupling of the concept of "reform" from the word "deregulation" in the youth labor market.

name: Maria SPYRAKI
text: Mr President, Commissioner, President Juncker said aptly yesterday that we have 29 Member States in the European Union and the 29th is home to the unemployed. So I am speaking to you on behalf of this Member State, because there live 1,303,000 Greeks, of whom 734,000 are under 25 years old. And the question, Commissioner, is what are we going to do with them? What will we do with these young people, of whom 178,000 are super-qualified? Is the "Guarantee for Youth" enough? Even if we extend it to 30 years as we propose today with the resolution? Is the 340 million euros that come to my country through this program enough? The answers in both cases are no. Are apprenticeships that do not seem to be focused on the countries of the South most affected by the crisis enough? The answer is no. In any case, we must not give the impression that we have the magic wand, that politicians can create jobs. Jobs are created by those who take the risk, those who take the business, and those we need to strengthen. We have no right to talk about the excluded generation anymore, nor even to talk about an excluded life. In the European Union, we must decide on targeted policies, in countries like Greece that have suffered the crisis, for small and medium-sized enterprises without distorting competition. To increase all available tools for liquidity, to enable a small and medium enterprise to create a job. These should be the goals. And the goals that will be set must be measurable. That, I think, is the highest duty of all here.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Youth unemployment is caused by several factors in our society. On the one hand, it is a reduction in jobs as a result of the effects of the crisis, both financial, economic and, unfortunately, also social. It is an extension of retirement - today the retirement age is so high that, of course, it blocks many jobs. It is a structure of education in the individual Member States and, of course, it is also a consequence of the overall situation and how production is translated outside the Member States of the European Union, because companies and firms want to generate ever higher and higher profits at the expense of jobs they should provide. us, in the Member States of the European Union. The Youth Guarantee is one of the good tools, but it is a short-term tool, and I think that in order to create more jobs not only for the young generation but in general, it is important to change the overall social fabric in the Member States of the European Union and start to address how to harmonize social policy within the European Union.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Mr. President, unemployment and the departure of young people is an alarm to which we must respond with stronger and more concrete measures. It is important to secure funds, but it is also important how the funds are spent and whether they really give results. In defining measures, we need to listen to young people, involve them in decision-making. What do young people tell us? Young people want incentives for entrepreneurs, for job creation, they want incentives for self-employment and youth entrepreneurship, for start-ups. What do young people not want? They do not want social measures, and they are offered the most. We must not, by our passivity, bring young people to the wall to rejoice in social measures because there is nothing else. Thus, for example, in Croatia, the Government has adopted vocational training measures. Young people work for a year for 210 euros and a small number remain employed. Employers are not motivated to hire a young person after this measure because they are not entitled to the benefits they would otherwise receive for their first employment. Young people are not in favor of this measure, but they are in a hopeless situation. They were against its abolition because the Government did not intend to introduce alternative quality measures. They made young people think, "At least something is better than nothing." Young people did not deserve it. We need to change and together with young people design and implement programs and measures for their employment and better education.

name: Eva KAILI
text: Mr President, in Greece, with the implementation of the Pact and the austerity programs, but also in Spain, youth unemployment reaches 60%. This means that the policies of the European Union did not solve the problem and that is why Euroscepticism is reviving and rising, but also the extremes. Among other things, young people who are out of education and employment cost tens of billions. I also emphasize that some funds have not been absorbed. This means that the planning needs to be adjusted to make it easier to absorb these funds. Let me add one more dimension: businesses need to be facilitated to make new investments by lending but also by tax incentives and stability for those who naturally invest and recruit, as well as by reducing interest rate differences between Member States. , as there are very big differences for businesses. Finally, the European Union must emphasize both new technologies, as there is a huge market in this area, which we can claim, as well as innovation to cover the competitiveness gap with the United States, India and China, because it is not enough to have jobs, but we must have jobs that will give young people in Europe the opportunity to become protagonists, but also jobs that can help women, who are hit hard by unemployment. .

name: Andreas SCHWAB
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen! As part of this youth employment guarantee, the Member States have undertaken to ensure that all young people up to the age of 25 should find employment within four months. Commissioner, that was perhaps an extremely ambitious plan from the start, because in the end it is not the Member States that can create the jobs, only companies and employers. That is why I am delighted that the resolution that we are going to adopt expressly states under letter G that the main issue is how we can equip young people with the necessary skills in good time, professions that are already open today for which we have too few applicants to fill in the end. It is not only the case that in Germany the large and especially the small companies are urgently looking for young workers who have the necessary qualifications, but that in the meantime France, Spain and Italy are also desperately looking for young people with technical skills. That is why, Commissioner, I would urge you to put a stronger emphasis on this. There is work in the European Union, but we don't have the applicants at the moment. If we succeed better in combining education, training and the necessary skills, we will be able to solve many problems! (Applause)

name: Maria ARENA
text: Mr. Speaker, when we talk about young people, we need to know which young people we are talking about. Knowing these young people effectively will perhaps give us more information on the most appropriate policies to pursue. For example, we can talk about qualified young people or young people who have dropped out. If, indeed, the 2008 crisis plunged the two groups, whether qualified young people or those who had dropped out of the unemployment crisis, when we speak of qualified young people, the youth guarantee is an effective tool to put them back to work. employment. Unfortunately, this tool cannot be the only one to put them back to work and we are pleading for there to be real recovery plans. Because it is through stimulus plans that we will create jobs. The youth guarantee makes it possible to better match the qualifications of these young people with these jobs. Unfortunately, when we talk about low-skilled young people, even if the economic indicators return to positive values, they will not drag the "low-skilled". The European social elevator is now broken. Studies show that our systems need to be more voluntary and less unequal. In this case, we need investments to fight poverty, family poverty, child poverty, adolescent poverty. Therefore, we advocate for social investment criteria to be integrated into the European Semester. We also advocate for the creation of statistical indicators on child poverty, which inevitably leads to poverty among young adults.

name: Renate WEBER
text: Mr President, how can the European Union provide young people with jobs has been the question of recent years? Beyond statistical data, we are talking about individual destinies, of more and more young people who have come to believe that going to school is useless. I believe that this will be the great challenge for the Union in the coming years: to show that those who go to school will quickly find a job, either in their country of origin or in another Member State. The youth guarantee, although welcome, is only a partial response to youth unemployment. We need to change the way we think about education at European level and labor mobility. I sincerely believe that we can make these two aspects the engines of European development. School and university education should take into account the requirements of the economy across the European Union, and young people, instead of being allowed to move to other continents, should be supported by financial assistance programs when finding employment in another EU country. than the original one. Partnerships between schools, universities and the private sector must become a reality everywhere, in order to give young people access to that type of education and to those skills that are required in the labor market. Such transnational partnerships should also be encouraged. Of course, that means more Europe, more integration, and we should not be afraid if we want young European citizens to feel that the European Union as a whole means at home.

name: Silvia COSTA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner Andor, yesterday President Juncker announced his desire to expand the target of young people and the Youth Guarantee up to the age of thirty, which, I would like to remind you, is already foreseen in Italy with additional funds, and I am also happy that one of the two plans already approved by the European Commission is that of our country. I would like to reassure you that the Turin Youth Employment Summit has only been postponed to have the full new Commission in office. However, the unemployment rate is rising among young people and so we need to tackle two main challenges. The first is that the Youth Guarantee with its 6 billion in the next few years will increase to at least 21, as we have already asked, and that it is not only a response aimed at a specific target of young people, namely the supply chain for training orientation, apprenticeships and work, but also an opportunity for Member States to reorganize the network of services, opportunities and incentives and the reform of apprenticeships also in higher education, that is, it must become a new active labor policy. Second, this is not enough if two major issues are not raised: the dual system of education and vocational and technical training and investments in strategic sectors at both European and national level, also knowing that this must be coordinated with the cohesion policies with Horizon and with education and training.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: Mr President, I will not talk about numbers. They are well known, after all. But behind the numbers there is a huge human pain of misery and despair. And Cyprus is a small member state of the European Union with a huge human suffering due to unemployment and the disaster that has occurred. I expected, ladies and gentlemen, that this would make us more condescending in order to demand practical measures from the competent Commissioner. So I make the following findings: first, the most common finding, Commissioner, is that the success of the youth employment program depends on the ability of economies to create jobs. Secondly, without this, any measures will result in the recycling of the unemployed and we will be here in a year or two to talk about the new social phenomenon of the recycling of the unemployed. And I end with the following: combining market capacity with state support and intervention can solve the problem. I expect the Commissioner to give us concrete proposals that combine this with the ability of the Member States to shape the individual issues.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we appreciated the youth program and in Italy we were among the first to approve it.However, it must not be a system that feeds itself, for example only funds that can go to the establishment of IT platforms.They must go directly to young people, there must be controls such as a bonus-malus for the regions that actually use the funds to create jobs.On this I ask Andors if he does not think, having already heard him in the work committee in the Senate, that the public network should be implemented with the private network.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: For my part, and I think many of us have shared this, I was extremely pleased that this Social Democrat has its roots ... (Statement by the President.) that this Social Democratic Youth Guarantee program has been taken over by the European Commission and the EU institutions and started to be implemented. We have stated several times that this budget needs to be increased. The age limit must be raised to 30 years and, of course, we must also underline the importance of control, especially control of Member States' uses, especially if we can expect increased amounts in the future. We want to avoid individual governments trying to cover up their sluggishness with numerology, just like e.g. my Hungarian colleague did just that. And I want to say one more little thing - maybe not so little one thing. The little money a young person receives would be worth more if we abolished VAT on food across Europe.

name: Joachim STARBATTY
text: Mister President! I am new to this Parliament. I am a scientist. Scientists think in terms of cause and effect. I've only heard normative sentences here: We have to do this, we have to do that. Normative sentences without analytical support are irrelevant. We will need these sentences again and again in the next few years. What is needed is a root cause analysis. Why has unemployment decreased dramatically in Germany since 2010, especially youth unemployment? Why has unemployment, especially youth unemployment, increased dramatically in the southern periphery? Why is our export surplus always higher? Why are they no longer exportable internationally? Those are the crucial questions! If they just have an exchange rate that should apply to different countries, then I can tell them that it won't work. They will say the same thing again next year, and no one will invest. Who invests in a country that is not competitive? If you answer this question: "Why don't private individuals invest in our country?", Then you come closer to the question: "How do we get rid of unemployment?" (Applause)

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: Mr President, I would like to welcome the announcement made yesterday by Mr Juncker to change the age limit of people who can benefit from this Youth Guarantee program to thirty years. I also want to express a concern: this program will work well to the extent that it is close to the economic reality and the labor market, and as long as it is comprehensive. Many of the skills and knowledge to achieve this proximity are in the regions. In Spain, the Government has made an absurd distribution of the funds received to finance the program: the State Government will manage 85% and the regions, the remaining 15%, when powers are distributed exactly the other way around. This is not an internal problem of a Member State, it is a threat to the success of a European program. Therefore, we ask for control to correct these dysfunctions and guarantee the effectiveness of the program. And that is why, Mr. Andor, I ask you if you know the program of the Spanish State, of the Government of the Spanish State, and what do you think of that distribution that you are proposing when in the end it does not adjust to the different needs of the different regions of the Spanish State . It does not fit the needs that we have in Euskadi with a youth… (The President interrupted the speaker)

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: Mr President, the issue of youth unemployment is one of the key issues today. In my country, the Czech Republic, before joining the European Union, it was said that we must arrive to become valid and equal partners for our neighbors in the West. But dreams of adulthood have been replaced by the reality of forced structural adjustments and rising unemployment. The cynicism with which the neoliberal-soaked European institutions have decided to treat southern European states shows the true face of that European dream. Millions of unemployed people in Greece, Portugal, Italy, Spain, but also in other countries are an evil that needs to be confronted. Europe cannot afford to have a lost generation of young people. Nor can we afford the continuation of neoliberal and austerity policies. That is why we are also presenting a proposal where clear concrete measures will be taken, such as strong supervision of working conditions, which we, dear colleagues, did not talk about at all today. This also belongs to the complex of measures that we need to address. We will not solve this with one program, which also has a lack of funding. We will solve this only with a complex of measures for young people and money, which we will not give to companies and banks, but to young people as a whole.

name: Marco VALLI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I wanted to address the Commissioner for a moment to ask whether he really believes that the problem of employment is resolved by being precarious through reform.Because, in my opinion, this process transforms work into continuous blackmail and does not give people the opportunity to face life with long-term projects, feeding a greedy and exclusive system in our society where wealth is concentrated towards those who exploit the work.

name: Janusz KORWIN-MIKKE
text: Mr President, John Fitzgerald Kennedy, introducing the first bill on the minimum wage, said, frankly, that it was to protect industry in the North from competition from cheap labour from the South. Four million people lost their jobs. Then it was four million niggers but now we have 20 million Europeans who are the negroes of Europe – a full 20 million young people are negroes from Europe. Yes, they are treated like negroes. We must destroy the minimum wage and we must destroy the power of trade unions because the trade unions… (Objections) …listen to me, the trade unions are the instruments of … (The President cut off the speaker)

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: I invite you to use expressions which are appropriate for this House, thank you.Before giving the floor, I would like to ask the House to be silent.We are at the end of a very important debate.

name: Reinhard BÜTIKOFER
text: Mr President, forgive me, but that person used racist language. He used the word ‘nigger’ and should be censured much more strictly. (Applause)

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: Honorable, my reminder is a reminder to the honorable member who used that expression and the Bureau will evaluate and take action in the event of action.(End of the "catch-the-eye" procedure)

name: László Andor
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, honourable Members, I would like to thank everyone who contributed to this discussion and especially those who were speaking for the first time in this House. Because the time is short and the discussion itself was quite long, I will try to be brief but also concrete. I agree with everyone who stressed that the European Union needs to do more for economic growth and job creation overall, not only focusing on the young generation but on the entire labour market. However, we have reasons, strong reasons, to develop measures and reforms targeted at the young generation, improving school-to-work transitions in the European Union, because young people have been disproportionately hit by the consequences of the financial and economic crisis, and as is well known the youth unemployment rate is more than twice as high as the overall unemployment rate in the European Union. But our starting point is that Europe indeed is quite diverse. It is also very imbalanced. There are some countries which have been performing quite well and we have to help others learn from the good performers – this expression has been used widely in this discussion, including by Mr Arnott. Indeed the good examples of Austria, Germany and other countries where there is not such a great gap between the overall unemployment level and the youth unemployment rate need to be studied and if possible taken over. This applies to the various forms of dual training, apprenticeship models, but also how the public employment services function in these countries, and I strongly believe that good social dialogue and social partnership also contribute to finding the right solutions and the right ways forward. The Youth Guarantee is not a one-size-fits-all policy. The EU agreed on some key principles and parameters which can be delivered if the financial backing is also provided. But the Member States themselves are developing their own national Youth Guarantee schemes in close cooperation with the Commission, and also paying attention to each other. Questions have been raised concerning specific countries, such as Spain or Italy where the situation is indeed much more serious than in some other cases. The Commission is paying close attention to these countries. I myself before the end of this week will be going to Italy to attend the informal Council and next week once more to Spain, and these missions allow for comparing notes with the governments about progress with the implementation of the Youth Guarantee. This implementation does not entirely depend on the EUR 6 billion financial instrument, because this is a top-up fund to supplement the European Social Fund resources and the national resources that also have to be used. Almost all countries are still spending the ESF allocations of the previous period that ended last December. So because of the financial factor there are no delays. In fact those who have any kind of questions were given a good explanation of how to use these financial resources in March, which all the Ministers received, and some countries take advantage of the European Investment Bank bridging finance facility to accelerate funding to youth-related measures. This is of course not sufficient if we look at the very severe imbalances inside the eurozone. I agree with those who stressed that there is indeed a link between the EMU imbalances, and that is why we do not just have to monitor these imbalances through a scoreboard which includes youth unemployment and inactivity, but also to continue working on EMU reform and consider options for counter-cyclical fiscal capacity. This is what the Council will also discuss later this week in an informal setting in Milan – what options exist. The age limit has been discussed. Member States – and this needs to be known – Member States are allowed to go to 30 years if they opt for this. However, the Commission has been encouraging all these Member States first of all to focus on the generational cohorts under 25, to introduce the measures – very important reform measures – to support and improve school-to-work transitions, whether on the education and training side or on the labour market side. And once this is successful for under-25s obviously there should be no reason to refrain from going to a higher age bracket. This is not only a supply-side question – this is my answer to Mr Schwab. Skills are very important. Supply-side measures are important but the Youth Guarantee also has to be able to intervene on the side of the demand for labour and supplement the missing demand in many cases, especially at a time of recession. The Commission has been working very closely with the Member States and also checking how the funds are used and how the reforms are prepared. It is not only a matter of personal visits which I made in pilot cases in the city of Évora in Portugal, or Ballymun in Ireland, or the Extremadura region in Spain where there is a regional Youth Guarantee scheme already in place. We also use the European Semester to assess and provide feedback to the Member States and we cooperate with the ILO and the OECD which are also involved in technical advice. It is true that the Turin meeting of Heads of State and Government has been postponed but the Italian Presidency keeps youth employment and the Youth Guarantee among its priorities and the attention of the Heads of State and Government remains very important. So the Youth Guarantee is a major flagship initiative. The Commission is working with the Member States and other stakeholders to implement it, but this is of course not a substitute for the right macroeconomic policies or industrial policies which will help generate economic growth and jobs in the EU.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: Motions for resolutions to be tabled pursuant to Rule 123 (2) of the Rules of Procedure will be notified subsequently.The discussion is closed.The vote will take place on Thursday 17 July 2014. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Andrus ANSIP
text: in writing. - I support this resolution on youth employment, as youth unemployment is a pressing issue that needs to be addressed, especially in view of the aging population. It is extremely important to keep public finances in good order - this is how investments come to the state. And investments are what create new jobs. In Estonia, the government debt burden is the lowest in the European Union and Estonia has been a fairly attractive destination for foreign direct investment. In addition, both general and youth unemployment in Estonia is lower than the EU average. Nevertheless, the relatively high youth unemployment is also a significant problem in Estonia. I firmly believe that education is the best way to fight unemployment. In Estonia, there is a strong correlation between unemployment and the level of education - the unemployment rate is lower among people with a higher level of education. This confirms that we should further promote European Union education programs such as Comenius, Erasmus, Grundtvig and Leonardo Da Vinci. And, more importantly, to promote the free movement of workers within the European Union as a whole. Thank you!

name: Lorenzo CESA
text: in writing. - The "Youth Guarantee" introduced by the European Parliament is certainly an important step forward in the fight against youth unemployment, but is aimed at unemployed young people under the age of 25. As an Italian MEP, I cannot fail to point out the terrible emergency that my country is experiencing regarding the unemployment of young people up to 30 years and even beyond. But not only in Italy, in fact the young people between 25 and 30 who do not have a job, nor follow a course of study or training are about 6.8 million throughout Europe. It is clear that the solution to the unemployment problem cannot come only from the "youth guarantee". States need to work to streamline their bureaucracy, which prevents the creativity of self-employed workers and small and medium-sized enterprises from growing and developing. Fiscal policy must be lightened. Young people must be able to lead a dignified and independent life, with a job that guarantees them stability and security, decent wages and social protection. Only in this way will they be able to leave the family of origin, which today represents the last and only support for young unemployed people.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: in writing. - The economic, financial and social crisis has had a very negative impact on employment, especially with regard to the employment situation of young people. Unemployment in the EU-28 was 10.4% in April 2014, 22.5% for young people and over 50% in some Member States. 7.5 million Europeans under the age of 25 are not in employment, education or training. The EU's Youth Guarantee initiative contributes to the three goals of the Europe 2020 strategy: raising the employment rate of 20-64 year olds above 75%, reducing early school leaving to below 10% and lifting at least 20 million people out of poverty. and social exclusion by 2020. However, EU initiatives are not enough, and the active involvement of Member States is essential to reduce unemployment. According to Eurostat, youth unemployment has fallen most significantly in Hungary over the past two years. Thanks to the workplace protection action plan launched by the Orbán government in 2012, the employer burden decreased by 14.5 per cent for all employees under the age of 25, and by 27% (up to HUF 100,000) for two years for career starters. This measure helped some 200,000 young people. Promoting employment and reducing unemployment remains one of the most important goals of the Orbán government.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: in writing. - Europe's results are so far modest - there are very few countries where youth unemployment is not rising but falling. It can be seen that there is a great deal of confusion in Europe today, which is why everyone knows that the easiest way to fight unemployment is to reduce taxes or social security contributions, so that businesses can find work for people more easily. But because states are in debt, they can’t use this tool, so they have to dance in a heap and try to find ways that can lead to results without tax cuts. However, real recovery can only be expected from tax cuts and the consequent economic growth. Unemployment among the under-25s averages nearly 24 percent in EU countries. The negative record is held by Spain and Greece, where 56 and 61.5 percent of those between the ages of 18 and 24 are looking for work, respectively. In Hungary, the proportion of unemployed young people is around 27 percent. The European Union has recently decided on a number of targeted measures to support the unemployment of almost 6 million young Europeans, including the implementation of the so-called Youth Guarantee. I believe that the most important task now is to implement this program, so we must live up to the achievements so far, so I can only hope that the disbursement of the sums previously fought by the EP can begin in the near future.

name: Adam GIEREK
text: in writing. - In Poland, unemployment among young people exceeds 28%, which is more than a quarter of people under 25. Although this is a better indicator than in Greece (over 58%) and Spain (over 55%) and slightly worse than the EU average (23.5%), the Polish problem is just as serious. Youth unemployment not only has harmful economic consequences (lack of income - low standard of living, poor consumption), but also negatively affects the entire society. There is an army of young, highly educated people who are getting used to the belief that you can live without work. This causes an increase in crime and a threat to social stability. The relay of generations is torn apart, which may result in a future civilization catastrophe. Employers selfishly take advantage of the situation on the labor market and in Poland they increasingly employ young people for the so-called junk wages without basic social security. Thus, young people who are poorly paid and poorly prepared are gradually replacing older and experienced, but more expensive professionals on the labor market. I believe that, while rightly addressing the problem of youth unemployment, the European Parliament should do so taking into account the broad social and economic context, which goes far beyond the ad hoc solutions used so far. The degradation of work is not only a serious living problem, but also a psychological factor: the need for self-realization in the process of creating civilization.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: written. - One of the main reasons for the high youth unemployment in many member states is the economic and debt crisis in Europe, in the course of which companies tend to keep or even cut existing staff rather than employing young people. That is why sustainable crisis management is the most effective measure to combat youth unemployment! The eurozone members must consolidate their budgets in line with the Stability and Growth Pact and implement structural reforms, because this is the only way to achieve sufficient economic growth that creates new jobs. In addition, measures must be taken in the member states to make it even more attractive for companies to hire new employees - and especially young people. The following measures are suitable: - The reduction of the tax burden. - A relief for labor costs. In Austria, non-wage costs make up 49.1% of the total wage bill. - Measures to increase the willingness of companies to train, such as B. the so-called "Blum-Thousand", which companies in Austria received that trained apprentices. A measure that led to a sharp increase in youth employment in Austria. - The increase in the attractiveness of dual training, a system that is responsible in Austria and Germany for the fact that youth unemployment is relatively low compared to other member countries. The dual training system is an ideal "best practice" for the countries of Europe.

name: Eduard KUKAN
text: in writing. - It was stated several times yesterday in plenary that strengthening employment, growth and investment will be an absolute priority under the new President of the Commission. We are in a critical situation, the EU is fighting huge youth unemployment. We all agree that we need to pay attention to youth employment. I think one of the main recipes for success is rooted in business support. Create opportunities for young people. The business environment creates more jobs in which young people can find employment and where they can use their experiences and ideas. Let us remove the administrative obstacles that unnecessarily hamper the development of this sector. The second important part is the emphasis on education and support for those fields of study after which young people have a chance to get a job. It is necessary to focus on connecting the academic world with the practical one! Let us support as many programs as possible in which young people can gain their first work experience. I would also like to remind you that one of the cornerstones of the functioning of the EU is the free movement of people. Labor market mobility is irreplaceable for young people. In this respect, the creation of EURES is a necessity.

name: Krystyna ŁYBACKA
text: in writing. - To effectively increase youth employment, we must act together, coherently and effectively with the Member States. Increasing jobs for young people requires mutually complementary actions in the fields of employment, social and youth policy, economy and education. The increase in youth opportunities on the labor market is undoubtedly related to their substantive preparation and qualifications. In this respect, education plays a key role, as it should provide young people with adequate preparation for functioning in the changing labor market. It is important to introduce career counseling early in the education system. Vocational education is directly related to the labor market, therefore its curriculum should be consulted with employers' corporations and all other interested parties, including youth organizations, career counseling offices, training institutions, research centers, NGOs, etc. at all levels of education, which will enable the development of professional qualifications and competences of young people and increase their chances of finding a job. Ultimately, the effectiveness of actions depends on the fulfillment of the above criteria: commonality and coherence of actions, modernization of the vocational education system in terms of the needs of the labor market, and coordination and monitoring of initiatives taken in terms of their effectiveness.

name: Marian-Jean MARINESCU
text: signed up. - The youth unemployment rate in the EU reached 22.5% in April 2014, and in some countries even exceeded 50%. It is a wake-up call for both the Member States and the Union. Member States must make the most of the tools made available by the EU: the European Social Fund, the European Union Program for Employment and Social Innovation and the Youth Guarantee for 2014-2020. On the other hand, Member States need to reform the standards of education and training for young people and take into account employment opportunities in line with labor market demands. Cooperation with the private sector, creating an SME-friendly environment in the EU, ensuring optimal financial and legal conditions for start-ups, are initiatives that must be taken into account consistently. The European Commission must implement the Youth Guarantee as soon as possible and publish a communication in the coming months on how it has implemented it. The EU must keep its promises to young people, small businesses and disadvantaged regions, make the necessary funds available to them and spend money effectively.

name: Luigi MORGANO
text: in writing. - Joblessness in Europe is a major issue for most EU governments. It is not only a very "heavy" situation from a social and economic point of view, but also frustrating and disheartening as it places people in a situation of inferiority and to consider themselves unfit. The drama of the situation is evidenced by the data repeatedly cited in the debate, in particular those relating to youth unemployment which in Europe is 23% and in Italy 43%. Three considerations: either the trend on job creation is reversed or we will be forced to record increasingly alarming data; at the moment the reabsorption of youth unemployment appears distant; it is necessary to invest in school, vocational training, university and research to facilitate the meeting between demand and supply of work, in particular where innovation is required and at the same time dropout and early school leaving must be more effectively countered. If unemployment generates poverty and poverty overcomes the characteristics of the transitory and conjunctural phenomenon, social inequalities widen to assume the characteristics of a structural involution, and the fundamental rights of citizens are affected. For this, major political choices and the mobilization of all cultural, social and entrepreneurial forces are needed.

name: Péter NIEDERMÜLLER
text: in writing. - Today, more than 5 and a half million young people under the age of 25 in the EU do not have a job, while one in three young people in Hungary cannot find a job. The European Council will set aside a total of € 6 billion over the next seven years to tackle youth unemployment. I therefore urge the European Commission to consider the ILO's recommendation that EUR 21 billion a year be needed to effectively reduce youth unemployment. The introduction of the Youth Guarantee in Hungary is of particular importance. Due to the constant austerity, the economic policy that drove out investments, and the attachment to the institutionalized nugget in higher education, the young people lost hope that the current Hungarian government could change their hopeless situation. The situation of Hungarian young people is further aggravated by the fact that the largest reduction in funding in higher education was in Hungary, besides Greece. In Hungary, the education policy of the Orbán government is to cut the amounts available for higher education by 47% compared to the 2006 level, and to reduce the number of state-supported student places drastically. The European Youth Guarantee program offers hope to young Hungarians who have lost their faith. I therefore ask the representative of the European Commission here, Commissioner László Andor, to do everything in his power to implement the Youth Guarantee in the Member States and to provide the appropriate resources. You can count on DK MEPs in this work!

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – Youth unemployment in Europe is a challenge that needs to be urgently addressed if we are to secure better lives and futures for Europeans. We need an ambitious and holistic policy approach, encompassing the following elements. In order to achieve sustained employability, we need to create jobs in the short term, but also create long-term high-quality jobs and a business environment that will enable employers to hire more people. This can be done with a cut on the corporate tax of all EU-based companies, so that they could afford to hire 1 million Europeans on the average EU salary. Reforms are necessary in relation to the inclusion of vocational training in the curricula. It is also important to unleash the entrepreneurial potential of the young generations, e.g. by reducing bureaucracy in the application process for EU grants. The Youth Guarantee is an important step in bridging all instruments for tackling youth employment, but still some issues with its design and implementation exist. I would like to request information from the Commission on the implementation, costs and outcomes of the Youth Guarantee so far, e.g. what is the number of people that have found jobs through it up to now.

name: Marek PLURA
text: in writing. - The fact that one in five young Europeans is unemployed is today the greatest threat to the future of the EU, both economically and socially. Therefore, comprehensive reforms of the labor market and education systems are imperative without delay. Educational programs should better prepare graduates to meet the requirements of the labor market, close cooperation of the ministry of education and business is essential, as well as training towards entrepreneurship at all stages of education.
