It is also worth returning to proven forms of dual and vocational education, such as learning a craft. I am convinced that a well-prepared and carefully monitored implementation of the Youth Guarantee can bring about positive changes. However, it is necessary at the same time to create favorable conditions for the development of SMEs, as this sector creates over 66% of jobs in Europe. It is imperative to break down bureaucratic barriers and introduce incentives for self-employment and micro-entrepreneurship. I also believe that a coherent strategy for re-industrialization of Europe can contribute to a long-term improvement in the situation on the labor market.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing. - We have been tackling youth unemployment in Europe for several years, but it does not seem to be very successful. The young people themselves showed their dissatisfaction in May this year, when they did not vote in the EP elections. They have simply resigned, losing hope that Europe can solve their problem of finding a job in the labor market and secure their future. We are quite successful in offering young people the opportunity to study in any Member State, but we can no longer guarantee them employment. We currently have Member States where youth unemployment is 4%, but also countries where the threshold exceeds 30%. Therefore, measures and guarantees for young people must also take into account national requirements, they must guarantee that education will be linked to the requirements of the labor market. This will only work if all stakeholders, public authorities, schools and employers are aware of the need for cooperation. I support every good resolution that we will approve in the EP, but greater initiative must also come from the Member States themselves.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: written. - We are aware of the dramatic increase in youth unemployment and therefore I am especially pleased that this topic took place at the beginning of the new session of the EP, it is also commendable that the newly elected chairman Juncker mentioned solving youth unemployment as one of the priorities. It is good that there is a European Social Fund, a Youth Guarantee and a Youth Employment Initiative. These are all instruments to help solve this big problem, but the real solution is to create a culture conducive to SME development, create a conducive economic environment that can create growth and development in creating a flexible labor market and removing bureaucratic hurdles. It is also necessary to encourage mobility in order to acquire new knowledge and to change the education system and harmonize it with the needs of the market. It is unfortunate that today the 29th member state is mentioned, and that is the state of the unemployed. That is why we must do everything to make the economy in the service of man, and not the other way around, so that it is the main lever in youth employment. I must also mention the Republic of Croatia as a negative example because youth unemployment has been around 50% for several years, so politics has fallen on the test of using European instruments, but also on the implementation of reforms and strengthening the Croatian economy.

name: István UJHELYI
text: in writing. - There are currently 5.4 million young people out of work in the European Union, and high youth unemployment reduces the Union's social cohesion and economic competitiveness. In Hungary, the youth unemployment rate exceeds 27 percent. What is even more depressing is that the number of economic emigrants has increased tenfold in the last few years, now six hundred thousand - mostly young - have left the country and sought prosperity abroad. As a Member of the European Parliament and a Social Democrat politician, I feel obliged to create the institutionalized protection of the interests of this community and to find all the means to help and support those who need it to return home and make a living at home. Youth Guarantee and microfinance programs provide a meaningful clinging to this, but long-term results require much more comprehensive strategic solutions that protect the principle of free movement of workers but actively support repatriation. On the positive side, the newly elected President of the European Commission, Jean-Claude Juncker, will boost economic growth, and in particular the employment of young people, by EUR 300 billion over the next three years, working with the public and private sectors. At the same time, I suggest that we find platforms and resources that can be used specifically to support economic emigrants. Which can guarantee that we can provide them with opportunities in their own country, regardless of the actions of national governments.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: in writing. - Never before has Europe had a new generation with so many qualifications. This generation is called upon to survive in unprecedented economic and social conditions, with no way out. Today, millions of young people, European citizens, do not work or study. They have no choice, they have no tomorrow. The European South, and especially Greece, is affected by youth unemployment. Because a young man without a job, without a job prospect, is a young man without a vision, without a disposition to create. As members of the European Parliament, we have an obligation to act, to exhaust all our institutional possibilities, in order to deal with the greatest social scourge of our time. We must demand the implementation of the financial instruments already available, but above all the introduction of new flexible mechanisms, directly adaptable to the economic reality of each Member State. Reducing bureaucracy, promoting tax breaks for young entrepreneurs and start-ups is a first step. The strengthening of mechanisms, such as the European Certificate of Professional Qualifications, while recognizing non-formal education and supporting quality apprenticeship, a second. Any financial facility, whether through the ESF, or through programs such as COSME and Erasmus +, or through low-interest loans from the EIB, must be made immediately available to young people.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The next item is voting time.(For the results of the votes and other details concerning them: see Minutes)

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: This concludes the voting round.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: Mister President!In order to avoid any misunderstandings, I would like to say that we of course voted for Lithuania to join the euro zone, but against Amendment No 1, although youth unemployment is the biggest wound in the European Union and I therefore very much welcome the fact that the Commission President-designate yesterdaymade it very clear that he will present an investment, growth and employment program worth EUR 300 billion by February 2015.The amendments that we voted against have nothing to do with Lithuania's accession to the euro zone, but they do address important issues that we need to address in economic, social and employment policy.I just want that clarified.This application was only rejected because it has no causal connection with the accession of Lithuania.Monetary union is a strengthening of the internal market, and the internal market is our job engine.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: Mr President, regarding the Langen report on the adoption of the euro in Lithuania, I would like to explain why I abstained on Amendment 3 to Article 7, which calls for reform of the EU Treaty. No doubt the Treaty is in urgent need of reform, but to vote in favour will be to accept the Treaty in principle, which I cannot – and will not – do. I do not want the European Union Treaty to apply in the United Kingdom in any way, shape or form. I want my country to leave the European Union and not to be bound by any EU Treaty, reformed or otherwise. Britain’s accession to the Treaties was in fact an act of treason, something I explain in detail in my little book, ‘Inglorious Revolution’, which you can get from Bretwalda Books Ltd. Britain should withdraw without delay from the European Union, repudiate the Treaty and restore her status as an independent, sovereign, democratic nation.

name: Andrus ANSIP
text: in writing. - I supported Lithuania’s adoption of the euro. It will strengthen Lithuania’s position at the political and economic core of Europe. Estonia joined the euro area in 2011 and this step has proved clearly beneficial for us. Our three-year experience in the currency area is a positive example of how the euro allows for the enhancement of economic ties with the rest of Europe. Namely, the euro brought stability and made the economy attractive to foreign direct investment, which has further helped in creating jobs. The unemployment rate in Estonia is lower than the average in the EU. In addition, the euro has clearly supported trade – 70% of Estonia’s exports go to other EU Member States. Last but not least, the euro was and is beneficial for ordinary people. During the time of the Estonian kroon, 90% of all credit was taken in euros: those people no longer have to worry about currency risk. I strongly believe that Lithuania will benefit in the same way Estonia has. It is my great pleasure to extend a warm welcome to Lithuania in the euro area.

name: Heinz K. BECKER
text: written.- The crisis was not a euro crisis, but a national debt, economic and financial crisis.The crisis in particular has shown that we in Europe can only exist together.The aim of monetary union is “to achieve convergence in the internal market and in the euro zone, which creates growth and employment.A year ago, some were predicting the collapse of the euro zone.None of this happened, ”recalls the EU politician.The EU even emerged stronger from the crisis.The monetary union is not finished yet.The admission of Croatia to the EU and the admission of Latvia and Lithuania to the euro zone during the crisis is a sign that we are getting stronger.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: written.- I show my support for the adoption of the euro by Lithuania since January 1, 2015 because, as stated in the report of the European Central Bank of June 4, it meets all the convergence criteria required by the Treaties and that hasIt was the will of the Lithuanian Government and Parliament.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing.- I did not intend to support with my vote the Langen report which analyzes Lithuania's adoption of the euro.The extension of the eurozone to this country, starting from January 1, 2015, will absolutely not benefit its economy.We will soon have a new state brought to its knees by the crazy economic choice of the single currency.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this very important report for Lithuania. First of all, I would like to congratulate and congratulate my country, which has successfully implemented the necessary convergence criteria with great effort and has the opportunity to join the euro area family. The single currency of the European Union is one of Europe's most successful achievements. It is not clear what the economic situation would be for Europe now, if not for the euro, because having different currencies during the crisis would have put us in the grip of banking and fiscal transactions. Thus, Lithuania's accession to the euro area once again demonstrates the success and necessity of the single currency in Europe. The euro is one of the most important connections that unites Europe, so I am confident that we will continue its successful history. I would like to wish my country that the introduction of the euro in Lithuania will continue to promote economic growth, job creation and quality employment, so that the Lithuanian people will finally feel its benefits in their daily lives.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing.- I vote against.Unfortunately, the euro has already given ample proof of its harmfulness to the economies of the various countries in the area to which it belongs in general and with several very serious particular cases (Greece, Spain, Portugal, Ireland, Italy, Cyprus).Currency parametrized exclusively on the German economy (Germany is the only country to have benefited from it), responsible for the recession, the drop in exports, the increase in the unemployment rate and an unprecedented impoverishment of the middle and lower segments of the European population.Now, with the adoption of the euro by Lithuania, the crisis will only spread to this country.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. - In the resolution adopted today, Parliament declared itself in favor of Lithuania joining the euro area from 1 January 2015. I welcomed the fact that Lithuania has met all the eligibility criteria for the euro: average annual inflation recent by 0.6% (well below the reference value of 1.7%); a government deficit of 2.1% of GDP in 2013 (3% reference value) and a gross debt ratio of 39.4% of GDP (well below the 60% reference value). All this shows that a lot of work has been done by Lithuania since 2006. Lithuania is about to become the nineteenth member of the euro area, after Latvia (2014), Estonia (2011), Slovakia (2009), Cyprus and Malta (2008), Slovenia (2007), Greece (2001) , and Belgium, Germany, France, Ireland, Spain, Italy, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, Austria, Portugal and Finland (1999). Welcome to the euro zone, Lithuania!

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing.- I have recently arrived in the European Parliament and I was genuinely surprised to be immediately voting for this report.In Italy there is discussion about the goodness of the choice, made at the time, to join the euro, and in other countries there is an effort to respect the parameters required to be able to enter this monetary system.It is a sobering fact, combining rudimentary economic policy considerations with deeper assessments of the factors that determine the competitiveness of our businesses.However, these assessments add to my wealth of political experience.With regard to the proposal, I chose to accept the request presented by Lithuania and, after evaluating the consequences for my country (limited to the governance of the European Central Bank, therefore without impact for Italian companies), I decided to vote in favor.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: signed up.- I welcome the expansion of the euro area, given that the European Executive considers that Lithuania's progress in meeting its obligations to achieve economic and monetary union has been met and that Lithuania meets all the conditions for the adoption of the euro.

name: Rachida DATI
text: in writing.- I supported Lithuania's entry into the euro zone from January 1, 2015. This Member State of the European Union indeed meets the criteria required to be able to adopt this single currency.Lithuania's first request to adopt the euro in 2007 was too early.The country's economy did not meet the required convergence criteria, in particular because of excessively high inflation.Lithuania has made efforts to meet the targets.Now able to adopt this currency, Lithuania will be from January 1, 2015 the nineteenth member of the euro area.

name: Dennis de JONG
text: written.- The SP group votes against amendment 3 because of the call to the European Commission to make proposals to achieve "genuine European Monetary Union".The SP is not in favor of this.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. - As in other cases, including that of Portugal, the process of preparing Lithuania for joining the euro, obliging the fulfillment of strict membership criteria set out in the Stability Pact, involved a painful exercise of applying measures and policies with high social costs and economic. Contrary to what is said in the report, this process is far from being a success. Lithuania has gone through a period of deep recession in recent years, with a strong contraction of the national economy, loss of purchasing power for workers and the general population, very high unemployment rates and forced emigration of a significant part of its youth. All in the name of wonderful promises that - the situation of countries like Portugal demonstrates today to the satisfaction - never materializes, quite the contrary. The promised Eldorado results in a prolonged nightmare, with the loss of important instruments of monetary, exchange rate and budgetary sovereignty that are now held by the ECB / EU and exercised in the interests of the great powers and their economic and financial groups. We respect each country's sovereign right to decide on its future. But we are not unaware of the fact that the Lithuanian population has consistently opposed this accession. We voted against.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing.- The enlargement of the European Monetary Union to include other EU Member States is an important step not only in strengthening the single currency, but also in response to EU opponents' efforts to subvert the single currency as a strong stabilizer of the market, economy and common EU policy.Meeting the criteria for joining EMU is not easy for the countries that joined the EU in 2004.I also know this from the experience of my country - the Slovak Republic, which had to meet not only all the criteria, but also to establish an internal mechanism that would prevent a huge increase in prices for consumers.I would therefore like to wish Lithuania the best possible results on this journey and we can offer inspiration from Slovakia.

name: Peter JAHR
text: written. - I would like to thank the rapporteur Werner Langen for his good and balanced report, which leaves no doubt that Lithuania is ready to adopt the euro. The country has experienced remarkable economic development in recent years and has met all the criteria for admission to the euro zone. Despite the financial market crisis of recent years, Lithuania has low national debt and low inflation rates. The efforts made so far must be maintained in the future in order to achieve sustainable development. As for every other euro partner, the stricter rules of the Stability Pact also apply to Lithuania. The introduction of the euro will further boost the economic upturn in Lithuania. Exchange rate fluctuation risks are minimized. A small country like Lithuania in particular benefits from a stable euro. The introduction of the euro is not only a positive sign for Lithuania and the Baltic States. Like Latvia's accession, Lithuania's accession is a strong signal for the euro zone. The euro has not only established itself - despite many prophecies of doom - as a strong second world currency alongside the dollar. It's also a political project and a shared success story. I am pleased that in Lithuania we have gained another reliable partner in the euro zone and I am convinced that others will soon follow.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: in writing.- I support Lithuania's entry into the euro area.Lithuania has not been unworthy since 2006, following its first unsuccessful candidacy.The Lithuanian debt situation has improved considerably in recent years.Lithuania now fulfills all the technical criteria to join the euro area from January 1, 2015.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: in writing.- I welcome the fact that the European Parliament has supported the resolution on Lithuania's accession to the euro area from January 1, 2015. After a first attempt in 2006, Lithuania made significant efforts to meet the criteria foradoption of the euro.This new membership sends an important positive signal to the entire Union.Indeed, the euro has been strongly criticized and wrongly blamed for the economic and budgetary difficulties that several countries of the Union are currently experiencing, and in particular France.Thus, this accession of Lithuania reminds all Member States that the euro is an opportunity and, on the contrary, offers guarantees of security, stability and economic prosperity.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: in writing. - I voted in favour of Lithuania joining the eurozone, and I am overwhelmed by the fact that 545 colleagues supported Lithuania’s adoption of the euro, thus paving the way for Lithuania to join the eurozone on 1 January 2015. This marks the final success of Lithuania’s efforts to comply with the common rules on fiscal and economic discipline. It is also a further clear proof that the eurozone is viable and continues to grow. Poland too is on its way to join in the foreseeable future. Lithuania was the third Baltic state to join the eurozone, reminding the European community that it requires political will and commitment to further European integration, to conduct structural reforms, to ensure budgetary balance and to abstain from spending resources that are not available. I welcome our Lithuanian friends to the eurozone. Another contribution has been made to reliable fiscal discipline in practice.

name: Kaja KALLAS
text: in writing.- I supported Lithuania's accession to the euro because I believe that this is the only right step for a small country.We must not forget that the European Union is both an economic and a monetary union.As Lithuania is an open economy, as are Estonia and Latvia, which have already joined the euro area, joining the common currency area will benefit the economy.Firstly, currency risk and security will disappear for investors, and secondly, it will increase the inflow of money into the local economy.Together we are stronger.Thank you!

name: Jeppe KOFOD
text: in writing. - Unemployment, and in particular youth unemployment, is one of the biggest challenges we face in Europe. It is vital that we boost growth and investment, which can provide more and more than 25 million unemployed Europeans with good and lasting employment in good conditions and at a fair wage. Fighting unemployment is and will be a social democratic flagship issue. I myself have pointed out the possibilities of improving the EIB's lending opportunities, creating green jobs through more ambitious climate and energy goals and the need for a strengthened youth guarantee. However, this vote is not about unemployment or youth unemployment, but specifically about Lithuania's introduction of the euro. That is why the amendment by the Verts / ALE Group does not belong in this specific text, and I have therefore chosen to vote against it. I want to work for a real fight against unemployment in Europe and not just vote for meaningless expressions of opinion in reports that have no bearing on the fight against unemployment.

name: Werner LANGEN
text: written. - The large majority in the European Parliament for joining the euro is a sign that MEPs are counting on a successful future for the euro and the EU. The vast majority of over 82% also proves that the Eurosceptics are on the wrong track. What was particularly noteworthy in yesterday's plenary debate was that a large number of negative contributions were made by left and right-wing opponents of the euro, which obviously do not correspond to the mood. Mr Lucke's justification, which has now been postponed, that the Bundesbank would temporarily lose its voting rights as a result of the rotation principle in the Governing Council, which will come into force upon accession, was not the subject of debate either in the Economic Committee or in yesterday's debate in plenary. Mr Lucke, who sets this out in a written minority declaration, has neither tabled any corresponding amendments nor comparable requests to speak, thereby proving that the opponents of the euro are not interested in an objective discussion, but rather short-sighted and populist arguments against the common European currency. I am pleased that the enormous efforts that Lithuania has made to join the euro have been so clearly supported by the European Parliament.

name: Jérôme LAVRILLEUX
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the Langen report on the adoption of the euro by Lithuania on January 1, 2015. Indeed, Lithuania fulfills all the conditions necessary for a secure entry into the euro zone, such as legislationcompatible national level, stable prices or even controlled public finances (public deficit of 2.1% of GDP, where France fails to meet the 3% required by the European Commission).In addition, entry into the euro area will help Lithuania meet the challenge of its energy independence.

name: Patrick LE HYARIC
text: in writing. - I abstained on Lithuania's accession to the euro because I believe that it is above all for the Lithuanian people to vote on this issue. In order to meet the Maastricht economic criteria (limits of 3% of GDP for annual deficit and 60% of GDP for debt), Lithuania made a drastic reduction in its public spending when it was impacted. by the fallout from the financial crisis. This lack of flexibility is even more drastic once in the euro, since it is in the name of the rules of the Stability Pact that the Commission can now regularly monitor the budgetary policies of the States and dictate the economic policy to be followed. This loss of sovereignty, in favor of a currency that is certainly more solid but in many ways too rigid, and within a budgetary framework that significantly reduces any investment policy, must be the result of a broad citizen debate. That is why I abstained while respecting the decision of the Lithuanian people.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: written. - Following Latvia's entry into the euro area on 1 January 2014, the introduction of the euro in Lithuania is expected in 2015. Persistence in implementing structural reforms and fiscal consolidation in Lithuania has resulted in meeting the criteria for the introduction of the euro. Inflation in April this year was 0.6 percent far below the 1.7 percent reference value. At the end of 2013, public debt was 39.4 percent of GDP and the central government deficit was 2.1 percent. Lithuania has been a member of the exchange rate mechanism since 2004 and has not had any major deviations since then and has managed to keep the long-term interest rate below the reference value of 6.2 percent. Thanks to the efforts made by Lithuania in recent years to implement the convergence rules, Lithuania will become part of a society in which it will participate in decision-making that will help strengthen the euro and secure the benefits of the euro as a currency. Transaction costs, the reluctance of credit agencies (joining the eurozone will raise the country's credit rating) are a thing of the past. Falling prices, increasing competitiveness and exports are the advantages of the introduction of the euro. It is up to Croatia, as well as other Member States, to make additional efforts to meet the convergence objectives and ensure the benefits of eurozone membership.

name: Svetoslav Hristov MALINOV
text: In written form. - On 16 July 2014, we adopted by a large majority a resolution supporting Lithuania's accession to the euro area. The Baltic Republic has for years demonstrated a firm course towards the adoption of the single currency and I am pleased that this will officially happen on 1 January 2015. The fulfillment of Lithuania's convergence criteria is indicative - the country demonstrates a moderate government deficit of 2.1% of GDP and a public debt of 39%, which is far below the European average. With regard to all other ECB benchmarks and criteria on interest rate levels and price stability, Lithuania has also demonstrated convincing performance. The Republic of Lithuania joins Latvia and Estonia, which have also made the transition to the euro in recent years. It is significant that, despite the financial crisis and difficulties throughout the EU, the pan-European currency project remains attractive to newer member states. The Lithuanian Litas joined the ERM II currency mechanism (the so-called "waiting room" of the euro area) as early as 2004 and has been pursuing a targeted policy with a view to adopting the euro ever since. Such efforts are to be welcomed and can serve as an example of the successful transition from a currency board system to the full adoption of a common currency for countries such as Bulgaria.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing.- I presented my position in favor of Lithuania's adoption of the euro on 1 January 2015. The legal conditions for the adoption of the euro are defined in Article 140 TFEU and Protocol 13 on the convergence criteria, whichmust be fully complied with.According to the Commission's convergence reports, all criteria were met, so I was in favor of another Member State joining the monetary union.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. - This report confirmed Lithuania’s progress in complying with the convergence criteria under Article 140(1) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, namely: the compatibility of national legislation with Articles 130 and 131 and with the Statute of the European Central Bank; the achievement of a high level of price stability; the sustainability of the government financial position; compliance with the normal fluctuation margins of the European Monetary System’s Exchange Rate Mechanism for at least the past two years; durability of convergence, as reflected in long-term interest rate levels; and financial stability. I look forward to Lithuania joining our common currency soon and I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Anne-Marie MINEUR
text: written.- The SP group votes against amendment 3 because of the call to the European Commission to make proposals to achieve "genuine European Monetary Union".The SP is not in favor of this.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. - I support this report on the adoption by Lithuania of the euro on 1 January 2015. Since Lithuania is the last Baltic state to adopt the euro, it is very positive that the country has achieved a high degree of sustainable convergence with the euro area and that it fulfils the conditions for adopting the euro as its currency. I believe it is essential for the European Union to have a single currency for the Member States and that is why I voted in favour.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing.- The euro area is made up of 18 countries that share the same single currency and common economic and budgetary controls, with a view to ensuring the continued stability of the European monetary area.Lithuania aims to be the 19th country to join the single currency, and the International Monetary Fund (IMF) has found that the Lithuanian financial system is liquid and well capitalized.I am therefore voting in favor of Lithuania's accession to the single currency, considering the euro to be a strong and stable currency, a situation that is largely due to the strong action taken by the European Central Bank (ECB).I would also like to congratulate Lithuania for presenting solid and sustainable public finances, namely a budget deficit of 2.1%, a public debt of 39.4% of gross domestic product and an average inflation rate of 0.6%, thus conferringfinancial independence in favor of new strategic investments.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of Lithuania joining the euro zone. This text has consultation value since the final decision rests with the Member States. Lithuania, like all countries that have joined the European Union since 2004, is required to adopt the euro. Obviously very strict criteria have been put in place in order not to weaken the euro zone by a succession of unprepared memberships. In my opinion, two of these criteria are very important and make it possible to strengthen the convergence of the zone. The first is the respect of a contained inflation during the 3 years preceding the adhesion. This measure helps maintain price stability in all countries using the euro. The second is to have a debt of less than 60% of GDP. The economic crisis that has rocked the continent in recent years was a debt crisis and not a currency crisis. The integration of indebted countries in reasonable proportions therefore makes it possible to strengthen the whole area. Finally, I would like to stress that it is a prepared accession which follows a first refusal by the institutions in 2006.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: written. - Even in its first serious test, the euro hardly proved to be crisis-proof. Only the massive and very worrying intervention of the ECB prevented a collapse. The reason for its weakness is the basic construction: One currency for a Europe of 20+ different economies with different economic cycles and fiscal policies. At the turn of the millennium, we were guaranteed that the over-indebtedness of individual states would not be paid for with the money of other countries within the monetary union, because there should be no over-indebtedness (Maastricht criteria). Now we have known since the ESM that the dachshund - although contractually obliged not to touch the stock of sausages - has eaten it. What a surprise and how prophesied! With great effort and all kinds of taxpayers' money, the collapse in 2012 was averted and I do not think it makes sense to include another nation - no matter which one - in this unstable construct at the moment. In addition, the number of permitted ECB Council seats will be exceeded due to the new inclusion. This now requires that every nation has to sit out once. Controversial euro decisions can be made over and over Austria or Germany through good timing. That is very dangerous. That is why I voted against the admission of Lithuania to the monetary union - but this has nothing to do with Lithuania in particular.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: in writing.- I believe that the decision on Lithuania's accession to the euro area may have significant consequences for the future of the state and the Nation.Therefore, at the most important stages of the development of the state, the government should hear the voice of the Nation.We have no right to ignore the fact that most Lithuanians do not want the euro.However, the "Euro train" travels to our country at a tremendous speed, despite the fact that more than half of Lithuanians have a negative opinion about Lithuania's accession to the euro area.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: in writing.- At today's meeting, I supported the report on the adoption of the euro in Lithuania.I respect that the decision on Lithuania's adoption of the euro was taken on the basis of the will of the democratic institutions of the Republic of Lithuania.Personally, I prefer the adoption of the euro in my country to be decided in a referendum, but the form of adopting the euro is a matter for every Member State and its citizens.

name: Franck PROUST
text: in writing.- I voted for the Langen report on the adoption by Lithuania of the euro on January 1, 2015. This non-legislative report is in favor of Lithuania's entry into the euro.It clearly shows that the euro is not a negative currency.Despite the economic crisis which has seen the euro falter due to constant attacks from certain financial markets or speculators, the euro has turned a corner.A regulation and a protective framework have been added to our currency, which remains a strong, stable and forward-looking currency.The euro protects us from external attacks.Lithuania has understood this, and in view of its very good results it will become the 19th Member State of the euro area on January 1, 2015.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: in writing.- Since its candidacy in 2006, Lithuania has done important work to meet all the criteria for joining the euro.Indeed, Lithuania now has a public debt of less than 60% of GDP and a budget deficit that does not exceed 3% of GDP.At the same time, Lithuanian inflation is low and its currency remains stable.I therefore supported this resolution which will allow Lithuania to become the 19th Member State of the euro area on January 1, 2015.

name: Kay SWINBURNE
text: in writing. - According to the Commission Convergence Report 2014 (COM(2014)0324) and the European Central Bank Convergence Report of June 2014, Lithuania now complies with the legal and economic preconditions for adoption of the euro laid down in Article 140 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union and Protocol No 13 on the convergence criteria, namely: legal compatibility with the Treaty, price stability, sound and sustainable public finances, durability of convergence, and exchange rate stability. The ECR Group takes the view that EU Member States which fulfil all the criteria and wish to join the euro should be allowed to do so. The Group position was therefore in favour of the Langen report.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: written. - I welcome the efforts made by the Lithuanian authorities in the past period, as Lithuania has distinguished itself as a serious country when it comes to implementing reforms. This is confirmed by the fact that of the eight EU countries assessed by the European Commission, including Croatia, only Lithuania meets the set convergence criteria for the introduction of the euro. I hope that the Council of Ministers will confirm the Commission's recommendation and that Lithuania will adopt the euro on January 1, 2015, because for a country like Lithuania, but also Croatia, joining the eurozone brings more benefits than costs since Lithuania is highly "euroized". The consequence of high "euroization" is that citizens keep their savings in euros, and the currency clause and exchange rate differences have a negative impact on the population, but also on business people, because they are exposed to exchange rate risk. For example, citizens in Croatia, which is in the process of excessive deficit, currently "pay" the price of non-membership in the eurozone, so due to exchange rate differences, rates for housing loans and other types of lending are often extremely high. The introduction of the euro would avoid such a possibility. Therefore, for the benefit of Lithuanian businessmen and citizens, I welcome the introduction of the euro and I hope that Croatia will follow the example of Lithuania and meet the set criteria in order to join Lithuania and other members of the Eurozone.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: in writing. - Lithuania has fulfilled all the conditions necessary for it to adopt the euro early next year. The European single currency is an important tool for economic development. It is no coincidence that the next President of the Commission also referred to the euro as an important tool for protecting Europe. The introduction of the single currency is therefore in the common interest of all Member States, and thus of the Union and its citizens. Therefore, there is no question that I support its introduction in all Member States that meet the conditions. Lithuania was forced to step back once in 2006 in this area due to high inflation. Now, however, you can introduce the euro in a more prepared way and in a way that better serves the interests of its citizens. In order to avoid misunderstandings, I would like to state here that I urge Hungary to fulfill these conditions as soon as possible, together with the fact that the Hungarian government will have to pay special and much more attention to the fact that the implementation process both in its interests and as far as possible.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: in writing.- Lithuania already wanted to adopt the euro on January 1, 2007. This project failed in 2006 due to excessive inflation in the country.Since then, Lithuania has continued to develop and has made significant efforts to meet the criteria for adopting the euro.On February 25, 2013, the Lithuanian government decided to set itself the goal of introducing the euro on January 1, 2015. It is to be hoped that the determination of the Lithuanian government to adopt the euro on the 1stJanuary 2015 will increase the support of the population.The Lithuanian Parliament (Seimas) adopted, on April 17, 2014, the law on the adoption of the euro by Lithuania by 87 votes in favor, 7 against and 13 abstentions.This result indicates that Lithuanian parties are clearly in favor of the euro.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. - I particularly appreciate the fact that Lithuania wants to enter the eurozone. Its willingness should remind many of us how we sometimes fail to take sufficient account of the benefits of sharing this common project that is the euro. It is particularly pleasant to vote for the acceptance of Lithuania, as this Baltic country meets all the criteria for adoption of the euro. As we all know, this has not been the case in the past with other countries. Twenty-five years ago, Lithuania was part of the Soviet Union: today it is a European country, its prosperity is increasing day by day, it is a Member State of the EU and it will soon be part of the eurozone. That is a success we should all be proud of.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: written.- The convergence criteria applied to the new members of the euro area are entirely arbitrary and ideological.In this sense, the austerity measures imposed on Lithuania for the adoption of the currency have been draconian and have caused great suffering to a large part of the population.As Lithuania has already de facto adopted the currency and its Parliament has asked for membership, so as not to call into question the sovereignty of the country or exclude it from the government system of the euro area, I have cast a favorable vote for membership.This does not exclude that the euro area continues to have serious structural problems that it must face immediately, if it is to endure and not continue to be a drag on the well-being of the population, particularly on the periphery.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: in writing. - Although the UK is not a member of the eurozone many other Member States believe it is right for Member States like Lithuania to join. I am therefore pleased that Lithuania has met the criteria, including low inflation and interest rates, and I voted in favour of Lithuania joining the euro on 1 January 2015.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. - Lithuania's preparations for joining the euro represented a painful exercise in forced austerity. Throughout this process, the people of Lithuania were subjected to drastic measures with high social and economic costs. Contrary to what is said in the report that supports this accession, this process is far from being a success, considering the strong contraction of the national economy, the fall in wages, the very high unemployment rates and the resurgence of forced emigration. It is also important to remember that this accession was rejected by the majority of the population in a referendum in May 2013. We continue to consider that the process of joining the euro represents an intolerable interference with national sovereignties, preventing national authorities from developing autonomous policies adapted to specific needs. each country. The subjection of national states to the ECB's monetary policies, which are strongly conditioned on the interests of the strongest economies in central Europe, has been and will continue to be a factor of divergence from EU economies.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing.- Lithuania's preparation process for joining the euro is a painful exercise in forced austerity, whereby the people of Lithuania have been subjected to drastic measures with high social and economic costs.Contrary to what is said in the report supporting this accession, this process is far from being a success.It is not, by chance, that this accession was rejected by the majority of the population in a referendum in May 2013. Indeed, Lithuania has in recent years gone through a period of great recession, with a strong contraction of the national economy, loss of power topurchase of workers, very high unemployment rates and forced emigration of a significant part of their youth.The will of the Lithuanian people must prevail over any other foreign interests.

name: Claude MORAES
text: Mr President, I rise on a point of order, under Rule 11(2) which refers to Members’ conduct being characterised by mutual respect, based on the values and principles laid down in the basic texts of the European Union. We heard from Mr Janusz Korwin-Mikke in the previous debate language which is deeply unacceptable in this Chamber. I want to intimate to this Chamber that appropriate action should be taken by Parliament’s services. Cécile Kyenge, the Member next to me, has made the same remarks as myself and she may want to add to what I have said. (Applause)

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: Mr Korwin-Mikke's speech this morning was very serious.Those words spoken by him here offend the dignity of this place above all, the dignity of this Parliament and also the spirit of the Union.His words undermine the principles stated in Article 11 (2) of the Parliament's Rules of Procedure.His words have not only offended people like me, who have another skin color, but all of us in here who are animated by the values that are the basis of these institutions, the values of equality and dignity of every person.I therefore ask for this to be able to apply appropriate sanctions for this type of behavior.The words that are pronounced here have a weight and this is also why a strong battle against all forms of discrimination and racism must begin from this place.

text: Mister President!There is nothing more to say about these two requests to speak.That's why I'm not saying anything more, just that I fully understand and share it.However, I would ask you not to stop at saying that you are informed, but also to indicate a possible reaction that could take place here.I think this meeting deserved it.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: - The next item on the agenda is the debate on the statements by the Council and the Commission on the state of play with payments from the EU budget in view of unresolved EU commitments of unprecedented amounts (

name: Della Vedova Benedetto
text: President-in-Office of the Council. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, you have asked the Council and the Commission to make a statement on the situation of payments in the EU budget. This is an issue directly linked to the budget negotiations underway this year. The Council recognizes the existence of a specific problem relating to invoices, overdue payments, in particular in the area of ​​cohesion policies. Such payments, like all others, must of course be made. Obviously, it is in the interest of the Council that no Member State has to deal on its own with the consequences of a problem which risks leading to an increase in national budget deficits. But there is another important aspect in relation to the budget which concerns the ways in which to achieve a correct balance between two different kinds of interests. On the one hand, we must respect the commitments we have made, and on the other we must take into account the need to ensure that the EU budget reflects the requirement for individual Member States to fully respect the deficit targets set in the Pact of stability and growth, a requirement which is primarily a European obligation. It is true that last year we agreed on the annual budget ceilings from 2014 to 2020 in the Multiannual Financial Framework, but these ceilings do not constitute expenditure targets. Rather, they must be assessed annually in the context of the economic situation of the Member States and the possible impact on national budgets. This Parliament together with the Council approved a legislative package three years ago which lays down the basic rules that impose such budgetary discipline on the Member States. Therefore, the EU budget requires careful planning. Requests from Member States to create sufficient margins below the ceilings are made to try to control unforeseen or unexpected financial needs. Therefore, I strongly hope that we can avoid a debate in which we try to divide the European Union between good and bad, those who want to spend generously and those who first of all want to save. We're all in this together. We want to use and invest the EU budget in the most effective way to stimulate innovation, growth and jobs. At the same time, we must bear in mind the budgetary constraints within which we find ourselves operating. The experience of the last two years shows that the Council is always willing to respond to proposals to cover justified and urgent payment needs. Last year we approved an amending budget of € 11.2 billion. Why did we ask that it be divided into two parts? To ensure adequate monitoring of changes in payment needs, but also to assist national budgetary authorities in adjusting to the resulting additional financial burden. This year we will participate in the same spirit in the discussion and negotiations on the draft amending budgets that are on the table, as well as on the draft budget for 2015. Although the backlog of payments in the area of ​​cohesion was very high towards the end of the year. last year, it decreased significantly from 23 to 10 billion euros in the first half of the current year. We are evidently going through a transition phase between the accumulated bills at the end of a programming period and the start of a new period where a certain amount of time is required for the implementation of programs and for these to be fully effective in terms of economic leverage. We should take advantage of this situation rather than risk our negotiations failing. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, our national economies and the need to promote growth in investments require an EU budget that is designed and implemented in the most effective way to deliver results. The Italian Presidency is ready to spend all its energies to achieve this goal. Thanks for the attention.

name: Androulla Vassiliou
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, the Commission welcomes this discussion on the payments situation in the EU budget at the start of the Parliament’s new term. The discussion is indeed timely, as both branches of the budgetary authority are engaging in discussions on the amending budgets for 2014, requesting additional payment appropriations, and on the 2015 draft budget. Over the last few years, the budgetary authority has effectively followed a two-step approach whereby, first, an artificially low level of payment appropriations was authorised in the budget with the understanding, reflected in a recurrent joint statement, that a supplementary amending budget might be needed in the course of the year once implementation provided compelling evidence that more payment appropriations were needed. We saw this in 2012, when an amending budget of EUR 6 billion was adopted at the end of the year, and again in 2013 when, thanks in particular to the determination and support of Parliament, an additional EUR 11.2 billion was eventually made available to cover outstanding needs. This approach in agreeing the budget in successive stages makes the budgetary process almost unintelligible and undermines the EU’s credibility. The EU budget should serve to implement our common priorities. This must be taken with seriousness and realism, addressing all the foreseen needs in the knowledge that the new Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) provides the tools to address unforeseen needs should they arise.  The Commission proposals for the 2015 draft budget and for amending the 2014 budget reflect a responsible and realistic approach but again, realistically, they will only lead to stabilising the overall situation. The new MFF provides for enhanced flexibility, not least thanks to the determination of Parliament. The Commission has consistently made it clear that the overall payment ceiling defined in the 2014-2020 MFF would require the implementation of specific and maximum flexibility, and that it would make use of available flexibility instruments as provided for in the MFF Regulation if and where needed.  This is what the Commission did in late May this year by presenting draft amending budget No 3, with a request to use the remaining margin under the payment ceiling – some EUR 700 million – and the activation of the contingency margin mechanism for an amount of EUR 4 billion. Such a request is justified by the payment shortages experienced in several programmes and by a number of unforeseen circumstances, including a higher than expected pace of implementation in cohesion policy, which led to an unprecedented level of unpaid bills at the end of 2013 to be covered with appropriations in the 2014 budget. For the 2015 draft budget, the Commission proposes to make full use of the payment ceiling agreed in the Multiannual Financial Framework. Combined with a careful management of resources these measures should curb the global growth of outstanding commitments and provide the means to address our obligations stemming from previous years’ commitments.  Let me take this opportunity to give a face to this problem. It is not just about ministries or universities or even Member States as such, getting money back later than expected. In many programmes, for example in research and innovation, we have small private companies that have valid contracts and have performed their agreed work and incurred the agreed costs and now could face a situation in which the Commission simply cannot pay them in time. The Commission will have to mitigate these risks. In this context, the risk of SME bankruptcy will be one important factor to consider. These proposals are also a key condition to kick-start the new investments in infrastructure, innovation, growth and jobs needed for the new period 2014-2020, precisely in line with the strategic priorities for the Union as agreed by the Heads of State and Government on 26 and 27 June. Developments on the revenue side should greatly facilitate the solution. Exceptional additional revenue from fines stemming from the enforcement of competition policy will accrue on the EU budget in 2014, meaning that the additional payments requested for 2014 will be at virtually no cost to the Member States.  At the budgetary trilogue last week, Parliament and the Council had a first opportunity to exchange views on the Commission proposals for the three amending budgets for 2014 and for the 2015 draft budget. The Commission is doing everything within its powers to address a difficult situation. We can only hope that the Council and Parliament will soon reach agreement on a sustainable solution.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, Mr President of the Council, ladies and gentlemen, to speak of expenditure on payments is to refer to investments already made in favor of innovation, research, the promotion of smart, sustainable and inclusive growth, the promotion of employment . These expenses are legally incurred with the agreement and at the request of the Member States. Beneficiaries are young people, small and medium-sized companies, researchers, universities, local authorities. It is not acceptable that these expenses already incurred do not have sufficient amounts to be paid. It's not about saving here, it's about paying what you owe. In cohesion policy alone, we have more than 23.4 billion euros of expenditure already made, for which there is no financial availability. All studies show that cohesion policy makes a positive contribution to all 28 Member States and its 272 regions. In addition to infrastructures, we are also talking about support for young people, training, innovation, research, environmental protection and sustainable growth. The European Union institutions must be exemplary in terms of their commitments. Payment expenses are commitments assumed and already made. Not paying means, in addition to not respecting commitments, a breach of solidarity with the Member States and regions that are in greatest difficulty. The Council must work together to resolve the payment problem. Failure to do so is to act against oneself, it is to lose authority and credibility. I therefore hope that the Council will contribute to the adoption of the amending budgets that are proposed and that will help to alleviate the problem of payments. And congratulations to the Commission for the fact that it has submitted amending budgets that are aimed at solving this problem.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Mr President, we are starting a new mandate and we are already in plenary talking about the problem of payments that we have in the Union. We have been dragging this problem for several years, above all because of the incomprehensible attitude that Member States have had in the Council so far. In 2010 we ended up with 5.5 billion euros in unpaid bills; in 2011, with 11 billion euros; in 2012, we went up to 16 billion euros; and we ended 2013 with 25 billion euros in unpaid bills. It is clear that this situation is unsustainable and, if we do not remedy it now, we will end with a suspension of payments. It could appeal to legality and sound financial management, which requires that the European institutions make the necessary resources available so that the Union can comply with its legal obligations. It could appeal to the credibility of the European Union and to the need for our partners to trust that we will meet our international commitments; or compliance with the agreements of the European Council, which, at its last meeting, for example, agreed on the need to invest and prepare the economies of the member states to meet transport, energy or telecommunications needs. But honestly, these appeals have never been of any use. We have given them reasons and we have given them figures and the Council has continued to act as usual: not paying and cutting money. I am glad to hear the Council acknowledge that we have a problem; but it has just agreed on the level of payments for 2015 and has cut the European Commission proposal by 2 billion. I honestly don't know what your plan is. I don't know if they have it. I don't know if you think that by not tackling the problem we will solve it, and that is why I would like to hear from the Italian Presidency, which we trust to solve this problem, the proposal of a package of measures to put an end to the problem of non-payments. And I'm going to give you a few ideas. First: to approve the amending budgets, to reduce this debt by 4.7 billion euros. Second: work now on a review of the financial framework to be able to raise these maximum payment limits. Third: definitely promote this high-level group and work on new own resources for the European Union project. Fourth: to draw up a proposal for financial instruments to mobilize resources to be able to invest in the long-term investment plan that the Union sorely needs. And fifth, for example, to draw up a proposal to exclude the national contribution to the European budget from counting the deficit of the countries, and thus relax the tensions suffered by national finances. We have given you reasons, figures and even solutions, but if you need more examples I will give them to you. Because behind these unpaid bills there are municipalities, there are small companies that need their money back, and there are also NGOs. I will finish, President, with one last example: humanitarian aid programs have been paralyzed and 400 Iraqi families do not even have money to eat.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Mister President! We are talking today about the EU's outstanding debt obligations, which have reached a level that is a matter of great concern. The current payment budget of the EU is 135.5 billion euros, and now the budget is to be increased by 4.7 billion euros for payments through a supplementary budget No. 3. Of this, 4 billion euros will be accounted for by additional revenue, which the Member States will ultimately have to raise. For example, Germany has to pay 668 million euros for this amount. Although these funds are to be credited to future budgets, according to the draft supplementary budget not immediately as planned, but only in the budget years 2018 to 2020. This shifts the burdens into the future and significantly limits the budgetary sovereignty of future parliaments. Can the Commission guarantee that it won't need more money in 2018? I would like this information. In addition, z. B. provided in the supplementary budget to make these payments for so-called unforeseen expenses. But every year there are unforeseen expenses. It is also noteworthy that this expenditure is partly necessary because it is determined in this way by EU regulations. For example, with the ESF, the pre-financing rate for a particular measure was set almost ten times as high as usual. That alone has led to additional spending of 99 million euros. But if these expenses are deliberately brought about by regulations, are they unforeseen? We say: no. We, the ECR, oppose budget increases through the back door. Instead, we should take this as an opportunity to think about whether our budget system is sustainable at all, whether we have enough transparency and sufficient control options. We should definitely introduce this and use it as an opportunity.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Mr President, the inadequacies and dysfunctions of public governance, whether national or European, arouse the exasperation of our fellow citizens. The May 25 poll made it possible to measure its full extent. Each public actor has a duty to be exemplary by staying away from hypocritical and unsustainable practices. From this point of view, the European Union is jeopardizing its authority due to the explosion of "remainder to liquidate" (RAL) and the alarming increase in unpaid bills. The RAL, this practice justified by the time lag between the authorization of commitment and the realization of the corresponding expenditure, reached an unprecedented level of 222 billion euros on December 31, 2013. The Council must align its promises and its acts. Any complacency in the matter activates a fatal gear. For lack of courage, the gap widens from year to year and comes a time when delinquencies accumulate. As of December 31, 2013, the invoices due reached more than 23 billion euros, in sharp acceleration: 5 billion at the end of 2010, 11 billion at the end of 2011, 16 billion at the end of 2012. Undoubtedly 26 billion at the end of 2014 if no corrective measures are taken. . This situation is outrageous. At the start of the legislature, we must resolve this drift because it contradicts the principles that we intend to ensure that the Member States respect in terms of the sincerity of their public finances. The Commission has just sent us three draft amending budgets which will reduce the pile of unpaid bills by 4.7 billion. Unpaid bills affect NGOs for humanitarian aid, field hospitals in the Middle East, students deprived of Erasmus grants, researchers in need of funding, and local communities deprived of resources. The account is not there. In this context, the alternative is simple. Either we reduce the commitments and proceed to strict trade-offs by giving priority to investments for the future, competitiveness and employment, or else the Member States accept an additional contribution covering unpaid debts. Although not liquidated, this share of costs should be entered in the budgets of the Member States. It is futile to imagine that waves of fines would be enough to alleviate this debt. I am impatiently awaiting the new own resources, but I doubt that we are on the eve of their collection and, in any case, this European taxation should be offset by the reduction, by the same amount, in the weight of the levies compulsory levies levied by Member States. We must act without delay. The European Union is not intended to get into debt in a sneaky way. Finally, of course, the post-electoral review of the multiannual budgetary framework will have to sanction the end of this ubiquitous system. Our heads of state and government can no longer make promises on the back of the European budget without providing the corresponding funding. I am thinking of the youth employment initiative announced in 2013 for an amount of 6 billion euros. Stop hypocrisy. The image of Europe in the eyes of our fellow citizens is in question. Let us see that the fruits keep the promises of the flowers.

name: Pablo ECHENIQUE
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, I am Pablo Echenique Robba, from 'Podemos', and I am new to this House, so little crowded when there are no votes. There are many things that I don't know yet, but being a scientist I learn quickly. Recently, I have learned, for example, that the European Union is not like the Lannisters, that the European Union does not pay its debts: they tell me that it owes more than 24 billion euros to the Member States and that, year after year, the The Commission and the Council are engaged in 'beating around the bush', as they are doing here today. This has really surprised me. You see, I come from a country to which the Union, through the troika, has been invited in very non-transparent and very undemocratic ways to change the Constitution to put the payment of the debt to the banks ahead of any investment in people's social rights. With the votes of the socialists and the popular, this reform was effectively carried out in a country that was living and is experiencing a humanitarian emergency, with millions of poor, unemployed and evicted. Seeing this situation, one tends to think that paying the debt must be something very important, something sacred, perhaps the eleventh commandment. Then you find out that the Union owes more than 24 billion and thinks that, being new, there must be something that you have not understood well. This double standard is too spectacular to be true. That is why I ask the President, the Council and the Commission to deny that the Union owes 24 billion and please confirm to me that what you put on the screens and on the agenda today is a mistake.

name: Helga TRÜPEL
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, dear Presidents! This is not the first time that the EU Commission warns of empty coffers and payment defaults. This year, however, it is particularly alarming because the payment defaults appear much earlier than in previous years. The Commission is putting off a mountain of payments. We have just heard the number: 221 billion euros. The annual budget is around 135 billion euros. This shows how big this problem is. Where does it come from? One major reason is that the Council was not ready to make the payments it had promised. As a result, payments and open invoices always had to be carried over into the next few years. So the problem just keeps getting bigger. I find the Council's behavior in disregarding promised payments irresponsible. Last year the Commission had to carry over 23.4 billion into 2014, and now we have a gap of 4.7 billion. A supplementary budget has been registered for this. I urge the Council to move here. Now we still have surpluses from 2013, and with amendment budgets 2, 3 and 4 we could now find a solution that would cost the Member States only EUR 105 million. But I think it is much more crucial that we not only keep looking at what ad hoc possible solutions there are in terms of crisis intervention, but that we have to come up with more structural political solutions, and that means that we need a revision of the multiannual financial framework. We Greens have always pointed out that the payments are too small. That is why we did not approve this MFF. We clearly need a revision so that the payment ceilings can be adjusted. And we need a new system of own resources.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, since I was a child I have been taught that if commitments are made, they must be respected. It is therefore absolutely not permissible not to honor what is due. The 5-star Movement is available to support all the measures necessary to get out of this situation, starting from the next amending budgets. However, I would like to make one thing very clear: either the management of the European budget changes or we will find ourselves in this situation once again. I have here with me a joint declaration from the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission concerning the implementation of the 2002 budget. 2002, you got it right, well over 10 years ago! This declaration regretted the serious payment situation and called for measures to reverse this dangerous trend. Unfortunately, the hopes have remained so, as too often happens, and we are still here to discuss this problem, today even more serious and more dramatic than in the past. I would like to ask the Commission: why has this huge payment gap been created? Perhaps in the past we have chosen to commit ourselves to indulge this or that particular interest, without thinking of specific well-determined priorities that must necessarily take into account the difficult reality of the facts and above all of the accounts. It is also curious that my compatriot Della Vedova is leading the Council today. We Italians, in fact, cannot give lessons to anyone in this area, since we are well aware of the enormous problem of paying public administration debts. The European Union has also recently opened an infringement procedure against Italy for this very reason. Let me say, Mr President, that we are in a rather paradoxical situation. Italy today is preparing to lead the European Union just when the latter has a huge payment problem. The European Union itself, however, sanctions precisely those who drive it because they do not pay. We are therefore wondering how this issue will be resolved, because honestly, gentlemen, we are a bit confused.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, in order to exist, the European Union promises to make itself visible, generous, indispensable and to do this multiplies the programs and commitment appropriations, forgetting that eventually , you have to pay the bill. Today, we are debating the unprecedented gap - these are your own words - between the Union's financial commitments and the funds actually available to honor them. 21 billion on average out of 140 billion, or about 15% of the 2014 budget. Today, this recurring unforeseen period must unfortunately be dealt with urgently by post-budgetary revisions. This proves once again that, both at the level of France and at the level of the European Union, your macroeconomic model is inept and ruinous for the citizens. The inflation of the European budget since the Delors I package is continuous. In 35 years, the budget has multiplied by 15. The Europe of Brussels has good luck giving lessons to States on sound management of public finances via the European budgetary treaty and the stability pact while it is incapable. -even to do the forecast management and that it finds itself in negative cash to the tune of more than 21 billion, that is to say a situation of suspension of payments. This certainly raises the question of the credibility of the European Union, which is always striving to steer the budgetary policies of the Member States a little more. When you want to give lessons, you have to be irreproachable yourself. Now, what is the sincerity of your budget? What private sector company would not anticipate this shortage of payments and financial drift? In your logic, we spend first and then adjust the revenue, like so many public authorities and inconsistent States. This is how you make up for it with annual amending budgets. It is the facility for reckless public spending that has generated in France 40 years of fiscal year deficit and over-indebtedness of 2,000 billion euros. However, the Member States do not wish to contribute more to the Union budget, as the discussion on the multiannual financial framework showed very clearly in June 2013. We therefore foresee the next stage of the reasoning, that is to say say European tax. Commissioner, tell Mr Juncker that the French patriots have placed the European Commission under enhanced surveillance ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Marian-Jean MARINESCU
text: Mr President, at the end of 2013, outstanding payments in cohesion policy for the 2007-2013 financial programs amounted to 23.4 billion. According to the latest estimates, by summing up the 2014 payment claims, the level of outstanding cohesion payments will increase by 3 billion, reaching a backlog of around 26 billion. The situation we are facing is not new. It started in 2010; the figure was then 5 billion. Each year, the need for additional payments increased, but each time the Council did not recognize the amount calculated by the Commission and accepted only an insufficient increase. We live in a paradox: Member States submit payment claims, Member States do not want to cover the necessary amounts, ie to meet their commitments. There are no amounts higher than the commitments in the MFF, there are amounts that were not spent when they were provided in the budget; the Member States received those amounts back at that time, because you know that then the rule was that, at the end of the year, the unspent amounts would go back to the Member States' budgets, now the Member States have to bring those amounts back to the Union budget. Parliament requested, if you remember, as a condition of the 2014-2020 MFF approval, the settlement of overdue payments and this was not fully done. We are still in a time of crisis. The projects carried out by the Member States, for which payments are requested, are projects whose theme is exactly what is needed during this period: economic development and job creation. If we do not solve the situation created, jobs will be lost. A rectification for 2014 is needed, to be approved before the approval of the 2015 budget, in order to avoid discussions in previous years. I ask the Council, if it does not agree with the settlement of these outstanding amounts, to decide which of the invoices should not be paid and to assume full responsibility.

name: Isabelle THOMAS
text: Mr President, Commissioner, Mr Representative of the Council, you have observed, as I have, the persistent difficulty in which the Community budget has found itself since the crisis of 2009 broke out. The Union's resources are more than ever necessary for investment, especially when States are subject to austerity. However, the Union's budget is constantly shrinking. We deplored this during the negotiations on the multiannual financial framework and every year we fight against further cuts by the Council in budgetary years. Member States are now prisoners of their austerity choices. Worse, for several years we have been faced with a "Council of bad payers", in a mechanism that borders on the absurd. Member States underestimate their billing, postpone their payments and deny their signed commitments with the European citizens we represent; a narrow and faltering ambition where their contribution to the Union budget becomes an adjustment variable, even when it comes to long-term investments. Since 2010, we have been in increasing tension with each financial year and today, the European Commission is proposing a third amending budget to the tune of 4.7 billion euros, of which around 4 billion would be made up of the new system introduced by the MFF , the contingency reserve. First year of existence of this patch and already an unforeseen one! Is this not proof of the lack of sincerity on the part of the Member States in the Union's budget negotiations? At the same time, the Commission is proposing two other amending budgets, this time to the credit of the community. In the end, this should only bring the Member States' contribution to around one hundred million euros. And yet some oppose the application of this new device. This payments crisis is therefore neither minor nor one-off. It is a symptom. The symptom of a sick Europe. The symptom of an outdated budget system bordering on the absurd. The European Union must endow itself with new own resources, no longer depend on blackmail from the Member States. We European Socialists, for example, have long been in favor of taxing financial transactions, but we will have to go further. We must make our budget, its expenditure and its revenues, a political instrument of sustainable growth, cohesion and social justice. This crisis is also the symptom of the failure of the austerity policy. The same Member States which advocate budgetary virtue multiply contortions and writing games so as not to apply the policy that they themselves have decided! Yes, of course we need serious budget! And this seriousness should be states that pay their bills, that do not endanger thousands of companies, associations, public authorities in Europe. It should not be this unbearable austerity which destroys the European social model and condemns the States of the Union to half-measures in the face of the most important crisis that our continent has known for 70 years. This payments crisis is above all the symptom of a Europe sick with its ultraliberalism, this organized and willed disappearance of public power, this absolute and unreasoning faith in the market. We wait for private investment like a Messiah who never comes! Yet Europe needs investment. To support the economy, to fight effectively against unemployment, especially among young people, to prepare the essential green growth. And for that, a strong and sovereign public power is needed. The payments crisis like the May 25 elections is imperative. We have five years to change course, and a new methodology ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Richard ASHWORTH
text: Mr President, I supported and approved a reduction in the size of the EU budget. I also fully support and approve the Commission’s proposals to increase spending on jobs, growth and competitiveness. But unless there is also a significant reduction in the other traditional spending patterns, then an ever-deepening payments crisis is inevitable. It is a crisis which, along with the long-standing and growing problems with RALs, means that the current spending plans are unsustainable. The solution is not continually to seek an increased budget. Instead, it is time we accept the fiscal limits, time we conduct a radical and strategic review of the whole budgetary process and time, in particular, to ensure that we prioritise spending strictly in line with value for money.

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: A Uachtaráin, d’aimsigh rialtais an Aontais Eorpaigh na billiúin ar mhaithe leis na bainc ach ní féidir leo airgead a aimsiú chun infheistíocht a dhéanamh i ndaoine. Caithfear taighde a dhéanamh ar infheistíocht i réimsí tábhachtacha cosúil le hoideachas, agus oiliúint. Tá na rialtais tar éis diultú go rialta do na hacmhainní riachtanacha seo a chur ar fáil, ag malartú na bhfocal agus ghaois an Choimisiúin. D’fhág an creatlach airgeadais ilbhliantúil poll de EUR 23.4 billiún i mbuiséad an Aontais Eorpaigh. Tá an t-airgead caite cheana féin. Anois tá ar na Ballstáit, na réigiúin agus páirtithe leasmhara eile fanacht ar íocaíocht. Ní amháin go bhfuil tionchar ag an moill ar na híocaíochtaí seo, ar chumas airgeadais na mBallstát, go háirithe iad siúd atá i gcónaí i gcruachás maidir le cúrsaí airgid agus srianta sóisialta, ach cuireann sé isteach chomh maith ar chur i bhfeidhm go leor tograí an Aontais Eorpaigh. Táimíd ag cur clár i bhfeidhm atá níos leithne i scóip ná riamh cheana féin ach i ndairíre atá i bhfad níos lú. Is iad na daoine óga atá dífhostaithe, na mic léinn, ollscoileanna, fiontair bheaga in Éirinn, sa Ghréig, sa Phortaingéil, sa Spáinn agus in áiteanna eile atá ag fulaingt.
