Caithfidh an Chomhairle Eorpach agus an Coimisiún a bheith freagrach agus tá sé thar a bheith in am dóibh aghaidh a thabhairt ar na dúshláin seo go dáiríribh agus go tapa.  Agus ar nóta beag amháin is mór an onóir dom gur féidir liom mo theanga dhúchais a úsáid anseo inniu.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: Mr President, this is not a difficult subject. It is not rocket science. You cannot spend money you do not have. Prioritise. What spending is not really necessary? If the political will existed in this Chamber, you could have just one seat for the European Parliament and save hundreds of millions of euros a year. If the political will existed in this Chamber, you would scrap the EUR 3 billion a year the EU spends promoting itself. That is a bigger advertising budget than Coca-Cola.  If the political will existed in this place, you could scrap many of the luxuries that we enjoy as MEPs and take a lead in showing that economy begins at home. But just three hours ago this very Chamber voted in favour of parliamentary delegations and junkets. The answer is not to go back, cap in hand, to national governments and to ask them to fleece taxpayers for even more money. The answer is to put your own house in order.  Where is the political will in the Committee on Budgets to do this? We do not even have pre-set failure criteria for EU-funded projects to know whether they have achieved what they promised. No-one takes responsibility. No staff are dismissed when taxpayers’ money has been wasted. Ultimately, this place could remember that EU money really belongs to the taxpayers of each Member State. Some in this Chamber, astonishingly, have used the misspending of EU money as an excuse to call for EU taxation. Well we will soon know whether the European Parliament has the guts to take the decisions necessary to bring this back under control. And is it not amazing how empty this Chamber is today as we discuss such an important issue? Where is the political will? We do not need more of the same. We do need some tough decisions. (Applause)

name: Jan OLBRYCHT
text: Mr Chairman, Commissioner, Ladies and Gentlemen! The question that needs to be asked today is: are we dealing with a problem of a budgetary nature, i.e. whether we are dealing with a problem of a lack of cash paid in, whether we are dealing with a problem of wrong calculations, wrong forecasts when it comes to the level of expenses, are we dealing more with a political problem? I am rather in favor of this thesis. If we give a signal that we lack money in the budget for a specific policy or policies, and let us remember that the cohesion policy is based on co-management by the Commission and by the Member States - if we give a signal that we have a hole in the budget, and yet - let me remind you - payments to the budget is 1 percent of gross national income - let us not exaggerate with the fact that it will overturn national budgets. If we give such a signal, it means that we are also giving a signal that we stop supporting certain policies, that we are no longer interested in certain politicians, that we will not say it out loud, we will not say it directly, we will not do it "de jure", but we will do it is "de facto". In other words, we will not close our priorities, but we will not have enough money to do so. This is a very dangerous political signal, and therefore we are not only dealing with a budgetary problem, but also with an attempt to change European policy.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the situation we are discussing today is not the result of extraordinary events, it is not the result of unforeseeable events. We are talking, Mr President, of a non-emergency that has arisen due to a tradition, a meaningless tradition that the Council, under pressure from some of its members, has been carrying on for some years, despite the Parliament and the Commission have always opposed. This is good to repeat today too. Even today, even here, we cannot fail to reiterate how the constant lowering of the level of payments, as has already been emphasized several times in this House, is to the detriment of citizens and not to their favor. Every euro that is taken from the European Union is a euro taken from research, it is a euro taken from education, small businesses, agriculture, innovation, cooperation and research and that is why the commitments that States hiring in Brussels must be honored, out of respect for other countries certainly, but above all out of respect for citizens, out of respect for those who, thanks to the support of the European Union, are trying to restart the economy of our continent. I want to remind you once again that the EU budget is an extraordinary, formidable investment tool. The investments that, in its absence, the member countries would never, ever be able to finance. And unfortunately, the recent negotiations on the Multiannual Financial Framework have reduced the overall amount compared to the previous period, and this has happened for the first time in the history of the Union. Unfortunately, our budget in times of crisis was not used to revive the economy. It was not used to revive the occupation, but wrong logic prevailed of ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Petri SARVAMAA
text: Mr President, first of all, the obvious but painful fact has to be stated once again: the situation is absolutely unbearable. And not just that, but unfortunately the payment nightmare of the European Union is also such that it will not go away even if we manage to solve the acute cash-flow crisis. But we have to start somewhere. So the first thing that should be done is to mobilise all instruments available to cover the shortfall. Every year we commit ourselves to a certain number of programmes. So we all agreed to a certain total of bills – and now those bills have to be paid. This can only be done by temporarily increasing the level of payments as far as I can see. But as I said, this alone does not get us far. As the total sum of outstanding commitments keeps rising year after year, there are only painful answers left – given that we genuinely want to solve the budget crisis. As I suppose we do. Ironically, the post-financial crisis position of the Council does make sense in the way that we can spend only what we can afford to spend. But it is ironic because Member States were there when commitments were made. So, if we want to be logical in building a better Union, we first have to answer our own call. After, but only after, that has been done, can we reduce the level of payments. The level of commitments we can, and perhaps should reduce cautiously. But even more importantly, we should make sure that what we commit ourselves to makes sense in terms of creating new economic activity, which will in turn help us out of this vicious circle and this means that we have to achieve the badly needed growth and that growth will then bring employment.

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the payments crisis is a recurring crisis which today calls for a political response before tackling technical questions. Some would like to take advantage of this situation to kill the very idea of ​​a Community budget. In fact, not setting a sufficient level for payment appropriations sends a negative message for the Structural Funds and for multiannual planning. That is why I insist on the fact that the issue must be settled politically. Many of us, during the electoral campaign, have provided education on the usefulness of investing in the territories and the need also to take future investments out of the convergence criteria. Indeed, we will not be able to revive employment without a policy of major works, in particular infrastructure. The Structural Funds have this vocation. It will be necessary to add an infrastructure fund which will have to be greatly revalued. I am elected from a rural and agricultural constituency and the use of the ERDF and the EAFRD, in fact, associated with ambitious infrastructure policies make it possible to win twice. They contribute both immediate activity but also prepare the future of the movement and attractiveness for our regions. I understand the point of view of States which have drained public finances and which are reluctant to add to the pot. This is the reason why I sincerely believe that we must very quickly work on the questions of new revenue and revenue, effectively European - in particular the taxation of financial transactions - which will allow, tomorrow, to imagine a new budget, new revenues, the latter effectively avoiding this pitfall. If we continue in this spirit, it will always be the headlong rush.

name: Lambert van NISTELROOIJ
text: We have a new Parliament and we are getting a new Commission. A fresh start inspired by Mr Juncker's thoughts yesterday: investing in growth, in jobs, in competitiveness. But there is still a big shadow over this new start, because what about our own payment morality? I hear from universities and from cities and regions that the bills for work done one or two years ago are not paid. We have adopted a new directive for the Structural and Investment Funds. We have established a late payment directive. Pay within three months, that's standard, that's the moral. As rapporteur and coordinator of the Committee on Regional Development for Cohesion, I have a major problem here. The Commission is shifting the accounts to 2015 and even 2016, but that does not solve the problem. This is even more difficult now that the budgets have been significantly reduced by the Council. What about 2014, the year of the new start of the Commission and the new period of the MFF, is there any investment at all? Is there fresh money? Will that be available? It should not and cannot be that 2014 is and will be, in all fine words, a lost year when it comes to investments. That is the core of my message. I have a few questions. Can we get transparency in September at the start of our new activities in the Committee on Regional Development? The figures we have now are from March 2014. Which Member States does the Council think have problems? Will you assist, as the Commissioner said, if SMEs go bankrupt because of this payment morality? How does that work? And can we regain the confidence of the citizens and send the new Commissioners a real message? This will be a crucial point, also in the hearings.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: If you ask the directors of small and medium-sized enterprises, hospitals, but also mayors and mayors, they will tell you that if the debtors do not pay them on time, they may go bankrupt or be forced into administration.That is why we have recently approved a directive requiring companies and institutions to pay their debts within 30 days.If we demand financial discipline from others, we must lead by example.Today, we are convinced once again that we lack the resources to repay our liabilities.We are in danger of structural deficits and distortions with consequences.How to force the Council to live up to these commitments, but also how to systematically solve the budgeting problems?The final solution is to complete the system of own resources to which the European Union has committed itself.I expect the future Commission, led by Mr Juncker, to help us with this.

name: Markus PIEPER
text: Mister President! If we have EUR 140 billion outstanding payments for the cohesion policy program alone, then it is foreseeable that there will have to be delays in funding decisions and payments. The Council cannot just cut payments and pile up commitments at the same time. This leads to supplementary budgets that violate the principles of good housekeeping. Many in the House appreciate the Council because it has put a lot of excessive activity on the part of the Commission and parts of Parliament in their place. But now the point is not to damage Europe's reputation. We want to remain a reliable partner to our regions, research institutes and companies. The Council must now do its part and at least temporarily increase payments. But the Commission must deliver too. Incorrect expenses can be recognized earlier and punished more severely. The recovery system should be speeded up. I call for the N + 3 rule to be revised. Some Member States have to learn that European funding is not a never-ending story. And last, but not least, we have to ask ourselves the question much more whether European spending doesn't have to be linked to European added value. Instead of the watering can principle and waste of subsidies, we have to focus much more strongly on regional and agricultural policy. That also helps to save money. One more remark to the colleagues here on the right: We really don't get any further with general insults and superficial criticism. I cordially invite you to enter into the details of the budget debate. Europe is more likely to be helped with constructive criticism than with general abuse. (Applause)

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: Mr President, the European budget has reached an unprecedented crisis. Today, we are almost facing a structural deficit that risks affecting European policies, all European policies, whether we are talking about education, research, foreign policy or cohesion policies, regardless of political color, regardless of nationality, regardless of state and this it will especially affect the citizens we represent. Unfortunately, I do not see here the policy of austerity imposed by Mrs. Merkel and the political right in many European countries, including Romania, the country I represent. Colleagues, concrete measures are needed in the following directions: a truly political political dialogue between the Council, the Commission and Parliament to resolve funding issues, a fair communication in the Member States on the direction of European funds that are truly reaching our countries. The European budget, we must say, belongs to all European citizens, it is not a piggy bank used only by some, by no means by those in the East, and we need to talk more to find a common solution to the European budget.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Mr President, the crisis we have with the remaining outstanding payment commitments is a recurring crisis, which we talked about last year and was in part part of the compromise in adopting the multiannual financial framework. We know that the announcement of such a scenario was very clearly foreseen by our colleague Lewandovski in April. The problems we have with payments for both research and employment and cohesion policy, education, foreign policy commitments, fisheries are essentially a key problem of what the European Union should be, and that is the added value for investment, for work, for employment. So it seems to me that we need to find a solution as soon as possible. I especially appeal to the Council that the funds that have already been allocated in some way must be paid - this is important for the credibility of the European budget, for fulfilling the commitments, but also for the new spirit after these European elections where we are all obliged. take care of the efficient financial management of the European Union.

name: João FERREIRA
text: Mr President, what is born late or never straightens. A maxim that can be applied as a glove to the 2014-2020 Multiannual Financial Framework. The eloquent statements about growth and employment that many here make, from the right to social democracy, shockingly collide with the budget poverty they have approved. But even this poor budget is not fulfilled as it should be. More than € 23 billion are missing, money owed to the Member States, particularly in the area of ​​cohesion, and the lack of which leads to the suspension of several ongoing programs. The same ones who are inclement when it comes to extorting interest on a largely illegitimate debt from peripheral countries, they do not pay what they owe to the European Union budget. It is increasingly evident that there is a need for a revision of the current financial framework as early as possible, with the appropriate and appropriate allocation of resources to the budget, without which cohesion, growth and other buzzwords will be just that - buzzwords of their own to unravel. in pious and empty speeches, increasingly distant from reality.

name: Ingeborg GRÄSSLE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen! We have a really worrying situation with outstanding RAL, outstanding commitments of 223 billion. I wonder if the 2014-2020 budget will ever come into force. Dear representatives of the Italian Presidency, it will not be enough simply not to show your colors here. As a Member State you cannot do anything other than represent the Council Presidency. That's why we count on you and count on you to put an end to this worrying situation. We have now highlighted one billion euros for research in 2015. This is an untenable situation. I believe that if we switch resources into the structural funds, we will make much better progress in terms of growth and jobs than we have done up to now. I also found a job where there is money left over: the staff statute came into force this year with corresponding restrictions on the subject of promotions. However, the money on the line acts as if these restrictions don't exist. I hear that all the EU institutions are handing out this extra money, so to speak. That is why I would like to call on all EU institutions to do the relevant homework here and also to give us the data on what money is actually available there.

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: Mr President, I am fascinated by this. We have again been talking constantly about how we are going to make things better and there is constant talk of investment. We have got all these programmes – all these programmes! – but not enough money. Well, that is the point. There is not enough money. You are all here talking about digging holes to get deeper. You are talking about trying to eat yourselves thin. The whole point is that the whole of the Western world is in debt, massively bankrupted. Hear some constructive commentary from my friend who mentioned it earlier: save this money, cut back on all these needless programmes, and stop trying to interfere in every part of everyone’s lives. How about saving that money and distributing it back to the countries you have taken it from? They could then give a really nice tax cut so that people could decide what to do with their own money. It is not yours to constantly make up ideas on how to spend it.

name: Andrzej GRZYB
text: Mr. Chairman! I think we are aware that it was the European Parliament that adopted the assumptions for the budget, both for the long-term and the current one. There are also commitments for both payments and everything related to these payments. This obligation is binding in the EU institutions and therefore we cannot say at the moment that temporary difficulties mean that the tasks performed cannot be financed. They have to be financed. I fully agree with what my colleague Olbrycht said that it is a political decision. After all, this is actually 1% of the budget and this money is intended for investment in the field of cohesion policy for regional development as well. British colleagues are worried that these are taken from the regions, no, they are funded in the regions. They serve to improve infrastructure, they serve to create jobs. They also help small and medium-sized enterprises to develop. These are also opportunities to create jobs for young people, about which we were just talking about a few hours ago in this Chamber. Therefore, I believe that it is our duty to achieve a balance between commitments and payments.

name: Androulla Vassiliou
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, some Members have asked how we reached this situation. I think the reason for today’s situation is clear: starting from a few years ago, it is a result of budgetary negotiations which provided payment appropriations at such an artificially low level, so low that it prevented us from being able to pay legitimate bills. This must be stopped and it can be stopped, provided that the Commission proposals for the draft amending budget for 2014 and the draft budget for 2015 are adopted by the budgetary authority as proposed. What the Commission asked for is observance of the agreement on the Multiannual Financial Framework. That means the possibility to use payment appropriations at the level of agreed ceilings, and the possibility to make full use of flexibility mechanisms. If we do not stabilise the situation now in 2014 and 2015, then it is indeed going to be difficult to have a sustainable budget in later years. We cannot afford to kick the can down the road again and again. We cannot accumulate unpaid bills. This is why the Commission proposed the three draft amending budgets for 2014, including a contingency margin, and a draft budget for 2015 at the ceiling level. This is the call for today: to stop the snowball effect. The Commission is indeed concerned by the position that the Council is taking in relation to payments, but it hopes that negotiations will allow for common ground to be found, to provide the financial means to fulfil the Union’s legal obligations in 2014 and 2015. The Commission will continue to monitor closely the overall situation, and budget implementation, and will provide all necessary information to Parliament and the Council. It stands, of course, ready to participate actively in any interinstitutional meeting to take stock with a view to addressing outstanding needs. The Commission counts on the commitment of both the Council and Parliament to work constructively in a continuing dialogue on payments, with the objectives of addressing the 2014 payment shortages and avoiding the recurrence of artificial under-budgeting in 2015 and the following years. This is necessary. Otherwise, we put the credibility of the EU at risk, and we have to avoid that.

name: Della Vedova Benedetto
text: President-in-Office of the Council. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I have listened attentively to your speeches and I hope that a solution can be found, as intended by the Italian Presidency, avoiding a polarization of positions. Here we are not discussing the appropriateness or otherwise of the expenses that have been budgeted, and which naturally have a legal basis, we are discussing how to avoid a phenomenon that - it is true - in our country we have experienced and we have been vigorously trying to solve for some years , ie that of late payments. As stated in my introductory remarks, a different approach to managing the annual budget is in question. Creating margins below the budget ceilings does not mean that you are trying to avoid related expenses. I agree with the Commissioner that the new Multiannual Financial Framework provides us with room for maneuver and the tools to deal with unforeseen needs. However, these need to be managed in such a way that the request for payment appropriations does not contradict our excessive deficit procedures and related constraints. Proposals have also been made here in this regard. The Council is committed to the achievement of all policy objectives linked to the old and new programs of the Multiannual Financial Framework. This commitment includes the goal of reducing the famous snowball effect, which has also been referred to in this discussion, and of providing the financial resources necessary to pay our bills. In this context, we will start, as soon as possible, the examination of draft amending budgets nos. 3 and 4, subject to the adoption of the Council's position on the draft budget for 2015. The Italian Presidency accepts the invitation that has been made, that the start of these new five years be marked by a new spirit also with respect to the issue we faced today. Thanks for the attention.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The discussion is closed.Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Bas BELDER
text: written. - The European Commission is again asking for an increase in payments for this year by more than two billion euros. She says she does not have enough money to pay the expenses of final recipients of European subsidies. That argument is insufficiently convincing. There are also budget lines where not all of the money will be used. Every year the European Commission says that it has too little money to be able to meet its obligations towards subsidy recipients. Yet there was an amount of more than one billion euros left over from the 2013 implementation, which the European Commission transferred to the 2014 budget last April. So there is indeed money left that can be found within the other budget lines. The European Commission must thus compensate for shortages. Council, Parliament and Commission have a responsibility to make better budgets for next year, that is to say, make fewer new financial commitments for 2015! This breaks the pattern of taking on too many new commitments compared to the level of payment, which leads to an increase in payments throughout the year.

name: Claudia SCHMIDT
text: written.- If we do not get the problem of outstanding payments under control soon, important programs such as research projects and Erasmus + are in serious danger.Settling the outstanding bills is also a question of the EU's credibility: to watch others as guardian of national budgets, but to accumulate billions in outstanding debts yourself, is simply unacceptable.The Council must finally assume its responsibility here: you cannot make big promises to the citizens, but you can cut payments at the same time.But the Commission also has a duty: there is an urgent need for mechanisms to identify incorrect expenditure as early as possible.As soon as the Commission has ordered its own house and is fully operational again, this issue must be addressed as a priority!

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The next item is the debate on the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission and High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the situation in Iraq (2014/2716 (RSP)).

name: Benedetto DELLA VEDOVA
text: President-in-Office of the Council, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission and High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the situation in Iraq – as you know – is very serious. The conclusions of the Foreign Affairs Council in June expressed the Deep Concern of the European Union, condemning the attacks carried out by the Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant (ISIL). In Iraq, a Sunni rebellion has broken out not only by ISIL, but also by several other Sunni armed groups, including neo-Ba'thisti and tribal groups. ISIL, along with armed militants, now poses a more immediate threat in Iraq than in Syria. This organisation, with its foreign fighters swollen, poses a real risk to Iraq's neighbours, such as Lebanon and Jordan, and also to the European Union. The current deterioration in the security situation in Iraq stems from both internal and external factors. Without a doubt, the crisis in Syria has allowed ISIL to gain a base and a starting point in the region for the creation of the so-called "Islamic State" on Syrian and Iraqi territory.  However, the causes of the recent insurgency are not limited to the expression of a terrorist ideology. The motives of most armed militants are to be found in the discontent that the Sunni community has had for more than a decade with the Shiite-dominated Iraqi government. Among the reasons for discontent are the arbitrary application by the Government of Iraq of 'deba'thisation' policies, inertia in providing for the basic needs of Sunni communities and human rights violations perpetrated by the security forces. We have seen these problems exacerbate this year in the cities of Fallujah and Ramadi in Anbar province, where protests by the local Sunni population against government policies have resulted in violent clashes between Iraqi Shiite-dominated security forces and local tribes. This situation has provided ISIL with an opportunity to settle on the ground, as shown by the full-blown offensive conducted on Iraqi territory in June. The speed and effectiveness of that offensive has, however, taken the international community by surprise. All political and religious leaders in Iraq share a responsibility to address the underlying causes of these tensions. The Iraqi Government, in particular, is called upon to play a moderate role, avoiding excesses in both rhetoric and action. A tragic corollary of security conditions is the humanitarian aspects. Today, a total of two million Iraqis have been forced to flee their homes. The European Union has serious concerns about the development of this humanitarian crisis and the massive internal exodus of civilians fleeing the fighting.  The European Commission, through ECHO, has so far allocated EUR 12 million for humanitarian assistance actions. These funds are intended for Syrian refugees and Iraqi citizens displaced within their own country. Furthermore, the European Union is coordinating its actions with additional donors and international agencies, and I would like to commend the efforts that the European Union services and international agencies are making in very difficult local circumstances due to the dispersion of displaced persons throughout Iraqi territory. The EU keeps up to date on the situation, adapting relief actions to developments on the ground. Another consequence of the terrible crisis in Iraqi territory concerns the Kurdistan region. Iraqi Kurdistan has unilaterally announced in recent weeks that it intends to hold an independence referendum in the autumn. Let me stress that Iraqi Kurdistan is a model of stability throughout the region and has been an essential interlocutor of international actors, particularly in response to the humanitarian situation in Iraq. This cooperation deserves to be rewarded.  However, we believe that unilateral movements towards independence do not help to overcome the situation in Iraq and could risk being a problem for Kurdistan itself. We have called on all parties to seek a solution to this and other disputes in the Iraqi Constitution, which, if fully implemented, can provide answers to many of the Kurdish demands. The transition that began in Iraq more than a decade ago, which has always enjoyed the support of the European Union, is a difficult process. Despite the many setbacks over the years and although today the prospects of an Iraq finally routed on a path of peace and stability are under threat, recently there have also been positive signals. The elections of 30 April saw a turnout of 60% of those entitled, despite the difficult security conditions. The European Union has sent a mission of election experts to Iraq to monitor the electoral process and report on what has been observed. According to the experts' conclusions, despite some problems that should not be hidden, in particular the exclusion of a significant number of Sunni voters in Anbar province due to violence, the conduct of the elections was satisfactory. The turnout for these elections, which took place a few weeks before the Sunni insurgency, demonstrates the commitment of Iraqi citizens to democracy and unity in Iraq. In addition to security, the most immediate challenge in Iraq today is the ability of moderate political leaders to advance the political process. That is the message we have sent to those leaders in recent weeks. The early formation of a new government following the legislative elections on 30 April is a priority issue. The appointment of the President of the new Council of Representatives yesterday 15 July was a step in the right direction. A President of the Republic will now have to be appointed to allow a prime minister to be appointed and the government to be formed. The new government will have to seek dialogue with all the communities that make up Iraq, including the Sunni community currently excluded from the national political process that triggered the insurgency. Without an inclusive approach and effective dialogue, Iraqi society will not advance on the path to reconciliation.  As The High Representative/Vice-President Catherine Ashton has repeatedly said, the exit from the Iraqi crisis is primarily a political solution, which must also lay the foundations for a security response. On the other hand, excessively harsh security measures are likely to feed sectarian discord and cause further suffering to the Iraqi people. The European Union stands ready to intervene in any way deemed useful to facilitate political dialogue, complementing the actions taken by our international partners. Despite the seriousness of the situation on the ground, the European Union continues to provide assistance and support to Iraq wherever possible, in particular in the planning and implementation of development assistance. This is a sign of the European Union's continued commitment to Iraq and is part of a joint action to make Iraq more stable by promoting governance capacities and supporting the provision of basic services. This assistance will include further support for rule of law promotion measures to follow up the work of the EUJUST LEX mission. In the light of the new security situation in Iraq, EU experts are also considering possible ways of supporting counter-terrorism actions. However, the fight against terrorism in Iraq must respect the principles of human rights and international humanitarian law. The European Union rejects the view that human rights violations would be an inevitable or necessary price for security. The European Union is also working to promote cooperation between Member States on the problem of foreign fighters, at their own request. Finally, Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the EU remains committed to the Partnership and Cooperation Agreement with Iraq and will continue to stimulate such cooperation. In this respect, I would like to take this opportunity to call on those Member States that have not yet done so to complete the process of ratifying the agreement as soon as possible. Thank you for your attention.

name: Arnaud DANJEAN
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, waking up is very late and it is painful. It took this dazzling advance of the jihadists and the establishment of the Islamic State after the capture of Mosul, to take the measure of the political and military disaster in Iraq. So, of course, we can of course constantly recall - as a Frenchman, that's easy for me - the serious mistake that was committed in 2003 by the American invasion of Iraq. This is the historical aspect, however, it does not advance the debate much today, because a lot has happened since then. Since 2011, we have focused, more or less rightly, on the chaos in Syria and this has hidden the gravity of the situation in Iraq. It is very simplistic today - as we read or hear it too often, including in this assembly - to see the deterioration of the situation in Iraq only as the consequence of the civil war in Syria. Let us not forget that Faloudja was taken by these jihadists more than six months ago. Let us not forget that these jihadists, the Islamic army, has its deep roots in Iraq, that its leaders are mostly Iraqis. These jihadists thrive on the carelessness and sectarianism of the Iraqi government, which threw into the arms of these terrorist groups the Sunni tribes who had hardly rallied to the government in 2006-2007. They also thrive on the decomposition of an Iraqi army that has been equipped and supposedly trained at great expense for years and whose armaments, today, fuel terrorist stocks in the region and elsewhere. Europeans must therefore ask themselves today about support for the Iraqi authorities. This support should not be unconditional, but linked to governance that truly integrates all components of Iraqi society. Support must also go to solutions which defend the unity and territorial integrity of Iraq, not to its communal break-up. We must also question the more than ambiguous links - and I am polite - between radical Sunni groups and certain state and non-state actors in the Gulf, because these groups with which we have had a lot of leniency are today threats not only to the region but to our own security. Finally, let's not forget that the killing of the Jewish Museum in Brussels on May 24 was perpetrated by a French jihadist, Mehdi Nemmouche, who passed through the ranks of the Islamic State in Iraq and the Levant and I would like us to have a thought for the victims of this slaughter.

name: Ana GOMES
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Still barely recovering from decades of oppression and the illegal American invasion in 2003, Iraq has again regressed to unbearable levels of barbarity, with the advance from Syria at war by the ISIS terrorist forces that proclaimed the Islamic State of Iraq and the Get up and continue torturing, raping and killing civilians, destroying heritage and any sign of modernity. Other countries in the region, such as Lebanon and Jordan, are under threat from ISIS. The sectarian policies of the Government of Al-Maliki that contributed to the disintegration of national unity in Iraq by refusing to respond to the legitimate needs and complaints of the Sunni minority and other minorities and vulnerable groups, stoking inter-religious rivalries, to the extent that Christians have almost disappeared from the country. The bloody crackdown on protests by Sunni populations by the predominant Shiite armed forces in Anbar province illustrates the opportunities offered to ISIS terrorists to gain ground between the Tigris and the Euphrates, with the support of Sunni tribal leaders and former members of the Baath Party. Al-Maliki has lost credibility and support in the Shiite population itself, has to withdraw and make room for a new government of national unity, has to listen to the calls of the international community, without which Iraq will not design a path to security. All major international and regional actors, starting with the United States, Iran and the European Union, must focus on their shared interest in a stable, united and inclusive Iraq. The April 30 elections can produce a national salvation consensus that integrates, with a new government, all major ethnic groups and protects minorities and prioritizes national reconciliation and ensures basic services to a bloodless population. The European Union, for its part, cannot continue to divest politically in the region. It must mobilize to mediate conflicts in the Middle East and foster dialogue between all communities in Iraq, helping them to build governance capacities. It has to dialogue with Iran and Saudi Arabia, which are central players in stabilizing Iraq and ending the war in Syria, and it has to promote the resolution of the conflict between Shiites and Sunnis. Other strategic countries like Turkey must be involved in the process. And as pointed out, I agree with colleague Danjean, as pointed out in the European Parliament's resolution tomorrow, the European Union must warn the Gulf countries to refrain from continuing to sustain, directly or indirectly, the war economy of extremist groups. , sectarian and terrorists, such as ISIS and others. The European Union must direct humanitarian aid to the thousands of refugees and displaced persons and must use the European Union-Iraq Partnership and Cooperation Agreement to include cooperation in the fight against terrorism, ensuring that it is actually done in the respect for the principles of human rights and the rule of law. It is no wonder that all Iraqis seek refuge in the other Iraq, which works in the Kurdistan Region, which, despite the inherent serious deficit in fundamental rights and freedoms, has become an example of development, security and stability in the country. The recently announced initiative to organize a referendum on Kurdistan's independence is understandable, given the breakdown of power in Baghdad. However, the process of unilateral independence, although peaceful, will not contribute to the stabilization of Iraq and may endanger Kurdistan itself, given other acute sensitivities in the region. It is still possible to look for alternative, constitutional solutions for a Kurdistan that remains part of Iraq. Finally, Mr President, the war in Syria, the risk of terrorist disintegration and terrorist control in Iraq, make us have to make our citizens understand that European security is also at risk. There are thousands of European extraction jihadists fighting on the ground. We have to demand cooperation from our intelligence and security services to avoid the repetition of tragedies such as the one that has recently claimed innocent victims at the Jewish Museum in Brussels. (The speaker agreed to answer a question under the "blue card" procedure, pursuant to Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Aymeric CHAUPRADE
text: question "blue card".- Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I simply wanted to draw the attention of this Assembly to the paradoxes mentioned by Mrs Gomes and Mr Danjean who, on the one hand, mourn the consequences of the interventions in Iraq which have generated conflictscommunities between Shiites and Sunnis, but forget to recall that they supported a military intervention in Libya which produced exactly the same effects, with a complete tribalization of the country.So, you should be consistent with your analyzes.

name: Ana GOMES
text: answer "blue card".- You are not right, Mr. Chauprade, we must not compare the two situations even if there are common elements, indeed.I was in Libya during the war, in Benghazi, and I could see that the international intervention only supported the people of Libya who were fighting against an oppressor, a dictator that we did not know at home and withwhich some of us even did business.So it is absolutely not the same thing.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, Nouri al-Maliki has presided over a government since becoming Prime Minister in 2006 and has exploited sectarian religious tensions in Iraq to the benefit of the previously marginalised majority Shi’ite population under the Ba’athist regime. His regime, which has enjoyed a parliamentary majority since the 30 April elections, has been aided – unfortunately – and abetted by Iran as part of its own wider regional hegemonic aspirations.  As part of the al-Maliki sectarian approach, Sunni Arab tribes in Iraq’s west have faced discrimination and thousands of innocent civilians have been killed, particularly in Anbar province, in the name of prosecuting a war against terrorist jihadi elements linked to ISIS. In so doing, Baghdad has driven a desperate Arab Sunni community, including secular former supporters of Saddam Hussein, into an unholy alliance by teaming up with ISIS to fight government forces. Meanwhile, the autonomous region of Kurdistan has pursued its own destiny of democracy, secularism and prosperity. Thus we now have three increasingly divergent entities that are jeopardising the territorial integrity of Iraq and one that has offered fertile ground to jihadi terrorists spilling over from the conflict in neighbouring Syria.  ISIS, sadly, is now very well financed by Gulf States and it has captured oilfields and looted money from the central bank and is fully militarily equipped, but it must now be stopped in its tracks. It has now declared an Islamic caliphate and is imposing a barbaric form of extreme Sharia law on the local populations and minorities’ heritage, including Christians, and it is being joined by hundreds of EU, including United Kingdom, citizens as fighters who are being radicalised and brutalised by their experience and pose a serious security threat when returning to their home countries. Finding a solution to this cannot come too soon and we must now look to both international and regional forces that can offer some support. The brave Kurdish Peshmerga, i.e. the Kurdish army, has been very successful in wrestling control of the Kirkuk oilfields previously in the hands of ISIS and securing the Kurdish region’s immediate borders and protecting the Christian minorities of the Nineveh plains. Kurdistan has announced a referendum for independence unilaterally, which I think is very understandable and something that western powers after the First World War promised them in the Treaty of Sèvres in 1920 and may now soon become an inevitable reality. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: blue-card question. – When the UK Government and others took action to remove Saddam Hussein we were given confusing messages. First we were told that it was about weapons of mass destruction, then terrorism, and then that it was for the Iraqi people. Do you agree that this was badly thought out by the Blair administration, and do you further agree that military intervention should never take place unless there is a clearly defined military objective?

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: blue-card answer. – I would agree that the Blair government at the time was slightly economical with the truth and I would also agree that people such as myself who then supported the war might have taken a very different attitude if we had known then what we know now. But I agree that, frankly, the intervention in Iraq, which was well-meaning, which was meant to be humanitarian, but which was also in search of weapons of mass destruction, has resulted, I am afraid, a decade later in chaos and much unnecessary carnage.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: Mr Tannock, do you accept another question?

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: It is the first time in fifteen years that the Presidency has not said who this question comes from, because we need to know who is asking this.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: I advise you to look at the rules.Do you accept a question or not?

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: Mr President, I still believe, on a point of principle, that you are the first President who does not announce who is asking the question.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: Then he doesn't accept the question.

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, the events in Iraq and in fact the entire Middle East are very worrying but the situation does not come out of the blue. The Islamic State (IS) was able to grow in Syria’s war circumstances with the toxic help of certain Gulf State actors. The Islamic State grew in a climate of sectarian politics fed by respective Iraqi governments not doing justice to the pluralism of the country. The post-Iraq war instability and damage, and broader problems of a social, economic and political nature led into a very explosive scenario we are looking at now. Now the illegitimate claims of the caliphate by the Islamic State, mass executions and the imposition of Sharia law are against universal human rights and they must end now. But we must also be realistic about the Islamic State, not give it more weight than is proportionate. For the entire situation in Iraq we need a political situation and the sovereignty of Iraq should be respected. The call for independence of the Kurdish region is understandable but also potentially invites a more explosive situation that will benefit no one at this point. We know that IS has a number of European fighters and recruiters and the danger they will present too when they return to our societies should not be underestimated. We need cooperation between EU Member States and a clear strategy for safety and other appropriate measures and to prevent these misguided ideologies inviting people to participate in the violent jihad. We should also work together with Turkey, through which it is believed many people enter Syria and Iraq, and of course, for a more sustainable solution in the Middle East, there must be talks which also include the Islamic Republic of Iran and Saudi Arabia as they are using various proxies to defend or promote their respective dangerous interests in the region. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: blue-card question. – Thank you for having the courage to accept the question. I was very interested to hear what you had to say. Do you agree with me that the best way to stop further problems of this nature is to make sure that both the EU and the Member States no longer pursue interventionist foreign policies that damage countries in which they have no reason to be, and that the best thing is not to send our troops or people anywhere near these places unless there is a massively unforeseen reason for doing so?

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: blue-card answer. – I am afraid, dear colleague, that the world is not black and white and that there is no one-size-fits-all for Europe, which should act as a global player – as a strong global player in my opinion – to meet the various challenges whether they are violations of human rights or whether they are other crises that we see in the Middle East, particularly now, and I do think that the EU should show more of a leadership position through diplomatic efforts, through working with partners like Turkey to curb the spread of violent extremism or the recruitment in our own societies of people who go through Turkey into countries like Iraq and Syria. So there are many steps we can take before military intervention is needed but we all know, sadly, that the world sometimes requires not only soft power, but also hard power.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, lovers of impunity do not like memory, but we, who have memories, know that the current situation in Iraq is not a natural catastrophe. It has its antecedents in the Summit of the Azores, where, with lies and deceit, the door was opened to the first genocide of the 21st century. One and a half million dead has already been Iraq. At that meeting, Durão Barroso, former President of the European Commission, acted as butler. I don't want Durão Barroso to get revenge, but I do want international humanitarian law to reach him, for the Law to settle the alleged crimes of the promoters of this aggression and invasion. As a result of this intervention and occupation, we currently have a destroyed and destabilized country, divided into ethnic and sectarian quotas. The clear example is the current government, a government that uses a national army as a sectarian militia, as when it launched it against the protests of 2011. We must condemn all interference: distant, that of nearby countries, but also that of fundamentalist terrorism , which some support in Syria or Libya. The European Union has the opportunity to initiate a new foreign policy, promoting a conference within the framework of the United Nations, with the participation of the Arab and neighboring countries, so that the Iraqis will endow themselves with a new Constitution; all Iraqis, without ethnic or sectarian distinctions, so that everyone can decide their future, that of the country and that of its natural resources, which, I remember, belong only to them. Only then can peace be achieved. (He agreed to answer a question asked under the 'blue card' procedure (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Ana GOMES
text: blue card question.- Colleague Couso, since he invokes memory, why does he only go back to 2003, to a framework that I condemned in his day and that I also condemn today?Why not go further back to the time of Saddam Hussein?Or do you think that Saddam Hussein was a democrat and not a terrible oppressor of the Iraqi people who also has a lot to do with what is happening today, because of all the sectarianism and violence induced from within and not only from without?

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: "blue card" response.- Yes, your problem is that you have a very selective memory: I don't.My memory even goes to the imperialism of the British Empire and the division: the problems that that area has come from the colonial division, and what is happening now in Iraq is the result of 2003, but also the result of the above.I don't have that selective memory that you have to invoke Saddam Hussein now.We still have more than one hundred thousand compatriots lying in the gutters of my country.A relative of mine was killed in Iraq.We are not going to forget, even if you don't like it.

name: Alyn SMITH
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, like many colleagues I feel considerable emotion in any discussion about Iraq. I remember myself marching through the streets of Glasgow protesting ‘Not in my nameʼ in advance of the illegal invasion of Iraq by the coalition of the willing. This motion takes some account of the other lifetimes cut short or blighted since that deep act of folly. According to the UN there are just in central and northern Iraq 1.2 million internally displaced persons and 1.5 million persons in urgent need of humanitarian assistance. The scale of the tragedy is as paralysing as the complexity itself. But in our role as a European Union, as well as remembering how we got to where we are – and there should be no corner where we do not shine that light and no person we do not hold responsible for their actions – we have surely to try to attempt to plot a way out of the nightmare. In that effort I will limit myself to three points within this discussion: the role of the Kurds, the role of Iran and the role of Saudi Arabia and the Gulf States, though I do endorse the rest of the resolution, which I think has a lot to commend it and I commend the the spirit of cross-party working across this House in its production. On the role of the Kurds, in recital F we note the actions of the Kurdish regional government in taking control, as Mr Tannock drew our attention to, of additional territory and we stopped just short of criticism of those actions. I think that is the right form of words. I think that is as realistic as it is pragmatic. In recital G we acknowledge the limited success that the Kurds have had, and they do deserve credit for it in providing a safe haven and the burden that the many refugees they have cared for represents. But in point 11 of the resolution we remember our own principles. Any constitutional changes must, and I quote: ‘respect and uphold an inclusive process in respect of the rights of the non-Kurdish minorities living in the province’. This process will need to be supported by outside, by ourselves. On the role of Iran and Saudi Arabia and the Gulf States in points 8 and 9 we call – and I think this is quite crucial – on the international community, especially ourselves, to facilitate a regional dialogue on the problems facing the Middle East and to include all significant parties. Iraqʼs neighbours cannot be viewed as distinct from it; they are actors within the conflagration under way and must be part of its solution as well as part of its current problems. We cannot escape our role in how Iraq came to be where it is. We can shoulder our burden in helping them plot a way out of the nightmare.

name: James CARVER
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, Iraq bears the hallmarks and scars of the misguided intervention of Western nations. This has been nothing short of scandalous. With scant consideration for the obvious failings of the Sykes-Picot Agreement nearly 100 years ago, we poked this hornet’s nest with a very sharp stick before embarking on regime change. Most would agree that Saddam’s treatment of the Iraqi people, not least the Marsh Arabs and the Kurds, underlined his warped approach to humanity. However, I believe that the second Gulf War was fought on the premise of preparing for victory and not, as has now been proved, for life after that victory. Yes, the senior Ba’athist elements in Iraq had to be removed, but what followed was the greatest foreign policy failing of modern times, namely the US-led decision to dismantle the Iraqi army after the fall of Saddam. At the stroke of a pen, this Sunni-led army, with vast combat experience and access to an immense arsenal, was side-lined. In a short space of time, this led to the birth of the militias and the bloody insurgency. Those militias have now become the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria (ISIS) or their allies. The Iraqi Prime Minister, whose role is to unify Iraq, has achieved exactly the opposite. Nouri al-Maliki has shown himself to be completely unfit for purpose, underlining a terrible lack of character judgment on the part of Western leaders. As Iraq stands on the brink of splitting into three, al-Maliki still clearly ignores the Sunnis and the Kurds, so the world holds its breath and prays. The British Independent newspaper reports that around 1 500 British Muslims have fought alongside ISIS. EU open borders mean that terrorists can move into Europe and make their way to any part of the continent, potentially to wage terrorist campaigns. Late last year the UK Borders Agency complained that EU rules banned them from collecting data on travellers within the European Union, data which the intelligence services could have used to spot security risks. ISIS has looted USD 400 million from banks and financial institutions in northern Iraq, making them the world’s richest terrorist group. This conflict could destabilise the whole region and, by extension, the world. The threat of ISIS must be a stark warning to us all. When decisions are to be made, they must be made with as much input as possible from across the Middle East, via the United Nations and by the authority of the United Nations alone. Britain mistakenly went to war in Iraq, too, because of Tony Blair’s ‘dodgy dossier’, and the world has become a far more dangerous place as a result. One hundred and seventy-nine brave British service personnel made the ultimate sacrifice and many more have suffered both physical and mental scars which they will have to carry for the rest of their lives. I pay tribute to them now. Neither I nor my party want to see another single drop of British blood spilled in either Iraq or Syria.

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the astonishing rapidity with which this 15,000-strong army has conquered a large part of Iraq should put us all and all those concerned with concern about this situation, which is knocking on Europe's doors, several questions. Certainly it is a total failure of the Obamanian policy on terrorism, which has erroneously focused only on and neglected the enormous capacity and potential to grasp that the most extremist Islamic fundamentalism has now had over an infinite network of organizations that are difficult to control, at the within which there are also two-three thousand warriors of Allah born and residing in our Europe, who will most likely return to their homes, live among us, we will find them again and perhaps we already find them among us, ready to act in the way we have seen. This should make our wrists tremble. It should shake the wrists of this Europe which, however, in its answers proves to be what the great Italian writer Oriana Fallaci has well defined. We also cannot ignore the violent ex cathedra speech made by the "caliph" al-Baghdadi which represents the most frightening threat to Christian Europe. A black caliph who affirms that the fate of Syria and Iraq concern much more than just the Syrian and Iraqi peoples but all Muslims specifically referred to the religious duty of actively contributing to jihad and even with a religious reference to the conquest of Rome, evidently seen as also a geopolitical and geographical symbol of the Christian entity of the heirs of the crusades. A very precise signal that only a blind and cowardly Europe can pretend not to understand. A radical Islam that no longer places territorial limits on it but considers the whole world, and as far as we are concerned, our Europe, as a territory of conquest. How not to see, how not to react, how not to understand that we are facing a challenge of this kind.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: Mr President, Iraq faces an existential crisis and its integrity is clearly at stake. The question is how was it possible that some groups of terrorists were able to take control of large parts of such a country within a few weeks? I think the responsibility lies with the Iraqi Government too. In the past eight years the al-Maliki government has failed to form a coalition which would encompass all sectors of Iraqi society. Instead the Sunni community has been marginalised, the Kurds have been denied meaningful participation and there has been increasing reliance on Iran’s support. As a result al-Maliki’s government has crucially weakened its support in the north of the country and weakened also the motivation to oppose the terrorists. I think the key to the solution is to form a new government of national reconciliation which should extend the hand of cooperation to moderate Sunnis and also Kurdish leaders. The EU should use all available means and press the Iraqi political forces to achieve this end. We call also on the Commission to extend more humanitarian aid than the recently increased sum of EUR 12 million. There are almost 2 million internally displaced persons; a fresh wave of half a million refugees has left Mosul and 86% of them are in immediate need of housing and core relief items. The Kurdish authorities especially, who have to host the bulk of refugees, need assistance. Finally, I am very much worried about the fate and future of the Christian communities in Iraq whose numbers have decreased by two thirds in nine years. More than 300 000 have been left facing continued harassment and persecution. Actually it is the Christians who do not resort to violence; who are vital in restoring dialogue, building bridges and mediating conflicts, providing healthcare and education to all people in need. In fact they perform an integrating role in a sectarian society and it is in our common interest to help them. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: question "blue card".- Mr. Kelam, indeed, it is not only Sunnis and Shiites in Iraq, there are also Christians.Forgotten Christians.Christians today who have the choice of either dhimmitude or execution.Christians today who say nothing because they have no lobby to support them in Brussels.My question is very simple: do Christians still have the right to live in the Middle East today?

name: Tunne KELAM
text: blue-card answer. – Thank you for this question but this is also my question. I think we share this worry, and the fate of Christians in the Middle East has not been decided yet.

name: Richard HOWITT
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by expressing my own deep concern at the escalation of violence and the deterioration in the situation in Iraq. According to the United Nations OCHA there are an estimated 1.2 million internally displaced people in central and northern Iraq and we should place on record our welcome for the additional EUR 7 million that the Commission has allocated in humanitarian assistance.  Individual stories such as the brutal killing of 18-year-old Mahmoud Redha and his 44-year-old uncle Zainal by Islamic state fighters whilst on their way to work must bring home the level of violence faced by civilians on a daily basis. I join the President-in-office in calling for respect for human rights and for international humanitarian law by all sides. According to a report by Human Rights Watch on 12 July, the Iraqi security forces themselves appear to have unlawfully executed at least 255 prisoners over the past month in apparent revenge killings. These deaths must stop. Europe itself cannot advocate our agreement to promote democracy, human rights and good governance in Iraq and then fail to act when these objectives are put under grave threat, not least because of the real problems of foreign competence, as well as the threats posed by failed states within the region. Much time can be spent debating the cause of this crisis but what is certain is that the Sunni minority in Iraq have felt unrepresented. I hope today’s appointment of Salim al-Jabouri as the new Sunni Speaker of the Iraqi Parliament will help to address the disenfranchisement felt by Sunnis and to ease the tension. On the Kurdish issue we cannot fail to also draw attention to the tension between Baghdad and Erbil which worsened on 11 July when Kurdish ministers announced a boycott of the Iraqi Government after Prime Minister al-Maliki made comments that Kurdistan was harbouring terrorists and suspended flights to Erbil. The conflict in northern Iraq has led hundreds of thousands of civilians to flee to neighbouring Kurdish areas administered by the Kurdistan Regional Government, but recently the KRG has restricted access to the areas under its control to non-Kurdish Iraqis fleeing the violence. Within Amnesty International and as someone who has consistently acknowledged Kurdish political and civil rights, I call on the KRG to allow access to those fleeing the conflict and to engage in dialogue with the Iraqi Government. Moving forward, the Iraqi people in their millions chose their own leader in al-Maliki but the delay in forming a government has been a disaster and poses a real danger for the future of Iraq. It is right that Parliament now calls for the Iraqi Government to focus on unity and we urge all political leaders, especially the Prime Minister, to make sure that an inclusive government representing the diversity of the Iraqi population is formed as a factor of urgency.  Finally, noting the clear link between the rise of IS and the Syrian civil war, I call for the regional dialogue to address the problems facing the Middle East, including Iran and Saudi Arabia, and in those discussions to make a reality the EU’s offer of assistance to help promote democracy, human rights and the rule of law.

name: Bas BELDER
text: It is remarkable that the present resolution does not mention the role of candidate country Turkey in the turbulent developments in Iraq. In this regard, I would like to hear a response from the Council to the serious allegation that Turkey is co-financing the recently proclaimed caliphate of ISIS through the decline of its oil production. Even more serious I consider the capture by ISIS of the largest Iraqi chemical weapons repository in al-Muthanna on 12 June. Medics from Syrian Kurdistan today accuse ISIS of using chemical weapons against the Kurds. Is the Council aware of this appalling report and, if so, how does the Council assess this news? In any case, the present reports about remaining chemical arsenals in al-Muthanna (for example missiles with about 15,000 liters of sarin) are notably disturbing in ISIS hands. Are Brussels and Baghdad discussing this? Finally, I am grateful that the resolution before us calls for specific attention to the dramatically declining Christian minority in Iraq. I urge the EU to make every effort to ensure the continued presence of Christians in the Land of the Twins. I would therefore like to hear which European initiatives have already been taken or are in the pipeline for this. Actions, not words!

name: Javier NART
text: Madam President, we must ask ourselves why the Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant (ISIL) was able to conquer almost half of Iraq in days, as well as why the Taliban were able to eliminate the Mujahideen at a stroke. . That means having the support of the civilian population, whether we like it or not, and what this means is that we have a sectarian government, which is the Government of Nuri al-Maliki. Franklin Roosevelt, many years ago, said referring to Somoza, in Nicaragua: "yes, yes, I recognize that Somoza is a bastard, but he is our bastard." The problem we have is that the risk of balkanization in the area is of such a caliber that it can turn Iraq into a veritable labyrinth, like the entire Middle East. What we have to do is not look to the past and see the sins, which exist and which are true, but to the future and demand, not through a mere parliamentary question or a request for democracy, a national consensus. In Iraq, for God's sake, let's stop talking about democratic elections, which is an oxymoron, it is a contradiction in terms. What must be done in order to continue supporting the fiction that is the Government of Nuri al-Maliki is to demand that there be a national consensus.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: Madam President, like exactly forty years ago, in Indochina, we are living the epigones of brilliant American policy, this time in the Middle East. Of course, in speaking of brilliant politics, I express a bitter irony. This policy in the Middle East and the Near East consisted in methodically and fiercely destroying the only political force that was able to oppose the most radical and conquering Islamism, namely Arab nationalism. Everyone should remember the lies of the state, such as Iraq's alleged involvement in the September 11 attacks for which Iraq had no responsibility; like weapons of mass destruction. Mr. Danjean was right to say that memory was not enough, but memory is still useful in order not to reproduce the same errors, I would even say the same crimes. Everyone remembers the lies of Mr. Bush, Mr. Colin Powell waving in the UN gallery a vial supposed to contain a deadly chemical weapon and which, in reality, contained only colored water. Everyone remembers the judicial assassination of Saddam Hussein, who was undoubtedly not a democrat in the sense in which we understand it, but who was certainly the protector of the various communities, including Christians today in the process of disappearance . The result is the break-up of the country between Sunnis, Kurds, Shiites and the emergence of a force even more radical than Al-Qaeda, which we have seen that with a few thousand fighters, it rout the brilliant new Iraqi army, an army trained by the Americans. The paradox of history is that the only way there is, temporarily at least, to contain this is to rely on the Shiites and, therefore, to argue with the Iranians with whom Americans still do not want to discuss. It's a doodle policy.

name: Esther de LANGE
text: I am ashamed to conclude that it actually took another attack in our backyard to wake us up about what is happening in Iraq. An attack on the Jewish museum in Brussels. I therefore do not share the analysis of the High Representative, who said that the international community was very surprised at the developments in Iraq. Come on, we've seen it happen in recent years: the Christian minorities made up 5% of the population ten years ago, now 1%! Structurally bullied out of the country. Radicalized groups carried out attacks. It should come as no surprise what is happening now. But apparently that attack in Brussels was necessary to shake us up. I agree with you, the first response must be one of humanitarian aid. I too welcome - and we are doing it in the resolution - the extra five million that will bring the total aid this year to 12 million. Secondly, we as Europe must very quickly identify the security consequences of the radicalization in Syria, Iraq, and the actions of ISIS, and limit the risks. The responsible ministers made a start on this last week, but that start is far too casual. For example, a register must be established at Europol that structurally maps all returning Jihad fighters in Europe. That register should not be voluntary, but mandatory. So many further steps need to be taken there. Third, we must support the reasonable forces in that country. Constructive political parties, ethnic groups, but also rational religious communities. Take the Christians, about the only ones who don't want to divide the land. They are doctors, they have schools, they have hospitals. These are places where people from different backgrounds come together. If the country wants to have a chance, we must further encourage these kinds of meetings and also support them financially. In Northern Ireland, Europe has been doing that for years, supporting these kinds of meetings of the different communities. Please do that in Iraq too, if that country has a chance!

name: Gilles PARGNEAUX
text: Madam President, dear colleagues, there is absolute urgency in Iraq: violence, absolute religious rigor, religious intolerance.This is the reality that we know in almost 50% of Iraqi territory after the takeover of the Islamic State.We must certainly give our humanitarian and financial support to Iraq, but we must also have political courage.In addition, we need a diplomatic policy on the part of the European Union that is clear and clean.This political courage must enable us to say - and we must include it in our resolution - that a political solution must be found urgently so that a government of national unity, without the current Prime Minister,or a necessity to ensure the territorial integrity of the country.It is very important that this point be included in our resolution, because otherwise it is a bloodbath between Shiites and Sunnis, which we are unfortunately going to witness.

name: Geoffrey VAN ORDEN
text: Madam President, I wonder first of all what point there is in parliamentarians here spending time debating this topic when there is nothing new on the table to be discussed. The fact is that parliamentarians here are going to have little effect on the situation and the Commission is not even here to listen to what we have to say, and they, after all, have their hands on the money pot of humanitarian aid and all of those things.  We are discussing the situation at a time when Syria is still in flames, when Hamas is once again flexing its terrorist muscles from Gaza, terrorist anarchy reigns in Libya and Iran continues with its nuclear and missile programmes.  Of course it is very much in the interest of our democracies that peace, stability and security should reign in Iraq. We have spent massive sums, including a billion from the European Union, on Iraq but a quarter of Iraq’s population still lives on two dollars a day, or less. The water supply, sewerage systems, power systems are all broken in spite of enormous international spending. Of course we do not want to see the re-emergence of another terrorist host state in the region and now we have this murderous ISIS army threatening Baghdad itself.  The last international conference on Iraq was in 2003. Do you not think it is time for the United Nations to call a fresh conference in order to stabilise the political and economic situation in Iraq before it spirals out of control, and can we have a close look at what our money has been spent on?

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: Madam President, in Iraq there is, to begin with, a deep problem of social justice and freedoms that ruins the vital expectations of most Iraqis. Iraq today is a factory of despair that allows all kinds of extremism to flourish; the economic and strategic interests that are concentrated in the area do the rest, because they turn the region into a powder keg. The sectarian assassinations, the attacks, the fighting make it possible to present this crisis as a simple military and security issue, but it is much more; and only by applying comprehensive measures that address the root of the problem will there be solutions. Freedom, development, equality and the basic rights of the people are the most important, and the integrity of the States, especially when they do not offer these answers to their citizens, are empty words. For this reason, I agree with the need to promote and support a comprehensive solution - political, social and economic - to the problem of Iraq. I support the announcement by the Government of Kurdistan to hold an independence referendum with respect to minorities, as stated in the Resolution signed between the five groups. We hope - and I hope - that they will quickly form a stable government so that we can explore solutions on the basis of regional dialogue, and in the meantime we must continue to support them with diplomatic and humanitarian assistance.

name: Andrzej GRZYB
text: Madam President! The situation is serious, said the representative of the High Representative, saying that the Islamic state is the target of militants who are currently fighting for an Islamic state in Iraq and beyond. Additionally, human rights are violated. The humanitarian situation is even more difficult, and of course we should be concerned about this situation, because we had the last debate on Iraq in this House in February, in the previous term. It was then that I also spoke about the worsening internal situation and also about the threatened safety of people, and in particular minorities, including religious minorities, Christian minorities and all refugees. Since then, the situation has worsened many times. At the same time, relations between the central government and the Kurdish Autonomy were strained. This means that in a moment we can witness, perhaps not "de jure", but "de facto", the emergence of a new state, which will be Iraqi Kurdistan. Of course, we would not want that, so these calls to the Kurdish Autonomy to support this process of Iraq's rebirth are absolutely right. There are tensions between the Shi'ite majority, which has strong spiritual leadership, and the Sunni majority, which does not have such strong leadership. Of course, there is also a disproportion, disproportion in the population of these communities. There is precisely the real danger of a great crisis that could lead to a great confrontation. This is indicated, among others, by the Iraqi Christian bishops, who say that they are trying to be such a bridge between these two Islamic communities that it would not lead to a great humanitarian crisis, God forbid, to some genocide, because it is very real in this a tense place like Iraq.

name: Janusz ZEMKE
text: This discussion today is absolutely at a turning point for Iraq.Iraq is just falling apart.There is a tough tribal and religious war going on in it.On its territory, on the one hand, a Muslim caliphate is being created, and on the other hand - which is more and more visible - the Kurds create their own state.Despite all this drama, I believe that the Union should not intervene in these conflicts in a military way.Nor should it support either side of the conflict as far as military instruments are concerned.Instead, we should press much harder than before on the Iraqi authorities to build a new structure for this state.The point is that these state authorities should take into account not only the interests of Shiites, but also Sunni and Kurds.Then, I think, there would be a better chance of a peaceful resolution of this conflict.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: Madam President, the main problem in Iraq today is Prime Minster al-Maliki, who is acting as a dictator. He has created the current crisis through his repressive polices against the Iraqi people, especially against the Sunnis, as well as the Christians and the Kurds. The solution is therefore to remove al-Maliki, who has been a puppet of the Iranian regime, and to form a national unity government. We should stop Tehran’s interference, because the Iranian regime is the real source of problems in the whole region. I should emphasise that the majority of those involved in the Iraqi uprising are local tribes, young Sunnis and foreign military officers, and not the extremists of ISIS, as has been portrayed.
