We should support the Iraqi people’s demand for change and an inclusive government. If we allow al-Maliki to continue his repression it will only lead to more extremism in this country.

name: Francisco José MILLÁN MON
text: Madam President, Iraq is experiencing a very serious crisis, although the election, just yesterday, of the new President of the Council of Representatives is good news. However, as has been reiterated here this afternoon, we must not forget the serious risk of decomposition that the country is experiencing due to the armed intervention of the group called Islamic State and the territorial tensions of recent times. Finally yesterday, as I said before, the Council of Representatives reached an agreement to appoint a new President. It is a modest first step towards ending the impasse, the political blockade that Iraq has been experiencing since the April 30 elections. I hope that as soon as possible an inclusive, broad-based government, representative of the different communities of the country, will be formed. It is precisely this extreme political divide that it serves for those who want to destabilize Iraq and end the hope of peace and prosperity in the country. The European Union must continue to encourage a process of national political inclusiveness and continue to support the unity, territorial integrity and independence of Iraq, as expressed by the Council of Ministers precisely at its meeting on 23 June. We do not want the fragmentation of the country. The rise of that armed group called the Islamic State, and its implantation both in Syria and now in Iraq, threatens to exacerbate the decomposition of this country - and also of the region - in various territories controlled by different armed groups. And this group, the former EII, is not only a terrorist group, it is already a true terrorist army that poses a threat of a regional and global dimension. We must work with all the countries of the region to help support the internal stability and unity of the country. In addition, none of them should help the territories adjacent to the border between Iraq and Syria to become what Afghanistan was in the 1990s. Finally, President, I would like to highlight the difficult humanitarian crisis that the country is experiencing, in particular the tragic situation of the hundreds of thousands of civilians displaced by insecurity, and, among them - as my colleague Tunne Kelam pointed out earlier - the Christian community, which in recent years has drastically reduced its presence in Iraq. The European Union must continue that humanitarian aid. (He agreed to answer a question asked under the "blue card" procedure (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: blue card question.- Mr Millán, two very quick questions.The first, I would like to know what degree of responsibility you attribute to Mr. José María Aznar with respect to the current situation in Iraq. And, the second, does the Popular Party still think that the intervention in 2003 was the right decision?

name: Francisco José MILLÁN MON
text: "blue card" response.- Mr Urtasun, I believe that the causes of historical events are multiple: some remote and others closer.And I believe that the intervention in Iraq was based on premises, on data, which later unfortunately turned out to be inauthentic.

name: Demetris PAPADAKIS
text: Madam President, the situation in Iraq is not only dangerous but tragically dangerous. And it is not just about Iraq, it is about Syria, it is about Egypt, it is about Libya. It turns out that the policies pursued were completely wrong. It is no coincidence that only Tunisia has led to normalcy in the region. At the moment there is a regime of destabilization and unfortunately we see that the Arab Spring has turned into a deep Arab winter. We have had a lot more casualties lately and much worse forms of oppression and human rights abuses. The answer must be complete on the part of Europe. There must be a common European foreign policy, based on real facts and not on piety.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: Madam President, ISIL has declared a "Caliphate" - an Islamic state in half of Europe, and its "Caliph" has called for a crusade in the name of Islam. Radical Islamism today is the greatest political and military threat to Europe and our civilization. ISIL has declared jihad, a holy war, and the threat is serious. This will be a battle for values ​​- our values. Today, ISIL is targeting the Western Balkans due to the presence of large Muslim communities there. We live in peace with our Bulgarian Muslim brothers and we do not want ISIS terrorists to fly the flag of the Caliphate either on our territory or elsewhere in Europe. Last week, this flag was flown during clashes in Skopje, which we perceive as a threat to the life, health and rights of the huge Bulgarian community in Macedonia. ISIL is recruiting its fighters in Cardiff today. I am afraid that this is happening in other European countries as well. Separately, the horrific crimes against humanity committed by ISIL in Iraq and Syria will cause a new wave of refugees, which is an unbearable burden on the Bulgarian economy. I urge Parliament to adopt the resolution proposed by the EQF and signed by me. I urge the Commission and the Frontex Council to help Greece, Italy, Spain and Bulgaria deal with the new wave of refugees from Iraq and neighboring territories.

name: Lars ADAKTUSSON
text: Madam President! I would like to begin by expressing my support for the motion for a resolution that Parliament has to consider today. One of the places mentioned in the resolution is the Assyrian city of Karakosh, where the church bells rang for worship half a millennium before Christianity came to my country, Sweden. However, the sound of church bells in the city on June 25 this year signaled something completely different than worship. Now it was a desperate warning to the population and only a few days later the city was emptied of its population. The families and families who lived for generations in the city were forced to leave everything - to stay was not an option when the execution patrols from Isis advanced. In the neighboring city of Mosul, the church bells did not ring at all the following Sunday. For the first time in 1,600 years, no Sunday service was held in the city. Madam President, there are increasing reports of bloody suicide bombings against churches or Christians being murdered by fanatical jihadists. In the face of such a situation, the outside world cannot be passive. In the short term, Isis' progress must be stopped and a national unity government established. When an Iraqi delegation of church leaders visited us here in the European Parliament a week ago, they emphasized the importance of supporting democracy development and security. The EU and the EU Member States must assist here. The situation demands that we help each other across the party lines. The resolution we have to consider today is a step in the right direction, but condemnation in the European Parliament is not enough. The whole of the European Union, including the Council and the High Representative for Foreign Affairs, must now put this issue at the top of the agenda.

name: Eugen FREUND
text: Lawlessness and an incompetent, corrupt government with no respect for the rights of minorities; all this has led to the present situation in Iraq. It has been reported by The New York Times that the government of Prime Minister Nouri al-Maliki has harassed Sunni Arabs with baseless arrests, and for Sunni militants caught by the security forces summary execution has become increasingly common. For years, the international community has even half-heartedly put pressure on the Shi’ite-dominated government to be more inclusive, but to no avail.  There is, however, a sliver of hope that has been mentioned before with the announcement yesterday that a Sunni has been appointed Speaker of the Iraqi Parliament. This will probably do little to those Sunni fighters who have proclaimed an Islamic state within the state. We are now witnessing an attempt at re-drawing the map of the Middle East that could have a multitude of consequences. All will eventually spill into Europe. As usual, the United States, which is not of course altogether blameless for this situation, was the first to intervene. As with the conflict between Israel and the Palestinians, decisive diplomatic action by the European Union is urgently needed.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: Madam President!Iraq is on the brink of civil war and disintegration.ISIS, the bloody jihadist insurgency, is spreading its influence as far as Baghdad.The situation is exacerbated by the incompetent, nation-dividing government of Prime Minister Nuri al-Maliki.This situation causes unprecedented suffering for the civilian population, including Christians.Coordinated action by the international community is needed to support the political dialogue of all groups of Iraqi society leading to the formation of a government of national accord.Urgent humanitarian action is needed.

name: Mariya GABRIEL
text: Madam President, the situation in Iraq - I am not saying something new - is of particular concern. There is de facto occupation of part of Iraq's territory by a terrorist group. I will emphasize three points. Regarding the first point, I still believe that it is necessary to underline the responsibility for a political solution, which is that of the politicians, in particular those who were elected in April, to the House of Representatives. They must take responsibility for the future of this state and its citizens. It is clear today that Iraq cannot recover without a real political and interfaith dialogue. As for my second point, the European Union's commitment must continue to be that of providing assistance to more than 1 million displaced people and 1.5 million people in need of humanitarian aid. Today, this must be done in good coordination, in particular with the UN, but above all by ensuring the promotion of political dialogue in the region. Finally, I come to my third point on which I will insist the most. We must not limit ourselves to reacting only to the humanitarian situation. The regional dynamics of the situation in Iraq must receive our full attention. The expansionist agenda of the Islamic State terrorist group, if pursued and carried out, is a threat not only to Iraq, Syria, but also the entire region down to Jordan. We must also be fully aware of the regional conflict that awaits us, including the possible overlap of tensions between Shiites, Sunnis, Arabs and Kurds. Let us be well aware of the serious consequences that such a development of the situation would have in the region, at the gates of Europe. So today, it is more than necessary to act quickly through diplomatic efforts - why not a high-level conference - in order to avoid finding ourselves in a situation where we will have our feet and fists tied.

name: Kati PIRI
text: Developments in Iraq are very worrying and require an international approach. The ongoing violence has caused 1.2 million people to flee. A humanitarian crisis, which the EU cannot and should not look away from. The images we see of mass executions by the Jihadist movement Islamic State are terrible and the situation that has arisen is very dangerous for the entire region. It is therefore important that the Iraqi government, together with the various population groups, starts working on the national reconciliation agenda. A first positive step was taken by electing a Sunni as the new speaker of parliament. Finally, the crisis also directly affects the situation in European countries. The appeal of the Islamic state, including to young European Jihadists, appears to be increasing. Better European cooperation to combat radicalization and jointly keep a close eye on returning Jihad fighters is therefore crucial.

name: Ramona Nicole MĂNESCU
text: Madam President, we have recently witnessed a significant worsening of the situation in Iraq, with violent attacks on Iraqi citizens, refugees, dead and injured, victims of acts of terrorism. Unfortunately, the Iraqi government has proved unable to defend its own citizens against the terrorist offensive, so any support action that may come from external allies, whether we are talking about the European Union, the United States or Iraq's neighbors, will have real impact only if Iraqi leaders will be responsibly involved in the country's stabilization process. At this point, it is difficult to overlook the fact that the real problem is the central government, led by Prime Minister Maliki and backed by Tehran, which continues a disastrous policy of antagonizing various ethnic and religious groups, a policy that obviously leads to conflict. and violence. The European Union is determined to make a substantial contribution to the humanitarian effort, to support Iraq in democratizing and stabilizing the country; it is important to show solidarity with the people of Iraq and to support Iraq, without forgetting that history has shown us that military interventionism and not only has often caused more problems than it has solved. We are witnessing an important moment for Iraq and its queens, a time when Iraqi leaders need to understand the need to overcome the ethnic and religious differences that divide them and unite in a common effort for the future of Iraq. Only national unity can bring peace and stability, a government capable of bringing together Sunni and Shia leaders, leaders of all ethnic minorities, all Iraqis, who through dialogue can build a strong state in Iraq. Iraq now needs a new government, a government led by a new prime minister, and a government that truly represents the legitimate interests of all Iraqis, regardless of ethnicity or religion.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Madam President, allow me to bring something different but greatly related to our discussion. The alarming situation in Iraq and the Middle East would imply tremendous geopolitical changes including even changes to borders. The EU and the international community have been unable to engage in the wider region in a constructive manner. All these events could further hamper the European Union’s security in general and its energy security in particular.  It is high time the European Union’s energy supply was rethought. It is time to seek safer energy routes from stable countries and partners. I recall in this sense the vast energy forces in the eastern Mediterranean. Swift exploration of these resources would clearly benefit our continent and the EU could and should be at the forefront of this effort.

name: João FERREIRA
text: Eight years ago, Colonel Peters published a peculiar and somewhat strange map in the US military's magazine. It was called the map of the new Middle East and, looking back now on the years that have passed, events, even the most recent, take on particular meaning in the light of Colonel Peters's map. Balkanization is an old technique of imperial domination. The fragility of sovereign states, the division of peoples are its instruments, as well as the use of bands of criminal mercenaries. The army of the self-proclaimed Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant is fighting with weapons and with funding provided by NATO powers to the mercenary bands that have spread chaos in Syria. The ongoing fragmentation in the Middle East is aimed at all states that, in recent decades, have proved, in one way or another, obstacles to projects of imperialist domination in the region. Iraq, Syria and paving the way for Iran - a trail of millions of victims, of persistent humanitarian dramas. Chaos in Iraq, chaos in the Middle East are not by chance.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: I would also like to comment on this terrible situation, which is explosive in Iraq and in which we are witnessing gross human rights violations.In northern Iraq, a new state unit, the Caliphate, was formed, headed by the Caliph, which is governed by Sharia law and is actually governed by the hateful killing of the so-calledunbelievers.It is shocking to me that - and these are two facts that he first began to kill his own, I would say, the brothers of Muhammadans, but they are of a different faith: some are Sunni, others are Shiite and do not hate each other.But it is very alarming that this situation is also attacking the position of Christians who have lived in the region and in Iraq for more than 1700 years and do not want to go anywhere.And it is our duty, both the European Union and this Parliament, to stand up and effectively help Christians living on the ground.And it is scandalous that the Council is here with us, but the Commission has ignored this negotiation.

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: Madam President, I just wish to urge great caution. I know the first instinct of this place is to interfere, to try to do things and often for the good, I understand that, but for many decades the situation in the Middle East has been made worse and worse by Western interference and involvement. My own country was brought into great shame by the dreadful lies of Tony Blair who brought our great country into disrepute with his evil lies. He has blood on his hands and he is one of the main reasons for the situation we find ourselves in now.  Please learn from this; learn that we cannot cure all the world’s ills. We cannot be the world’s police. Yes, let us help; let us aid where we can. But please, in the interests of peace, do not always seek to interfere; always seek to put your hand in. Sometimes it is better to respect national independence and let the people there make their own choices.

name: Georgios KYRTSOS
text: Madam President, I think Iraq is in the final stages of disintegration. And a huge distance has been covered (in the negative sense of the word). Let us remember that there was an ambition for the so-called "Nation building", that is, to create a modern democracy there, and now we have a bloody chaos. I believe that if we had more Europe, fewer mistakes would have been made in the case of Iraq. If we did not hesitate to have a common foreign policy, if we did not hesitate to have a common defense policy, we would have interventions in the right direction. We are afraid of the cost, but in the end we can not avoid it, because the collapse of Iraq can lead to an energy crisis that will have huge costs, it can lead to the strengthening of Iran and the escalation of the confrontation with Israel, which will also has consequences, it can lead to a new wave of refugees that will be extremely costly, it can even lead to the strengthening of fanatical Islamists and the destabilization of governments in the Arab world. So whatever we do, we have an account in front of us: more Europe is the most economical perspective.

name: Emmanouil GLEZOS
text: Madam President, 71 years ago the so-called "big" three, Roosevelt, Churchill and Stalin, met in Yalta and announced, expressing the wishes of the people, that after the end of the war, colonialism would be abolished, and there would be self-determination. respect for minorities, protection of individual rights. Let's not ostrich. Today these announcements of the three do not really exist. There is a problem of self-determination of peoples, there is a problem of self-determination of the Kurds, there is Ireland that has not gained its full independence, there are the Basques, there are the Catalans, there are the Northern Epirotes. Will we finally face the problems? Yes or No;

name: Benedetto DELLA VEDOVA
text: President-in-Office of the Council, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission and High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I thank all the Members who have spoken for the frank and thorough discussion that has taken place. The European Union pays the attention that I believe you have rightly requested to this issue. Iraq was discussed in the Foreign Affairs Council on 24 June, with a conclusion, and a new discussion on the issue of Iraq is planned for next week in the Foreign Affairs Council on 22 July. Among the issues that you have raised, which I believe are of common commitment, is that of the unity and territorial integrity of Iraq as essential elements for building a prosperity that benefits all citizens and promoting stability in Iraq. region. The gravity and drama of the situation do not escape anyone, of course. In the initial interventions of Mr Arnaud and Mr Gomez there are the reference to the idea of ​​a bound support and the point of an inclusive and unitary governance within this Constitution or in any case a governance that allows to resume the ranks of a transition towards democracy. The theme of human rights, referred to in several interventions, is a theme that historically, but also in this case, is at heart in the attention of the European Union, including the point recalled by several interventions on the freedom of the Christian faithful in the area. . This is also why we need a new inclusive and legitimate Iraqi government and we as the European Union are moving on this issue and on this level. I also wanted to respond to two specific requests that have been made regarding the issue of chemical weapons. Intelligence sources confirm that these are not usable weapons. The situation is certainly disturbing in the current chaos, but it is also necessary to stick to the known facts. As for the allegations that have been raised against Turkey as a country for ISIL funding, we believe that a clear distinction and distinction must necessarily be maintained between suspicions, rumors and facts and between funding that may have come from radical private sources. and the government, in this case of Turkey. It is a distinction that must be clearly maintained. The European Union is working with the Gulf countries to identify and block the sources of funding for ISIL and other terrorist groups. In conclusion, I would like to express my appreciation, I believe also shared by you, for the excellent work done by our delegation in Baghdad. Our colleagues in Iraq continue to render valuable service under extremely difficult conditions.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: Motions for resolutions to be tabled in accordance with Rule 123 (2) of the Rules of Procedure will be announced at a later date.The debate is closed.The vote will take place this Thursday, July 17, 2014, at 11 a.m.Written statements (Rule 162 (12) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: written. - There have been around 500,000 deaths in Iraq since 2003 - that is more than France had to complain about in World War II. The US has wreaked havoc in the region. The Assad opposition was supported at all costs and despite all warnings - unofficially also through weapons and training. Now the weapons are in the hands of an "ISIS". You really have to ask yourself now: Is this all on purpose? 1. Provoke a civil war, 2. Solve the problem with military invasion and bring democracy with bombs. 3. Justify the continued military presence there. Once again, the arsonist calls the fire department himself - and offers himself to do so again. And so can be earned in multiple ways with the war: arms sales to everyone and manipulation of oil prices through induced crises. Apparently it's all about resources. Terror is supported and financed in order to ostracize and fight against it - and to curtail our civil rights.

name: Emil RADEV
text: In written form. - For the past five years, Iraq has seemed to be emerging from the spiral of violence and instability and moving towards a fragile but nascent democracy. Unfortunately, however, the ongoing war in Syria, poverty and the existing religious and ethnic divisions in Iraqi society have quickly led to a new civil war. What is happening in Iraq shows that no conflict is encapsulated within a country. It also proves the maxim that no leader can govern stably without broad public support. Last but not least, Europe has a moral obligation to continue to support Iraqi society. The main conclusion is that peace in Iraq inevitably goes through peace in Syria. I therefore call on the EU, in close cooperation with the international community and especially the Arab states, to work actively to end the violence in Syria. European support for the Iraqi security forces must also continue in order to ensure stability in the country. At the same time, the Iraqi government must unite, not divide, society. I am not saying that these are easily achievable goals, but they are necessary so that Iraq does not fall into constant chaos and, above all, so that the future of generations of Iraqis is not stolen.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing.- Balkanization is an old technique of imperial domination.The fragility of sovereign states and the division of peoples are its instruments, as well as the use of bands of criminal mercenaries.The army of the self-proclaimed Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant is fighting with arms and funding provided by NATO powers to the mercenary bands that have wreaked havoc in Syria.The chaos in Iraq, the chaos in the Middle East is not a matter of chance, but the result of the destabilization and interference operations carried out by NATO, the USA and the EU.These are the most responsible.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The agenda calls for the debate on the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission and High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the escalation of violence between Israel and Palestine (2014 /2723 (RSP)).

name: Benedetto DELLA VEDOVA
text: President-in-Office of the Council, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission and High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, on 8 July Israel launched Operation Protective Edge in the Gaza Strip. The Israeli reaction followed intensified rocket fire from Gaza, in turn in reaction to the Israeli "Brother's Keeper" operation to find the killers of three Israeli teenagers kidnapped in the preceding weeks. Operation "Protective Edge" has already caused the deaths of over 213 Palestinians, mostly civilians, and more than 1,400 injured, victims of hundreds of Israeli air strikes and bombings on the Gaza Strip and the launch of hundreds of rockets from Gaza to Israel. Thousands of Gaza residents have been displaced and more than 40,000 Israeli Ground Forces soldiers along the Israeli-Gaza border have been mobilized. The humanitarian situation in Gaza, already very serious before these last hostilities, is deteriorating by the hour. The UN has launched an appeal for a "humanitarian pause" in the clashes to allow the population in need of relief to be reached. The European Union and all the other leading figures in the international community, including the UN and the United States, have intervened to deplore this spiral of violence. The EU expressed its extreme concern at the rapid deterioration of the situation and strongly condemned the indiscriminate firing of rockets at Israel by militant groups in the Gaza Strip. The European Union deplores the growing number of civilian victims of the Israeli operation, stressing the fundamental importance of the safety and security of all civilians in Palestine as well as in Israel. We strongly urge all parties to exercise the utmost restraint to avoid further victims and restore calm. We urge the neighboring countries to make every effort to bring about an immediate cessation of hostilities. Hamas has not accepted Egypt's proposal for a ceasefire, but if there is still a chance to agree on a truce, the opportunity must not be lost. High Representative / Vice-President Catherine Ashton from Vienna, where she is leading the Iranian nuclear negotiations, is in constant contact with the parties and encourages a ceasefire. The Italian Foreign Minister and the German Foreign Minister are in the territories between Israel and Palestine in these days. In her numerous contacts with Secretary of State John Kerry and her European counterparts, Catherine Ashton has sought to ensure that the international community, with the European Union first, takes care of the immediate needs of the people of Gaza. In this extremely worrying context, we continue to think that direct and substantial peace negotiations between Israelis and Palestinians are more necessary than ever to find a lasting solution to the conflict. All claims must be stopped and Israel's legitimate security concerns, as well as the situation in Gaza, must be taken into account. As part of this process, which we hope will resume soon, it will be important not to lose sight of the fundamental issues and factors behind the recent failure of the US-backed peace talks and the recent spate of violence. Let's say it as it is: the unwillingness to make the difficult choices necessary to achieve peace is the cause of the failure of the last round of negotiations which, in turn, has created the void now filled by the violence we are witnessing. As if that were not enough, recent events coincide with dangerous developments across the Middle East - we were discussing them until a few minutes ago - which pose serious threats both to the European Union and to its direct partners and neighbors in the region. The EU is convinced that the deterioration of the regional context makes a solution to the conflict based on the coexistence of two states more necessary than ever. The EU also believes that the only way to stem the violence and resolve the conflict is an agreement that ends the occupation that began in 1967 and that matches the aspirations of both sides. A reality based on a single state would be incompatible with these aspirations. Madam President, honorable Members, Israeli and Palestinian leaders must be persuaded to take the bold and courageous decisions needed to end the current spiral of violence and resume negotiations. Rest assured that the European Union will do everything it can to help achieve this goal. Thanks for your attention.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: I think we can ask you to sit down from now on (addressing the members of the GUE / NGL group who remained standing displaying a Palestinian flag throughout Mr Della Vedova's intervention).

name: Geoffrey VAN ORDEN
text: Madam President, in the House of Commons in London, the Speaker of the House has no hesitation in interrupting the Prime Minister on a point of order or when he wants to call order in the House. I see no reason whatsoever why you should not interrupt the Council when they are speaking when there is a blatant disregard for the dignity of this House, with people standing up making demonstrations of this nature, and it should be stopped. I think there is something that is particularly absurd about a group of Communists complaining about occupation and military aggression in any context.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: It didn't seem to me that order was disturbed by this protest, but now these people are seated.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Madam President, as you know, our group had some reservations about having a resolution today to accompany the debate organized now. It seemed to us difficult to come up with a short and clear text which brought together all the political groups. Finally, we have a text and even if, in the end, only the group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats), ECR, S & amp; D and the ALDE group will support the common text, for having participated in the negotiations, I can see that there is still a broad enough agreement on the ideas of force to react to the escalation of violence between Israel and Palestine. For the group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats), it is important to recall what brought us to the present crisis, namely the kidnapping and brutal murder of three young Israelis, on June 12, followed by the death of a young Palestinian on July 2. We can, of course, only condemn in the strongest terms these revolting acts and express our compassion with the families of the victims. Likewise, we are all extremely concerned about the renewed violence that has followed. We call for an immediate end to the attacks that are causing all this suffering. This implies that Hamas ceases its rocket fire at Israel from the Gaza Strip. As we have said several times in the past, Israel has the right to defend itself against attacks that indiscriminately target civilians. All parties must fully respect international humanitarian law. The only way out of the present crisis is obviously not violence and we support all diplomatic initiatives aimed at achieving a de-escalation of the conflict through a ceasefire. From this perspective, the Egyptian initiative presented on July 14 is welcome and represents a step in the right direction. And taking note of the acceptance of this proposal by Israel, we must insist that Hamas accept a cessation of hostilities. Finally, I would like to say that, despite our differences, we are all united by a common goal, that of ensuring peace and security for Israelis and Palestinians. The goal we all share is to achieve a negotiated settlement on the basis of the two-state solution. For that, we need credible efforts on both sides with increased support from the European Union to lead to the resumption of negotiations for a just and lasting peace in the Middle East.

name: Victor BOŞTINARU
text: au nom du groupe S&D. – Madame la Présidente, je veux saluer la contribution de la part du Conseil et vous demande l'autorisation de poursuivre en anglais. I reiterate today the serious concern of my group about the new escalating violence between Israel and Hamas and the rising number of Palestinian and Israeli civilians wounded in the huge logistic centres which have been destroyed due to the attacks. Yes, we strongly call for all further targeting of civilian populations to be avoided and for an immediate ceasefire followed by negotiations. The death of children and innocents is simply unacceptable to each and every one of us. The United Nations Relief and Works Agency (UNRWA) informs us that 55 installations have been damaged since 1 June 2014. In just the past 24 hours, six UNRWA installations were damaged, five schools in Rafah in the southern Gaza Strip, and one health centre in the middle area of Gaza. In this incredible context rockets are probably still targeting Israel today in an indiscriminate manner and air strikes continuing to hit different locations in the Gaza Strip, and the main and the most devastating question is: how could or should this round of violation be stopped? I do not believe that this war is serving either the Israelis or the Palestinians but it can serve Hamas groups and all other radicals who are fighting to recover their full influence over the Gaza Strip. I also believe in the Israeli Government’s sincere desire for de-escalation and ceasefire, and for starting the peace negotiations, as they demonstrated yesterday by accepting the ceasefire proposed by Egypt. The region is extremely unstable today and confronted with serious unrest. The crisis between Israel and Gaza is the last thing we need and the most dangerous as it could inflame the whole region in a dramatic context. The repercussions on the Palestinian territories and in southern Jerusalem, but also in the neighbouring countries, are of serious concern. This is why our role, our European Union’s role, which should be constant and strong, lies in mediating and calming the tension. Unrest in the Middle East has lasted for too long and it is time to end it right now. But the European voice is still too shy and too ineffective ... (The President cut off the speaker) (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Molly SCOTT CATO
text: blue-card question. – I share Mr Boştinaru’s horror about the increase in levels of violence in Israel and Palestine but I am aware of the fact that during the negotiations over which resolution was going to be taken tomorrow he was not prepared to support a much stronger Green resolution which specifically identified the failings of the Quartet process and the failings of its envoy, Tony Blair. Can I ask Mr Boştinaru whether he thinks the Quartet process is working well and does he think that Tony Blair is a successful and effective peace envoy?

name: Victor BOŞTINARU
text: blue-card answer. – The answer is evident. It is not functioning well because peace is missing, and this is why I reiterate the need for the European Union to be an effective, visible and consistent contributor to the peace process and not to assist the process as done by others. It is our fundamental role, an imperative of ours nowadays, to be a broker of peace in the Middle East. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Margrete AUKEN
text: blue-card question. – Just to ask, Victor, why are none of the figures included in your resolution? Why do you not mention the huge numbers of civilians killed on the Gaza side, with one-third at least children? Is it because you do not think there is an imbalance here? Do you think these are equal partners? To me, not having these figures in the resolution is very cynical. You did not accept them from our resolution and I think it is important to show that we are not dealing with equal partners in a war here, we are dealing with an enormously strong occupying military power, and a besieged civilian population.

name: Victor BOŞTINARU
text: blue-card answer. – A resolution is good if it can get a majority and is adoptable, and to be adopted we need a majority. This is why we negotiated and this is therefore why the four largest political groups in this House have joined together in a well-balanced, moderate resolution contributing not to inflame but to de-escalate the tension. This is the purpose of our common work. I welcome very much the likelihood that the four major political groups have succeeded in backing a resolution which is to be adopted tomorrow. This is why I welcome very much the contribution of all groups, including the four I mentioned before.

name: Bas BELDER
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Last Saturday I read in the Neue Zürcher Zeitung a worthy commentary on the latest escalation of violence between Hamas and Israel. I quote: "Hamas acts autonomously despite the so-called Palestinian unity government. In order to achieve its political goals, it does not shy away from targeting the people of Gaza." In short, Hamas is terrorizing the Palestinian citizens of the Gaza Strip with its persistent missiles on the state of Israel and its citizens. It is not without reason that Hamas appears on the European list of terrorist organizations. Meanwhile, insiders estimate that Hamas still has some 6,000 to 7,000 missiles. Enough to continue the fight against Israel for weeks. Which brings me to the crucial question of who is actually the supplier of Hamas's advanced missile arsenal and Palestinian Islamic Jihad. The answer is simple: the Islamic Republic of Iran. Council, you, High Representative, were recently at the negotiating table with Tehran. Mind you, without Iran's funding, armaments and training, the current terrorist threat from Hamas, Islamic Jihad and Hezbollah in the Middle East would not be possible. What horrors await the region if you, on behalf of the international community, do not clearly stop Iranian support for terrorist organizations in the region! A country that supports such organizations financially and materially cannot credibly claim to only have a civil nuclear program. The Middle East is already on fire! With Israel in immediate danger. I therefore call on the Council not to budge an inch in talks about Iran's nuclear program. Does the EU want to help extinguish the Middle East with the arsonists, Iran and Hamas?

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Innocent people are dying again in Gaza and Israel. Those who think that their death benefits their things, diametrically opposed to the other side's things, also die. Once again, we in the European Parliament have drafted a resolution that we want to see as politically correct, well-intentioned and balanced in Israel and on the Palestinian side. As a contribution to the search for a solution to a protracted conflict that not only burdens two nations entangled in conflict, but repeatedly represents a hotbed of conflict that has much broader dimensions. The fact that we have some wars and sites of major humanitarian catastrophes in the same region in the Middle East today in no way diminishes the drama of the latest developments around Gaza. It is clear that we cannot remain silent in the European Union and its Parliament over the events in Gaza and Israel. It is necessary to condemn without any hesitation the horrific crime, the murder of three young Israelis, which was the direct reason for the retaliatory action of the Israeli army. Even the response in the form of the murder of a young Palestinian was no less a reprehensible crime, a continuation of a story of violence that repeatedly replaces faith in peace and the peaceful settlement of conflicts. We cannot come to terms with a situation where incidents and attempts to resolve tensions follow one another in a constant, sinister sequence. It cannot be overlooked that the tension and violence are due to the fact that the Middle East peace process has not been moving from a stalemate for years and that a situation is being created in the Palestinian territories that always prevents the only possible solution to the Israeli-Palestinian problem. , who would live in peace and mutual recognition. Neither Hamas terrorist attacks, nor military evidence by Israeli forces, nor the permanent siege of Gaza, nor the occupation of the West Bank on the road to peace are acceptable.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, Gaza is once again at crisis point. Millions worldwide are protesting against the slaughter taking place there. Unfortunately, this joint resolution is a woeful attempt to address the reality of the current conflict. It neutralises the onslaught to avoid criticising Israel. The PPE and S&D cosy consensus is disgraceful. Over 200 Palestinians are dead. 1 250 have been injured, 17 000 have sought refuge, 1 300 buildings – including hospitals, homes and schools – have been destroyed by Israeli bombs, and it continues. This is an appalling carnage. Attacks from both sides should stop. The causes of the conflict are ignored in this joint sham resolution. Israel’s collective punishment of Palestinians in the aftermath of the murder of three young Israeli boys, which we all deplore, is not mentioned. The arrests of hundreds of Palestinians, which contributed towards tension in the region, are not mentioned. Israel’s violation of international humanitarian law, with the expansion of settlements and the construction of apartheid walls and roads are not mentioned. Israel must end – and we must end – the impunity over such gross violations. Israel must lift the blockade on Gaza and stop the slaughter. This Parliament must show it cares, and it would befit the MEP who complained about us standing along with millions worldwide who are protesting to also show that he cares. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: blue-card question. – Ms Anderson, you are a well-known apologist for Hamas, but would you not accept that Israel has the right to defend itself militarily against rocket attacks, even by military means if necessary? Would you not also accept that Hamas and Islamic Jihad are in fact committing international war crimes by hiding their weapons and launching their missiles from civilian areas including mosques, hospitals and schools?

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: blue-card answer. – The corollary of what you are saying must be that you would agree that when Israel is attacking Gaza, then Gaza has a right to respond. Let us be clear about this: Israel violates international human rights and humanitarian law. The UN Charter has also been violated. Also, it does not deal in the fourth Geneva Convention. There is a list – and it is endless – of points on which it has been criticised for its abuses and violation of international and humanitarian law. The millions of people who are standing in protest are concerned about what is happening in Palestine and Gaza. You should be more concerned about that. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: question asked by picking up a blue card.- Madam President!I would like to ask Mrs Anderson if you think we should adopt this resolution?If so, are you aware that being too far ahead in the demands will lead to its non-adoption, and after this criticism, could you name at least 3-4 advantages of this motion for a resolution tabled?

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: blue-card answer. – I was in the negotiation yesterday, and I have to say that the PPE and the S&D did not even try to negotiate with those of us who wanted a stronger resolution. The cosy consensus in this Parliament between the PPE and the S&D is not what the voters voted for. I think that it is absolutely disgraceful how those negotiations were conducted yesterday and I can tell you, as someone who was sitting there, that the views of the millions who are protesting were totally disregarded.

name: Tamás MESZERICS
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, it is certainly not easy to formulate a statement on the tragic situation in Gaza that is simultaneously meaningful and helpful to the victims and vulnerable populations, and might also, hopefully, have an impact on the entire crisis. As a first-time Member, and like many of my fellow Members I presume, I came here with a certain level of idealism in the sense of believing that benevolent intentions and political wisdom may be able to produce such statements or resolutions and that action may result from them. I am afraid the joint resolution is not such a text, and I regret to say that I was present at the negotiations yesterday. I may be a bit of an idealist but at the same time I am not naive. I know that in cases of escalating violence you had better tread very lightly in order not to exacerbate the situation. That is true. But, in this case, walking on tiptoes resulted in an empty resolution text: that is the considered view of my group and it is also my view. I do not call into question the motives of the major parties in trying to write a brief text focusing on de-escalation, and trying to strike a balance and to make the possibilities of de-escalation at least meaningful, but the excessive pruning eliminated almost all content. We regret to say that we cannot vote for an empty shell of a resolution. First of all, the text fails to mention almost anything related to the EU. Whenever the EU appears in this text, it appears tangentially. If we agree that the EU should play an influential role in the region and all its adjacent regions, then this text gets dangerously close to an abdication of responsibility. We tried to rectify that with an amendment that we tabled to paragraph 6. Secondly, the text fails to mention a number of facts that my colleague has already listed. These facts are inconvenient, I know, but I am sure I speak for my group, as well as myself, when I say I consider myself a friend of Israel and also a friend of Palestine, and it is a duty of friends to call attention to inconvenient facts.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we in the 5 Star Movement are not here to blindly support a faction or to put a label on our chest for interest. We stand solely for two peoples, the Palestinian and the Israeli, who both claim the right to existence and a normal life for their children. We stand up in defense of innocent civilians, of the weakest who too often have the sole fault of having inherited a painful history, of living near a disputed border, of crossing the wrong road at the wrong time. We still take sides with those who believe that the atrocious crimes committed on four boys - Eyal, Gilad, Naftali and Mohammed - demand justice and not infinite and useless revenge. An eye for an eye and the whole world goes blind. Wise words, words of an enlightened man, words of Mahatma Gandhi. While I am speaking to you, the bombing continues on one side and the launching of missiles on the other. The actions of a few extremists are paid for with the desperation of entire families. It is useless to hold trials, but the disproportion of the forces involved is evident. More than 200 dead and over 1,400 injured, including women, disabled people and children. Four children died because they played soccer. Some bombs call them smart but they certainly feel no mercy. The Gaza Strip is left to itself. The risk of a humanitarian drama for nearly two million people is just around the corner again. Its inhabitants now depend almost exclusively on UN aid for food and medicine. Tens of thousands of displaced people are fleeing aimlessly because the crossings to Egypt are open only for the most seriously injured. We could turn our gaze elsewhere, make assessments of mere political opportunity, think that the Mediterranean, the sea that surrounds my country, is enough to separate us from those unfortunate lands. But if the European Union aspires to be a global player on the international stage, then this is precisely the occasion to demonstrate that with a single voice it can and wants to live up to its ambitions, because the Mediterranean is not the moat of a medieval castle, but a bridge between civilizations for millennia. I therefore ask you to use all our courage to prevent the negotiation agenda from being dictated by opposing extremisms, because the only extremism we can accept is that of dialogue at all costs, that of peace based on equal rights and equal dignity. . Finding an agreement between the parties, starting with the Egyptian proposal for a lasting truce, and then helping to design a future in which two free peoples of two independent states will finally coexist in harmony. These, in my opinion, should be our two objectives, as a Parliament that has the burden of representing democracy in Europe. This is what millions of people around the world expect of us, that we can for once put aside the reason of state and embrace the state of reason with conviction. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Rule 162 (2)))

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: blue card question.- Mr Castaldo, you well know that I share your point of view in some of your speeches, but in this case, even assuming the good intentions of your words, don't you think that equidistance, when it comes to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict,Are you giving away a situation of injustice to the State of Israel against the weak, which, in this case, are the Palestinians?

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Answer to a “blue card” question.- Thank you colleague Iglesias.What I can answer is that it seems to me that I have pointed out several times in my speech that I believe there is certainly a disproportion.To be legitimate, a defense must also be proportionate and we are also afraid that at this moment there is a risk that the proportion will fail.We hope that the parties will soon be able to return to negotiations on the basis of the 1967 plans and on the basis of a fair recognition of both states and both communities.

name: Marcel de GRAAFF
text: Last week, residents of Israel once again had to live in fear under Hamas' terrorist rocket attacks. According to its charter, this Islamic organization has only one goal: to destroy all Jews in Israel. This violence must end immediately. Israel has adopted Egypt's proposal for a ceasefire. Hamas has rejected this in order to be able to sow even more death and destruction. Obviously, we are dealing here with unscrupulous murderers, with terrorists who are incapable of listening to reason. That is why two measures are needed to end this escalation and this terror: 1. Although Israel is reticent, it deserves the support of this Parliament to eliminate every terrorist in the Gaza Strip. The country derives this right from its duty to protect its own citizens and the Palestinian civilians who are now being used as human shields by these unscrupulous killers. 2. Hamas gives hefty salaries to terrorists if they succeed in murdering innocent Israelis. It is very likely that much of this money comes from the European Union. With this support from the EU, not a peaceful, prosperous society has been built, but a terror state is being created under the watchful eye of the Palestinian Authority. Its leader, Mahmoud Abbas, does not take any responsibility or action. Whether this stems from unwillingness or impotence is completely irrelevant. This EU funding must stop, and immediately! Today the bombs fall on Israel, tomorrow or the day after tomorrow they will fall in Strasbourg, London, Amsterdam or Brussels. The attacks on the Jewish museum in Brussels and on the synagogue in Paris warn us of this. Israel has been burdened by Islamic terror for far too long. We have a historical, moral and cultural duty to support the Jewish people and I request that the Commission move forward as soon as possible towards a solution whereby the Palestinians return to the land that was previously known as Palestine, but which we now know as Jordan. (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Rule 162 (8)).)

name: Emmanouil GLEZOS
text: blue card question.- Madam President, there is no doubt that violence must be condemned wherever it comes from.But my question is: what is the cause?Do the Palestinian people need or not need self-determination and statehood?

name: Marcel de GRAAFF
text: blue-card answer. – The Palestinians should just return to the country that gave them this sovereignty and that is the country that we know as Jordan. As for the violence, we see that we have to deal with a terrorist organisation that is racist, that is anti-Semitic and that actually exists for just one purpose and that is to destroy all Jews in the Middle East. So that is my answer. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Jordi Vicent SEBASTIA TALAVERA
text: blue card question.- Mr De Graaf, have you talked about the containment of the Israeli state - I have seemed to understand that - when those who die under the bombs of the Israeli army are children in the Gaza Strip?Is that containment?Do you know perfectly well that these children were going to be a Hamas terrorist and that, because of this, they deserved death?

name: Marcel de GRAAFF
text: blue-card answer. – Yes, you are absolutely right. There are children’s lives at stake at this moment. These ruthless murderers are using even children as a defence against the people they are attacking, so they are not only attacking Israel and the Jewish population but are also putting their own people at risk and are prepared to have their own children killed. This is a war crime.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the risk of a degeneration of the conflict is evident, with all the consequences both in terms of loss of life and in terms of the qualitative leap of the conflict itself. I think we must not escape the news that is taking place today. I have the impression that the further it goes, the harder it will be to have a controlled conflict if that term can be used. The changes that are taking place in the representation of power in the Gaza Strip in favor of jihadist groups should make Israel reflect more on its mistakes and induce Europe to intervene with greater determination. Resolution is a first response. Cease firing immediately and reopen the terms of the peace negotiations, but perhaps some more courage is needed. We must evaluate some mistakes that have been made by Israel, both in not recognizing Al Fatah's rapprochement with Hamas, and in the settlements of the settlers who continue to move forward and are the cause of so many problems. And then Europe. What does greater protagonism mean? We are among the first and largest financiers of the Palestinian Authority and represent the largest market for Israel. Using these tools to influence and force negotiations is our job. Do not leave a negotiation in the hands of the United States that we should do ourselves, because we have the possibility to do so. This is the qualitative leap that Europe needs, beyond words. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Rule 162 (8))

name: Marek JUREK
text: question asked by picking up a blue card.- Madam President!Dear friend!Would you agree that the most permanent fact is not a new fact, but an unchanging fact that Hamas rejects peace, both in a permanent sense because it rejects the existence of the state of Israel, and in the present sense, because it is Hamas that rejects the truce proposed by Egypt?

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: Answer to a “blue card” question.- To tell the truth, I did not understand the question well, but in any case the fundamental theme is that even in foreign policy it is necessary to go and see the papers and not refuse them.The fact of having rejected this possibility of rapprochement between Hamas and Al Fatah as an element to reopen negotiations is bringing Israel into a much more complicated and difficult condition than in the past.Perhaps some more evaluation on these errors should make it.

name: Geoffrey VAN ORDEN
text: We can all stand here wringing our hands, and the fact is that resolutions from this Parliament are not going to make any difference. Probably the only area where the EU can have any influence is on the use of money and that is what I want to come back to as well, because some 5.6 billion has been spent by the EU on support to the Palestinians over the last twenty years, and I want to know what leverage the European Union has exerted over the Palestinians to bring them to the conference table for that money. What political return has there been on this investment? We continue to pour money into the Palestinian areas with little input on the political situation. The Court of Auditors found that there were people in Gaza being paid from EU funds who were not even working! I do not want to reduce this whole tragic and serious matter to one of pounds, shillings and pence but it is an area that is very important and I hope the next Commission will exercise proper control over EU money and make sure that it is well spent and does not help to fund terrorism.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: Madam President, we have read and heard a lot of things over the past ten days: truths, half-truths, untruths and also a lot of lies. We have just heard it again. Only one thing really matters today: to put an end to the murderous escalation in the region and to bring the parties back to the negotiations without the rockets, as the Minister said. And Egypt proposed it on Monday evening. The total cessation of hostilities, immediately accepted by Israel and by Mahmoud Abbas, is categorically refused by Hamas. Hamas which, by rejecting the truce, promised, I quote: "to intensify the battle". Hamas therefore continues to rain missiles on Israel, Ashdod, Tel Aviv, Jerusalem, Eilat, on the airport, everywhere. This is the reality of Israelis today, a reality that no government in the world would tolerate without reacting. Neither Berlin, nor Madrid, nor Rome, nobody! The fate of the Gazouis is tragic. They are the hostages of a terrorist movement which, for ten years that it has the power in Gaza, has no other agenda than the destruction of the State of the Jews, it is in the charter. Every victim, every man, every woman, every child is a tragedy, one victim too many. And who is responsible? The Israeli army which protects its civilians and asks those in Gaza to flee or the Hamas which calls on the population not to move and to act as a shield? So yes, Netanyahu's government must take its part in the stagnation of negotiations, its lack of a long-term strategy for peace, this way of just managing the conflict. But make no mistake, it is Hamas that is murdering the fate of the Palestinians. And to this tragedy is added another, a despicable reality that we no longer thought we would see, never in Europe; a reality that we must name so as not to add to the misfortune of the world: Europe for the first time in decades is the theater of pogrom. There is no other term to what happened in Paris and Antwerp this weekend. Where will it be tomorrow? So, because these criminal arsonists import hatred, it is urgent for us to impose peace.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: Madam President, 17-month-old Mohammed Malake, 17-year-old Raneem Judeh Abdel Ghafour, 5-year-old Abdallah Ramadan Abu Ghazal, an endless list of over 190 currently dead Palestinians, children, women, the elderly, the disabled, who had a name, family, home, future. Eight families have been lost in their entirety. 160,000 re-displaced, 395,000 with minimal water supply. Three hospitals were hit, more than a thousand houses have been destroyed. What else awaits the newly elected Parliament when war crimes are being committed in front of its eyes? What else does the European Union and Mrs Ashton expect to condemn Israel's aggressive policy? Doesn't anyone hear the protests in the streets of European cities and cities of Israel itself? It is a shame for the European Union and the world to accept impunity for relentless violations of international humanitarian law and the human rights of an entire people subject to the logic of punishment. We support the request of the Palestinian President and call on the UN to bring Palestine under international protection to stop the bloodshed of this people once and for all. If the European Union respects its principles and declarations, it must suspend the association agreement until Israel ceases to violate Article 2, which explicitly states Israel's obligation to respect human rights. We, the United Left Group, want peace for the Palestinian people, the Israeli people, all the peoples of the Middle East. For us, peace means freedom in Palestine. (The speaker agreed to answer a question with a blue card (Rule 162 (8)))

name: Geoffrey VAN ORDEN
text: blue-card question. – Mrs Sylikiotis, it is a classic tactic of terrorists to target civilians deliberately and to use civilians as human shields. Do you not recognise that Israel suffered five days of rocket attacks before she retaliated? That Israel offered a cease-fire which Hamas refused? That Hamas instructed the people in Gaza not to leave their houses and that during the time that Israel suspended her attacks, during that time, fifty rocket attacks were launched from Gaza against Israel? Do you not recognise this?

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: answer "blue card".- But you do not say if there are victims from these attacks.We condemn all acts of terrorism, but above all we condemn the state terrorist attitude of Israel, which kills civilians and children.

name: Margrete AUKEN
text: Madam President! It is now clear, after hearing several of the speakers, that the joint decision of the major groups is quite alarmingly cynical. Where to flee to Gaza? Nowhere! One has to ask oneself what it is that the occupying power can actually achieve by these murders and destructions. Do you believe that the status quo can be restored? If that is the only promise to the Palestinians, it is impossible. The status quo does not exist. The siege of Gaza cannot possibly continue, nor can the occupation of the West Bank and East Jerusalem, and a democratic Israel cannot survive as an apartheid state. We need to come up with more than one hopeless ceasefire proposal. It must be accompanied by a promise to set in motion a just conclusion of the peace. There is now only one major player that can intervene and avert the death of the two-state solution, and that is the EU. The United States has given up, Israel has not delivered at all, only used this so-called peace process to confiscate land, expand settlements and tighten its grip on the Palestinians. But we can! We can take the EU's own legislation seriously by demanding that Israel live up to its part of the partnership agreement by respecting human rights, ie. end the occupation. The EU should now try to live up to the great honor associated with receiving the Nobel Peace Prize. It is not just a gift, it is also a task. Our credibility is simply at stake!

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: Madam President, the Communist Party of Greece strongly condemns the Israeli state's barbaric and criminal attack on the Palestinian people. The Israeli army has killed hundreds of Palestinians and injured thousands more in airstrikes, and thousands more have been displaced. Israel, frightened by the full support of the United States and the European Union, is preparing for ground operations. The responsibilities of the European Union are enormous because it equates perpetrators with victims. In fact, the European Parliament, with its unacceptable resolutions, takes the lead in acquitting Israeli crimes, putting the Palestinian people and their just struggle in the place of the accused. The European Union and the governments of the Member States are systematically upgrading their political, economic, trade and military relations with Israel and conducting joint military exercises, such as those with Greece. The Communist Party of Greece expresses its full solidarity with the struggling Palestinian people and demands an end to airstrikes against the Palestinian people and the prevention of land operations. To cancel the joint military exercises and all the military agreements of the Greek government with Israel as well as to immediately suspend all the political, economic and military agreements of the European Union and Israel. We demand the end of the Israeli occupation and the creation of an independent, viable and sovereign Palestinian state, on the 1967 border with East Jerusalem as its capital. We demand the recognition of the Palestinian state as a UN member state; the demolition of the unacceptable wall separating Jerusalem, the West Bank and Gaza; the immediate lifting of the blockade of the Palestinian territories; the immediate end of the settlements and the the immediate release of all Palestinian political prisoners in Israel and the right of all Palestinian refugees to return to their homes.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: The next speaker is Mr Eugen Freund. Allow me to add one or two personal words. We contested elections together in Austria during the last election campaign. I am glad to see you here as well, even in a different group, as a new Member of this House.

name: Eugen FREUND
text: Madam President, it is a special honour for me to speak here during your presence in the chair, on which I congratulate you very much. We are all very much in favour of a ceasefire, of course. Too much blood has already been spilled, too many innocent people have died, but a ceasefire is certainly not enough, as we have so often witnessed in the Middle East. I stopped counting the ceasefires that just come and go.  We have to put all our emphasis and when I say we, I mean the European Union, we have to put all our efforts into resolving the conflict, otherwise we will only leave yet another generation which does not know anything other than hatred, violence and desperation. It is cruel enough that we rob our young people in Spain, in Italy and in Greece of their hope for the future, as they are not provided with adequate jobs. Now just consider the situation of the youth in the West Bank or in Gaza, living in a stateless entity that is left unable to provide for anything, let alone for a decent living. On the other hand Israel, as we have seen in the present conflict, is under a constant barrage of rocket attacks. This is untenable. In the early 1970s, Bruno Kreisky, the pre-eminent Austrian statesman was one of the first to recognise the severity of the conflict in the Middle East. He did not find enough allies to help him resolve the crisis. Forty years later it is overdue that a reinvigorated and confident European foreign policy steps into that void. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8)).

name: Paul RÜBIG
text: Ask about the “blue card” procedure.- Mister friend!I would like to thank you for your statement, because wherever there is poverty, the conflict naturally becomes all the more severe.Can you imagine taking action from the European Union to eradicate poverty in this area?What actions can you imagine here?

name: Eugen FREUND
text: Answer to a question about the “blue card” procedure.- I believe that you cannot eradicate poverty without eradicating the conflict.So first and foremost we have to work to ensure that this conflict does not continue.We must of course start with a truce.But the ceasefire, as I said before, is only a first step.The conflict really has to be resolved.We cannot just leave these steps to the Americans; we, as Europeans, have to appear here with self-confidence in order to resolve this.Then, of course, we have to take these steps that you mentioned, namely that poverty will also be eradicated.Because a poor people are also a people who have nothing, and that is probably a worse situation than the one they are experiencing now.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Madam President! As a member of the European Parliament for the Family Party in Germany, I am shocked by the initial statements. Aggressors are made victims here. It is a shame that Palestine can be advertised in this way, for a Palestine that doesn't really exist. Israel’s security must be of paramount importance to us Europeans. Israel undoubtedly has the international legal, political and moral right to protect its people from currently over 1,300 rocket attacks. And they do not protect themselves indiscriminately, but try to target the aggressors. The mostly densely populated civilian areas of the Gaza Strip - from there they are fired at Jerusalem, Tel Aviv, Ramat Gan and many other Israeli cities. For the first time ever, long-range weapons are used. The people in Israel spend an average of 15 seconds to escape from the rockets in the protective cellar. For days they have lived in fear in order to bring themselves and their families, their children, to safety. Rocket alarms every minute. I'm not sure how the guns get to Hamas. But I am convinced that it is sometimes supported by EU funds ... (The President cut off the speaker) (The speaker agreed to a question about the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure to answer.)

name: Eleonora FORENZA
text: Question "blue card".- I would like to ask my fellow MEP if he knows that Israel has been an occupying state since 1967, if he knows that as a reaction he is acting in collective punishment in violation of human rights, if he knows that 213 Palestinians have died in recent days and that a fifth of these peoplePalestinians who died in recent days are children.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Answer to a question about the “blue card” procedure.- I am well aware that there are certainly victims here that we have to mourn.Because children die on the Palestinian side too.On the other hand, I don't know why Israel is always blamed for everything.There are millions of Palestinians who are really wasting away in camps in Jordan.Nobody cares about that here!Why is Israel always blamed?Israel is a country with a warfare that is unparalleled anywhere in the world.Calling Israel an aggressor is a shame if we do that here in the European Parliament.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: Madam President, dear colleagues! I would like to take a step back and ask: Where does that come from? How did we get into this situation now? A unity government was formed in Palestine in April, but the president of that unity government was unable to go to the Gaza Strip. Abu Mazen did not go to the Gaza Strip. Why? Because he's afraid of Hamas. It seems to me that there is little unity and little government there. Then three teenagers are kidnapped. Hamas did not distance itself from this kidnapping and murder. Then there was a terrible murder of revenge, the perpetrators are on trial in Israel. Over 1,300 rockets have landed on Israel since July 8th. Frédérique Ries said it: no country in the world can accept it, no country can tolerate it! None of the countries in which we are elected would tolerate a thousand missiles hitting our territory! What are the Israelis doing? They fight back, they fight back hard. But they are trying to obstruct one of Hamas' paths, namely that of human shields, by warning people: “We know the weapons caches are under schools. We know the arsenals are under hospitals. Go, leave these buildings! ”And yes, you can move around in the Gaza Strip, it's not that small either, dear Ms. Auken. Then a ceasefire will be reached under Egyptian mediation. Egypt has been a difficult partner lately, but they mediated here and this ceasefire is accepted by Israel, but not by Hamas! Yes why not? On the contrary, Hamas proclaims: “No, we are intensifying this fight!” What, for God's sake, is Hamas' goal if not aggression, terror and the annihilation of Israel? The way out is obvious: Hamas must accept the ceasefire. But beyond that, Hamas must finally accept Israel's right to a secure existence. Only when the threat to Israel is gone will the Israeli hardliners, the Israeli hawks, who also exist, be deprived of their arguments, and hopefully this will bring us closer to a peaceful solution at some point. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the blue card procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: Question according to the "blue card" procedure.- I wanted to ask Mr. Lambsdorff two questions.He first referred to the abduction and murder of three young Israelis by Hamas.This abduction or murder was not claimed by any Palestinian political organization.The Israeli government has provided no evidence.I would like to know how you can affirm this without proof and without claim by any political organization.And the second question: if you do not think there is much coincidence that, since the Oslo Accords, every time there is an attempt to reach agreement on the Palestinian territory between Palestinian organizations, it always ends with bombings in Gaza.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: Answer to a question about the “blue card” procedure.- Madam!Thanks for the question.I didn't say there was evidence.But with such a horrific murder of three teenagers, one can expect that an organization like Hamas, which exercises authority over a territory that has a certain responsibility, clearly distances itself from such a thing.But she didn't!So I can only say: As long as I don't hear that, I think Hamas is at least partially responsible.As for the other question: I want peace to move in.The Oslo Agreement was an attempt.We have to keep working on it, the resolution is a very small contribution here.Other suggestions have been made.But I think in the end it's because Hamas has to recognize Israel's right to exist in safety.

name: Sofia SAKORAFA
text: Madam President, today we are discussing another European Parliament resolution on the tragic events in Palestine. I recall the results after the last similar resolution: 180 dead, 1,300 houses destroyed, 1,250 injured, including 250 children, and 17,000 refugees. I am also reminded of the results of the hundreds of resolutions of international organizations from 1967 until today, which are co-signed by almost all the members of the European Union today and which are much harsher and more demanding than they are today against Israel. Ladies and gentlemen, what has all this achieved? Six million Palestinian refugees without the right to return to their homeland, two and a half million of them in 25 camps with miserable living conditions, 450,000 settlements in the West Bank and 100,000 in Jerusalem, 750 km of wall up to 12 meters high, 350,000 destroyed, thousands dead and apartheid conditions. Which of these do you think the current resolution can change, ladies and gentlemen? Let's not laugh. At the heart of what is happening in Palestine is the Israeli occupation and the complete impunity of Israel for the crimes it has been committing for half a century now. As a Palestinian national, I am appealing and challenging the European Parliament. Palestine does not need another resolution. Choose one of the crimes committed by Israel, illegal imprisonment, deportation, colonization, whichever you want, and let us, as the European Union, commit to enforcing all the sanctions provided by international treaties until Israel complies. Only one. For the rest, for a free and independent homeland, the Palestinian people have both courage and determination ... (The President interrupts the speaker). (The speaker agreed to answer a question with a blue card (Rule 162 (8)))

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Ask about the “blue card” procedure.- Mrs. Sakorafa!They enumerate a whole host of injustices allegedly done to Palestinians.It would be nice if you made the list in the same way, what the Palestinians did to the Israelites, to really see that these measures are not an aggressive measure, but that they are protective measures.Could you make that list too?

name: Sofia SAKORAFA
text: answer "blue card".- As a Greek woman, now I will talk to you about occupation.If you knew what occupation means - because we Greeks have experienced it - you would understand what resistance also means.So the Palestinian people are resisting this process in order to conquer what they lack, a free and independent homeland.

name: Jan Philipp ALBRECHT
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen! It seems to me that we are leading this debate - not for the first time, by the way - a bit under-complex. This may also be due to the fact that it is actually impossible to write a meaningful contribution to conflict resolution in one or two minutes in this plenary. In the last few years I have exchanged a lot on both sides - with people in Israel and with people in the Palestinian territories. I am convinced that all these people and the conflict will not be helped at all if you simply transfer it here to the plenary of the European Parliament, if everyone takes their own position - which is relatively easy - and then withdraws there and tries, convince the other that one side is right and the other is wrong. That is far too sub-complex. Both societies - both the Palestinians and Israeli society - are very diverse. There are not mainly terrorists among the Palestinians, so to speak, and there are not mainly right-wing Israelis who are of the opinion that the best thing to do is to grant the Palestinians no rights at all. This is total bullshit. I think it is important that this complexity finally moves in here in this House and that we talk about what kind of peace the partners are on both sides, deal with these partners and play a helping role as Parliament and not those who are responsible for the conflict just transported and reflected.

name: Marita ULVSKOG
text: Madam President! We received some figures from Mr Della Vedova on how many people have been killed in the Gaza Strip and southern Israel in recent days.
