And how many have been killed in the last five years? The last ten years? The last 40 years? And how many will have lost life and hope before there can be a lasting peace based on a two-state solution where two democratic states can live side by side? Direct peace talks must, of course, be resumed. Both parties must also address the underlying causes. Extremism must be pushed back, settlement policy must end. The EU and the Member States of Europe must play a more active political role. This is the most central issue for us, it is necessary to solve and to get involved in. We will do everything we can, said Mr Della Vedova. Well, do it now - together with us, together with the UN Security Council and regional actors. And to anyone who has participated in this debate with senseless outcomes and claims, I would recommend trying to do the following: see yourself in others.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: Madam President, Israel is a democratic state respectful of the rule of law, and of course it wants peace. But it cannot be subject to unremitting rocket attacks on its civilian areas without defending itself and its civilian population, and the right to retaliate militarily against Hamas and Islamic Jihad is its right under international law in Gaza – and it is they who are responsible for this tragedy. Ms Auken, this is compounded by their habit – a war crime – of using innocent Palestinian civilians as human shields and hiding their weapons in mosques and schools. Israel does everything humanly possible to minimise civilian casualties; in contrast, Hamas has a total disregard for human life. Even the Palestinian Authority’s President Abbas has stated as much. Now, the cruel rejection by Hamas of the Egyptian ceasefire is not only a tragedy for the Gaza civilian population, who are already undergoing a humanitarian crisis, but it is also militarily suicidal for Hamas, which, as we must remember in this House, is a terrorist organisation banned by the EU. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Margrete AUKEN
text: blue-card question. – I just want to ask whether you know of the Goldstone report, produced after the ‘Operation Cast Lead’ war, because it is clear that there is no proof of these allegations of the use of human shields. There is no proof. The allegations come from the Israeli media, and we know that media are highly controlled in wartime. Secondly, I want to ask whether you know how Gaza looks. name: Ángela VALLINA
text: Madam President, we certainly consider it unacceptable that the European Union, which claims to be the standard bearer of freedoms and human rights, maintains an association agreement with a State such as Israel, whose government maintains an apartheid system against the Palestinian population in the fringe. name: Bodil VALERO
text: answer ("blue card").- I'm glad I got a question ("blue card") to answer because I'm so upset about the senseless statements I've heard here in this House today.And I share my Social Democratic Swedish colleague's view that these are senseless statements.Of course, it is not the case that these 66 years have passed unnoticed in any way, but we must know that it is about two peoples: it is an occupying power and it is an occupied people.

name: Ana GOMES
text: Attacking Gaza in retaliation for damning Hamas attacks with disproportionate military force violates international law.It may even reach Hamas' operational capacity, but it sweeps civilian neighborhoods, schools and hospitals.The procession of victims will feed the narrative and the recruitment of radicals.Terror against the people of Gaza does not defend the people of Israel, nor does it guarantee the state of Israel a future.Since 2005, Israel has been blocking borders and movements, controlling water and other resources.Israel has established and surrounds the concentration camp, Hamas is the jailer on duty.Both strangle Gaza and the viability of the State of Palestine and peace in the region.The European Union fails us: it went from being a promoter of peace, at the time of the Venice Declaration, to paying for the systematic destruction of Palestine undertaken by Israel.The European Union must make itself heard: Israel's ground offensive in Gaza must be stopped now.

name: Teresa RODRIGUEZ-RUBIO
text: Madam President, Israel's wall violates international legality and the principles of the United Nations Charter, divides families and peoples and makes normal life impractical. Israel's wall is illegal - and I'm not saying it. It was said ten years ago, in a July like this, by the International Court of Justice in The Hague. The anniversary coincides with the umpteenth collective punishment of the State of Israel on Gaza and the West Bank. There have already been others: 2008, operation «Cast Lead»; 2012, "Defense Pillar" operation. They all deserved lukewarm condemnation from this Parliament. All these attacks, in the end, went unpunished. Unpunished also in the face of a shameful equidistance between one of the most important armies in the world and a people occupied and isolated by land, by sea and by air - in what has been called the largest prison in the world. What can we do? At a minimum, rethink the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement until the human rights set forth in Article 2 are fulfilled. Tomorrow it will be said in the street: tomorrow there will be mobilizations throughout Europe - also in Israel by civil society - and the international community will be asked a reaction.

name: Gilles PARGNEAUX
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, this afternoon we have to send two messages. First of all we must demand an immediate ceasefire, because the situation is becoming intolerable, 200 dead in a few days in Palestine. This afternoon, four children were killed in a cabin on a beach in Gaza. Then, we must be clear with Israel: the existence of two States - an Israeli State, a Palestinian State - does not succeed because in the end, the Israeli authorities do not want them today. This is the reality and I proclaim loud and clear this sentence of Mahmoud Abbas "There is not one state too many, but a state is missing in the Middle East". Nothing is more true. It is therefore time for Europe to assume its responsibilities, for the high authority representing foreign affairs to assume its responsibilities. We are Israel's primary trading partners, so let's stop being afraid to act. Let's play politics and get Israel to negotiate with the cards on the table. We cannot remain in this situation where Israel does not want to discuss the peace process for the recognition of a Palestinian state. Without this dialogue, we will only be able to deplore the end of the ceasefires every two or three years and the continuation of the violence and suffering. We cannot be complicit in the continuation of this cycle of despair. We cannot abandon the two-state thesis. Let us stop having weak positions and weakening the few measures we take, such as the non-financing of the European Union for Israeli projects located in the Occupied Territories. This is the reality. These are our political positions that we must reaffirm today.

name: Patrick LE HYARIC
text: Madam President, Mr Delegate of the Vice-President / High Representative, you have given a balanced and interesting presentation. As you said, we must put an end to all violence, but we must never forget that there is an occupying country, the State of Israel, overarmed, and an occupied country, with bare hands, the Palestinian people. There is a country which violates international law every day with impunity, which steals the lands and houses of another people, which imprisons its children, its activists, its parliamentarians, and now it is challenging the Palestinians, the right to form the government they want is the State of Israel. The European Union cannot remain silent in the face of the daily crimes taking place in Gaza today. You must take international initiatives in order to obtain a ceasefire, the end of the blockade of Gaza and the end of colonization. Use all the means at your disposal, including the use of Article 2 of the Association Agreement, and suspend all relations until Israel comes to its senses and complies with international law. Respond to Mahmoud Abbas' call to place the Palestinian people under international protection.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Madam President! The events in Gaza are hard to beat in terms of tragedy, mainly because it is a conflict that repeats itself with unbearable regularity, on average every two years. If processes are repeated in this way, it means that it is obviously not possible to get the causes of the problem under control. It is also not possible to give an explanation for this within one minute of speaking time. That is probably exactly the core of the problem: that we have been trying out such simple explanations for decades. The Israeli-Palestinian conflict is one of the greatest conflicts of the time. The problems are extremely complex. It is not only about problems of international law, but also about social and economic backgrounds. This statement must not lead us to relativize responsibility. Nevertheless, the solution can be outlined with a single sentence. More than ever, what Yitzhak Rabin, Israel's former prime minister, who had embarked on the path of understanding with the PLO, said a few minutes before his assassination at the great peace rally in Tel Aviv 20 years ago: "The path of peace is the path of Preferable to war. I tell you this as someone who was a military man for 27 years. "

name: Afzal KHAN
text: Madam President, hundreds of angry constituents have contacted me about the killing of innocent people in Gaza. Israel’s response has been utterly disproportionate: it is estimated that one Israeli and more than 200 Palestinians have lost their lives. According to the UN office, 80% of these are civilians. Moreover, more than 100 000 people have been asked to leave their homes. We should not accept that all this comes under Israel’s right to self-defence. Collective punishment must end if we do not want extremism to increase. We know from the history that it is largely the Palestinians who have suffered and that Israel has systematically eaten away at their land, breaking all international laws. Both sides need to understand that there is no military solution. A two-state solution may become redundant if we do not call for an immediate ceasefire and redouble our efforts to ensure a lasting peace. The EU, the winner of a Nobel peace prize, cannot remain a silent observer any longer. It prides itself on championing human rights and it must therefore lead this peace effort, providing the voice of sanity and hope. The three Abrahamic faiths have a common saying: ‘Wish for others what you wish for yourself.’ Both sides need to practise this.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Thank you very much Ulrika, congratulations on the presidency of this House and on this debate. Both you, I and many who have spoken here have been in this House for a long time. And we really return to such discussions about relations between Israel and Palestine here on a regular basis, and that discussion is always about opponents of Israel and those who, despite never visiting these territories, point to Israel as the aggressor. I have been in the interparliamentary delegation with Israel for 10 years, I have visited these territories several times, and if some in this House want to simplify this debate just to criticize Israel, I absolutely do not understand the whole situation. I am a staunch pacifist, I am against any military intervention. Nevertheless, I am convinced that no such discussion has ever been caused by Israel's attack on Palestine alone. And I am very sorry that those who criticize Israel here are not saying that they feel sorry for the women they use to commit suicide attacks in Israel to kill Israeli children.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: In the past few days, there have been more than 150 deaths, including children, more than a thousand injured and the systematic destruction of Palestinian homes.In the past 24 hours, six United Nations Agencies facilities, including schools and health centers, have been hit, bombed and, probably, with each passing hour, while we are here, more deaths are happening.In dozens of years, illegal occupation, repression, usurpation, plunder and permanent humiliation by Israel to the Palestinian people.In the resolution that Parliament is likely to adopt, it is unacceptable, it is cynical and it is shameful to make it believe that the aggressor is the victim and that the victim is the aggressor.To want to be neutral in a situation of state terrorism by an occupying power is the same as being a collaborator and an accomplice in this aggression.

name: Benedetto DELLA VEDOVA
text: President-in-Office of the Council, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission and High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. - Madam President, I thank the parliamentarians for this debate. It has been said that the situation is fraught with complexity and I believe this discussion has borne witness to this. It is also true that, as has been said a moment ago, this debate is similar to other discussions that I have happened to witness and participate in in this very House, as a Member of the European Parliament. But I believe that precisely for this reason, because the issues remain these, not only should not be lacking but the commitment of the European Union in particular must be reinforced. It is of the fundamental interest of the European Union to support the process towards peace and democracy in the entire Middle East region and to help end the Israeli-Palestinian conflict which, until resolved, will continue to undermine the peace and security that is just around the corner. of the European Union and, perhaps not directly, also to be one of the causes of what happens inside the borders of the European Union. He was recalled several times in the discussion preceding the attack right in the heart of the European institutions, at the Jewish museum in Brussels. The episodes of violence in southern Israel and in Gaza, occurring in an extremely unstable region, reaffirm the urgency to work towards this goal. Events show that there will be no definitive cessation of violence or lasting peace as long as the aspirations of Palestinians for statehood and sovereignty and those of Israelis for security are both met through a negotiated global peace based on the coexistence of two states. Together with its partners from the international community and the region, the European Union will continue to appeal to Prime Minister Netanyahu and President Abbas to end the violence, resume negotiations and work with renewed determination to resolve the conflict. The European Union is called to play - and this has been recalled several times today - an important role in this context and intends to continue to do so in the critical weeks and months to come.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. - The very terms that frame this debate are perverse, misleading and unacceptable. Israeli aggression against the Palestinian people, with the criminal military offensive against the Gaza Strip and its people, is disguised as escalating violence between Israel and Palestine. The disappearance and subsequent confirmation of the death of three young men from an Israeli settlement, in unclear circumstances, was the pretext for a collective punishment campaign against the Palestinian settlements, with the indiscriminate demolition of houses, murders and the arrest of hundreds of people, including dozens of children and members of the Palestinian Legislative Council. The ongoing Israeli military campaign is supported by the continued political, diplomatic and military support of the USA and the attitude of the European Union, which hides in its silence or conceals, under a false equidistant discourse, the effective complicity with the State terrorism policy of Israel. Pretending to rehearse a supposed neutrality stance towards the victim and the aggressor, towards the busy and the occupant, is nothing but an unacceptable and also criminal act of complicity, which cannot be left unclaimed. We express all solidarity with the Palestinian people, with their heroic and determined resistance and national liberation struggle, in the face of the genocidal policy of the State of Israel.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: The next item is the debate on the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the crime of aggression (2014/2724(RSP)).

name: Benedetto DELLA VEDOVA
text: President-in-Office of the Council, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission and High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, tomorrow 17 July will be celebrated International Day of Justice in conjunction with the sixteenth anniversary of the Rome Statute of the International Criminal Court, adopted on 17 July 1998. With the Rome Statute, the world has consolidated its historic commitment to prevent and discourage the most heinous crimes. Activating this promise of justice towards the victims of the crimes contemplated by the Rome Statute is a moral imperative and, at the same time, an essential contribution to peace, security and well-being in the world. Today the International Criminal Court is the pivot around which the international criminal justice system is articulated and an important tool for placing the perpetrators of the most serious crimes of international importance before their responsibilities. The EU, as is well known, is part of a solid tradition of firm support for the International Criminal Court. We believe that the international community finds in an efficient court an indispensable tool to combat impunity and promote an international order based on the rule of law. The International Criminal Court will remain an important priority for the European Union in the years to come. We therefore very much welcome today's plenary debate on the crime of aggression. The active involvement of the European Parliament in this important issue for human rights and international justice is crucial. With the Review Conference of the Rome Statute, held in Kampala, Uganda, from 31 May to 10 June 2010, a milestone was set by offering States, international organizations and representatives of civil society present in Kampala a forum in to reaffirm the determination to promote the Statute and take stock of international criminal justice, but not only. The Kampala Review Conference also marked an important step in consolidating the International Criminal Court as an effective tool by which the international community brings to justice those criminally responsible for crimes covered by the Rome Statute when national judges are unable or unwilling to prosecute them. . The Review Conference adopted important amendments to the Rome Statute, including the definition of the crime of aggression and the conditions under which the International Criminal Court can exercise jurisdiction in the matter. The amendment must now be ratified or accepted by the States parties to the Rome Statute. Provided that a sufficient number of ratifications are made and that a two-thirds majority of States take a decision to do so after 1 January 2017, the International Criminal Court will be able to exercise jurisdiction over the crime of aggression. As this Parliament is aware, all Member States of the European Union are parties to the Statute and some have even already ratified the Kampala Amendment on the crime of aggression. In others, the ratification process is, on the other hand, in the final or in any case advanced phase, while still others have indicated that they have no intention of ratifying this amendment for the time being. As it is not itself part of the Rome Statute, the European Union cannot ratify the amendment. However, with the facilitation offered by the European External Action Service, the Member States of the European Union exchange information and, where appropriate, coordinate on the progress of the ratification process. Our common goal in this process is clear: to further strengthen the Court to fulfill its mandate. The Rome Statute is a promise made to the victims of the worst atrocities in the world, the promise that they will get justice, the promise that, seeing the guilty faced with their responsibilities, the affected communities will be able to leave behind the violence in favor of peace, illegality in favor of the rule of law. Few of us could have predicted, ten years ago, that the Court would establish itself as the pivot of all discussions on the fight against impunity. Few of us imagined, ten years ago, that the court would be able to prosecute crimes committed in fifteen countries spanning three continents. But many have worked on this objective and welcome the results achieved, including in parliaments and also in the European Parliament. Today's debate on the crime of aggression illustrates once again how, under the Rome Statute, the Institutional Criminal Court continues to play, together with national judges, an essential role in guaranteeing justice to the victims of the most heinous crimes.

name: Andrzej GRZYB
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - We have had the opportunity to listen to current information on the functioning of the International Criminal Court many times, in particular in the Subcommittee on Human Rights. We also made some recommendations that would strengthen the role of this Court, and all those activities in which the European Union could support the work of this Court. The Kampala amendments to the Rome Statute define the notion of the crime of aggression, which is to fall under the jurisdiction of the International Criminal Court. For this to happen, these amendments must be ratified by at least 30 countries. So far, as we point out in the resolution we will vote on tomorrow, 14 countries have ratified them, including 8 Member States of the European Union. I hope that soon there will be more of these countries, including my country, Poland, which is already at the final stage of work on the ratification during the ratification procedure. The crime of aggression is an invasion of another country, but also its shelling, blocking its ports. Aggression can be carried out both by a regular army and by supporting irregular armed forces on the territory of another state. I am convinced that if these amendments had entered into force a few years ago, perhaps we would have avoided at least some of the conflicts that have occurred since then, and thus, most importantly, we could have avoided a lot of human suffering and the tragedy of many nations. Tomorrow is World Justice Day. I think that the adoption of this resolution calling for the early completion of the ratification process by those countries that accept the Kampala amendments would be a very important step on this day.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Madam President, ladies colleagues, I believe it is desirable to give perhaps a political dimension to our debate. It was recalled by the Honorable Della Vedova that tomorrow is the World Day of International Criminal Justice. I believe that it is a symbolic day that marks the anniversary of the adoption of the Rome Statute, the founding treaty of the International Criminal Court. I think it is a day also imagined as a time to reflect and act on the suffering of those who are still victims of atrocities, genocides, crimes against humanity, war crimes and aggression of one state against another, but also to spread the fight impunity for these crimes and celebrate progress in the field of international criminal justice. My view is that Kampala was a historic conference. The revision of the Rome Statute has opened a new path and we must be able to follow it to the end. On the occasion of this conference, the member countries of the International Criminal Court, after almost a decade of discussions, reached an agreement on the shared definition of "crime of aggression" as an offense of the state, for years a source of discord in international law. After numerous reviews and high-level meetings, a long way has been made. But there is still much to be done because the dramatic events in the international context of recent times - I am thinking of Ukraine, as I am thinking of the debate we have just had about Israeli and Palestinian issues - show with great force that a lot is must do on the level of the effectiveness of international criminal law. It was recalled that several countries have already ratified the Kampala amendments and many have begun their national procedures. Even if these are long and complex, I believe that it is essential to find a positive outcome as soon as possible. Now we think that remembering the historical importance of this compromise is a duty, as is re-launching European and international attention on the crime of aggression as an offense and on the Kampala compromise, which defines it, providing for the jurisdiction of the International Criminal Court. about this crime. The time has come to commit with a single voice to push for the states, which have not yet done so, to provide for ratifications. Even if the European Union is not an integral part of the Statute, we need to bring this important issue back into the political dimension.

name: Karol KARSKI
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Madam President! Aggression is historically considered the most important crime of international law. It also often creates opportunities or even an impulse to commit further international crimes, such as war crimes, the crime of genocide or crimes against humanity. The international community needs a universal legal definition of aggression, because unfortunately we do not have one. The London Conventions of 1933, which formulate such a legal definition, bind only about 10 countries, including mine - Poland. Unfortunately, only in the relationship between them. On the other hand, the resolution of the United Nations General Assembly of 1974 No. 3314, which is universal in nature, like any resolution of this body, is not a legally binding definition. The adoption of the Kampala amendment to the ICC's statute will therefore create a new quality, equip this court with the possibility of punishing perpetrators of aggression and give us a legal definition that will be binding. At the same time, it will be adopted in the target model by a significant part of the international community. Let us not forget, however, that even today, on the basis of universal jurisdiction, the perpetrators of the crime of aggression may be punished by domestic courts, not only their own, but also by ad hoc international criminal tribunals, established after committing the crime of aggression or other international crimes. Let us also use this possibility.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, the world we live in is far from ideal in spite of continuous and multiple efforts by many of us. The world’s history in general, and Europe’s in particular, is full of dark pages of wars, aggression, destruction and other unfortunate events. Did we learn any lessons? Did we do everything possible to prevent that happening again? It does not look so, even though we have just commemorated the start of World War One and are about to meet the 75th anniversary of the start of World War Two. At the same time we have to salute all international efforts to close legal loopholes that still exist in international humanitarian law and the Rome Statutes by criminalising the crime of aggression. We have to agree that this can be done only by undertaking all possible measures, by accepting necessary legal frameworks for naming the illegal use of force which manifestly violates the United Nations Charter. In 2010 the states parties, including all EU Member States, adopted the Kampala amendments to the Rome Statute which establishes the International Criminal Court. The above-mentioned amendments mainly provide for adding the crime of aggression to the list of crimes falling under ICC jurisdiction, thereby completing the ICC jurisdiction and deterring Member States from illegal use of force. It is against those who are willing and ready to challenge the peace and security of others.  Here I should make clear that the Kampala amendments do not cover cases of self-defence or a UN Security Council mandate. By now eight EU Member States have ratified and completed procedures for enforcing the Kampala amendments; it is good but not enough. 2014 is a crucial year to encourage states to start and continue the process of ratification of the amendments, given the long time that ratification of international instruments requires in many countries. The existing momentum should be fully used to push for ratification now. The resolution we are debating tonight explicitly calls for an EU common position around the issue. This is the key part of the document. The resolution in focus is about protecting human rights: this is the ultimate goal of the EU’s policies.

name: Helmut SCHOLZ
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President, President-in-Office of the Council Della Vedova! Today's debate is about the future criminal prosecution of military and political leaders for the crime of war of aggression - and that on the eve of tomorrow's International Justice Day, and here too today after a debate on the situation in Iraq, in the Middle East. Unfortunately, this list could go on indefinitely. The political core of the question is as follows: In order for the International Criminal Court to act in the matter from 2017, 30 signatory states of the Rome Statute must have ratified the compromise reached in 2010 and incorporated it into national law. Two thirds of the time, 14 ratifications have been deposited, eight of them from EU member states. Even if you take into account the eleven EU Member States that are at different stages of preparing for ratification, there are still nine - and not exactly small - Member States that are not moving - I ask: do not want to move? I do not think the situation is acceptable. That is why our demand for speedy ratification is directed primarily to the EU Member States themselves. I expect a clear program on the matter from the High Representative and a concrete timetable as to when this situation will be resolved.

name: Barbara LOCHBIHLER
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen! The review conference for the International Criminal Court in Kampala in 2010 passed by consensus the proposal to prosecute war of aggression as a crime in the future. The International Criminal Court has so far been responsible for the prosecution of war crimes, crimes against humanity and genocide and is now also supposed to punish the crime of aggression. The prerequisite is that the type, gravity and scope of the act of attack constitute a manifest violation of the UN Charter. For these crimes, however, not ordinary soldiers should be prosecuted, but people who are actually in a position to direct the political and military action of a state. In our resolution we call on the EU to adopt a common position on the crime of aggression and to actively seek to obtain the 30 necessary ratifications. So far fourteen states have ratified, including eight EU member states. And all EU member states that have not yet ratified are called upon to initiate this immediately. On September 1st of this year we are celebrating the 75th anniversary of the attack by Nazi Germany on Poland, a war of aggression that led directly to World War II - with all the resulting crimes against peace, crimes against humanity and war crimes. The Nuremberg war crimes trials also ruled on the crimes of war of aggression, among other things, and I would like to quote from the opening speech of the US chief prosecutor Robert Jackson in November 1945: "But the last step, to prevent recurring wars, which are inevitable with international lawlessness, is to hold statesmen accountable before the law. And let me make it clear: this law will initially only be applied to German attackers. But it does include, and if it is to be of any use, it must condemn the attack of any other nation, not except those who are now in judgment here. ”Waging war of aggression is not an ordinary crime. As the Nuremberg War Crimes Court ruled in 1946, it is the greatest international crime of all because it includes the collective evil of all other war crimes.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, José Ayala Lasso, when he held the position of High Commissioner for Human Rights at the United Nations, said that a man who has killed one person has a better chance of being tried than one who has killed 100,000. . This affirmation, sadly real, should make us reflect on the reasons that have slowed down the process of consolidation of the principle according to which no, and I stress no, type of aggression can be accepted and tolerated today. This Parliament, the only elected body in the old continent, will not have the legislative competence necessary to impose ratifications on the Member States, but it can certainly play a role of fundamental influence. With the Kampala conference, a shared definition of crime and the act of aggression was reached, tracing a parallel defining path of both the state's offense and individual crime. It is certainly a step forward, but the prevention process could and should have already been completed. The European Parliament already in 2011 welcomed the adoption of the Kampala amendments to the Rome Statute and asked the Commission and the Council to induce Member States to ratify them and introduce them into their criminal systems. Unfortunately, at the moment only eight states of the Union have done so. The inertia of the other winds - including Italy, alas - is in no way justifiable. There are twenty out of twenty-eight states that are represented in this hemicycle and have not yet ratified the agreement. What does this mean? Do we or do we not want to react firmly to the acts of aggression and human rights violations that are unfortunately on the agenda? Giving the International Criminal Court the possibility to intervene on the crime of aggression would constitute a real deterrent to put an end to the rampant impunity towards those States and those subjects who act in disregard of human rights, jeopardizing peace and safety in the world. Dear colleagues, I hope that the Kampala amendments on the crime of aggression will be ratified by the missing states and come into force as soon as possible. This Union, born as a community on a continent torn apart by world conflict, should pioneer and concretely defend the values ​​of peace and human rights throughout the rest of the world.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: Madam President, I would like to welcome the holding of this debate on the crimes of aggression during the first session of the European Parliament devoted to substantive issues. It is a very good omen, for the new legislature, that we are addressing a subject which is at the heart of our concerns for the defense of human rights. The European Union has always been an ardent supporter of the International Criminal Court and in the previous mandate, we accompanied, through our resolutions, the developments linked to the Kampala amendment process, as well as the efforts aimed at strengthening the Court. and to ensure the universality and integrity of the Rome Statute. The adoption of the amendments on the definition of the crime of aggression marked a turning point in the development of international criminal law by completing the system of protection set up by the Rome Statute. However, to be able to activate the Court's jurisdiction over the crime of aggression in 2017 will require a decision by the Assembly of States Parties after at least 30 States Parties have ratified, ideally before the end. of 2015 the Kampala Amendments. So far, only fourteen States Parties have ratified these amendments, including eight Member States of the Union. We are therefore far from the mark and we need a common coordinated action at European level to promote the ratification of the Kampala amendments and their integration into national legislation. This is a crucial question because it is about giving us the means to effectively prevent the unlawful use of force. Here again, Europe should lead by example by acting resolutely against impunity and to promote peace through criminal justice.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Madam President! Today we are debating a resolution calling on all Member States to do something they should have done a long time ago, namely to ratify the Kampala Amendments. Why is that so important? This process would further develop international criminal justice and thus strengthen its scope and binding force. So far there have been four offenses under the jurisdiction of the International Criminal Court: genocide, crimes against humanity, war crimes, and the crime of aggression. However, until now the International Criminal Court has failed to develop jurisdiction over crimes of aggression. The Rome Statute, on the basis of which it was established, does not have a detailed definition of the facts. For this reason, members of the military and political leadership elite cannot be held responsible if they initiate an act of attack that violates the prohibition of force in the UN Charter. As things stand at present, these groups of people cannot be held personally responsible if, for example, they order unlawful invasions, bombardments, the blockade of ports or the deployment of armed gangs, or if they make their territory available for such actions. When you hear that, you can clearly see some of the incidents of the last few weeks. The crime of aggression is only defined through the Kampala Amendments, which were passed after lengthy negotiations. We also already know the requirements that are required for how many states would have to ratify it. It is actually very regrettable that so far only eight EU countries have completed this process. Other Member States are taking part, including my home country Austria. I would like to point out one more point: after all, crimes are punished primarily because they have a deterrent effect. Crimes of aggression are crimes of conduct and the crime of aiding and abetting is explicitly excluded. So far it has often happened that the perpetrators were punished, but those who ordered the crimes went free. This unjust reversal of guilt will be broken by the amendments to be ratified. They send a clear signal to those responsible that they are aware of their leadership responsibility, because crimes of aggression may no longer go unpunished in the future.

name: Ana GOMES
text: I am very honored to be among the promoters of the resolution that the European Parliament must adopt tomorrow in this matter. The entry into force of the jurisdiction of the International Criminal Court on the crime of aggression, defined and approved by the States Parties in Kampala, will allow the foundation of a system that effectively penalizes the illegal use of armed force and that opens the possibility of accountability perpetrators of violence against territorial integrity and independence between States Parties. The introduction in the field of International Criminal Law of the definition of the crime of aggression is a civilizational advance necessary to strengthen the jurisdiction of the International Criminal Court, but also vital to mark the relevance of the United Nations Charter and to strengthen the binding character of the decisions of the Council of UN Security. The crime of aggression inaugurates a new era in the jurisdiction of the Court. If the jurisdiction of the Court has hitherto focused on crimes of genocide, crimes against humanity, war crimes, against individuals and peoples, criminal jurisdiction over crimes of aggression allows States to be held criminally responsible for the use of unlawful and unsanctioned military force United Nations Charter, namely with implications for the right to self-defense. This is a fundamental civilizational step towards the establishment of a true collective security order. But for that to happen, the deterrent effect must work, we must invest, the European Union must invest politically in the ratification of the Rome Statute of the ICC and in the amendments approved in Kampala by all the States that have not yet accepted jurisdiction of the Court and, in particular, those who are our partners in the framework of various cooperation agreements. It is also necessary that the mechanisms for activating jurisdiction provided for in the Kampala amendments to the Court's Statute be used and that the Security Council undertakes responsible action in line with the United Nations Charter. Given the enhanced powers in the matter that give the Security Council the right to determine whether or not a given event constitutes an act of aggression punishable under international criminal law, which will inevitably raise the bar by which the Prosecutor of the Court can or not investigating an aggression case, then it is vital that the five permanent members do not embark on a strategy of purposefully delaying the work of the Prosecutor in order to guarantee themselves an immunity and their allies. A position taken by the Security Council is fundamental in this matter, in accordance with the objectives stipulated in Kampala. The European Union, which was built from the rubble left in Europe, and not only by Nazi Germany, has to adopt a common position in this matter, as we call for in this European Parliament resolution, without fail to act as a bastion of the ICC and recognition of the crime of aggression.

name: Benedetto DELLA VEDOVA
text: President-in-Office of the Council, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission and High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. - Madam President, in thanking the Members who have spoken for their contribution to the debate on this important issue, allow me to reiterate that the European Union is part of a solid tradition of firm support for the International Criminal Court. We consider that the international community finds in an efficient court an indispensable tool to fight impunity and promote an international order based on the rule of law, peace and reconciliation. For this reason, the International Criminal Court will remain an important priority of the European Union in the years to come. The EU will therefore continue to support the International Criminal Court at the political and diplomatic level, as well as with logistics and funding. As a concrete example of support, I will mention the European Union's commitment to the universality of the Rome Statute and to promoting a better understanding of the mandate of the International Criminal Court. The EU continues to do its utmost to advance this process in third countries, in particular in regular human rights dialogues with over forty countries, with systematic campaigns of diplomatic initiatives around the world, with the organization of local or regional seminars on issue, with the systematic insertion of a clause on the International Criminal Court in agreements with third countries - as it was mentioned above - or with financial support for civil society organizations active in promoting the universality of the Statute. The European External Action Service will continue to facilitate the exchange of information and coordination between Member States in the progress of the ratification process which, as has been said, concerns the Member States individually. There are some - they have been mentioned, starting with mine - who are still engaged in the ratification process and we will ask that the ratification processes underway be accelerated - starting naturally from Italy.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: I would like to thank you for your comment that you, as acting President-in-Office, will ask your Member State and also thank all of those other speakers who said that they, as parliamentarians, would push their own Member States to continue to ratify. Allow me this comment here from the chair as it is important that we continue to have Member States sign up to the agreement. The motions for resolutions to be tabled under Rule 123(2) will be announced in the House at a later time. The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, 17 July 2014.
